characters: NOT GONNA START NOW, YOUNG LADY
GAME 1 MINNESOTA AMERICANS AT MIAMI SHARKS

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: EXT. "SHARK" STADIUM (MIAMI, USA) - LATE DAY Al (ANY SUNDAY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC sets a mood of mystery, verdure, sky... Grass sways gently in the wind, silence to the world... Then a football is placed in the grass. The large, taped knuckles of a center grasp the football for the snap. The world is still, coiled like a spring... CREDITS RUN...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS ACTION
dialogues.text: An EXPLOSION on the field -- as bodies crash against each other like armies. The game as played and felt in "the pi A swift, short pass over the middle... A tight end (Miami) takes the hit... Then the quarterback (Miami) goes down hard. A blur of motion. A WHISTLE BLOWS and referee #1 signals first down; chains are moved.

dialogues.speaker: HELICOPTER
dialogues.text: A steep view of the proceedings -- godlike, evoking ghosts, wind; as if the football gods look down on their human combatants and vote for first downs, touchdowns, careers, lives... These overheads punctuate the film... The silence lingers briefly -- before the Announcers' voices bring us back to the media reality of the late 20th Century...

dialogues.speaker: TUG KOLOWSKI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (on TV) «+. And what a beautiful day for football it is here in South Florida!! It's Sunday, and the sun is shining and playoff berths are on the line. It doesn't get much better than this! Don't you think so, Kevin?!

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN BRANSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (on TV) That's the one thing you and I can agree on, Tug. You can almost feel religion in the air here at Miami's 'Shark' Stadium. The MUSIC THEME -- a blend of martial, choral, and rock and roll -- is now swallowed in the ROAR of the CROWD...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «+. the technicolor eyes of quarterback JACK "CAP" ROONEY, hostage to anger and pain, as his aging frame crashes on the dirty grass.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Head coach TONY D'AMATO, a striking, intense man in his 50s, moves in a five-yard swath of the sideline, his eyes flicking worriedly to his fallen alter-ago.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I've been doin' this for too many years... (at McKenna) You mother...!!! Goddamn ass...!!! He's giving it to Leslie McKenna, the right guard, and the other linemen, as he senses the game is now shifting momentum -- against him.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: .»». ‘mother!... you candy ass... no blockin' bitches!... 68?! McKenna, get your brain-dead head out of your ass!! You're not blocking, you're tip-toeing through the tulips!

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: DR. ALLIE POWERS, 30s, the new internist with the team, grabs his doctor box and starts onto the field.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Powers! Get the hell back here! Where you going?! He's fine! Powers sheepishly u-turns back to the sideline where DR. HARVEY MANDRAKE, the grey-haired team orthopedist, gives him a second scolding.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: What are you thinking, Allie?! There's 1:43 on the clock! You walk on that field after the 2- minute warning and we automatically lose a time-out. Wake-up! You been here almost a goddamn season!

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Sorry -- I thought he was hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As LESLIE McKENNA (#63), the big right guard, helps Cap up, knowing he's blown the block.

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yes, sir! That's the real deal right there. Cap Rooney... Two Pantheon Cups. Almost 50,000 passing yards. More touchdowns than I care to remember...

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: (vising, to McKenna) McKenna, you fat bubble of lard! One more block like that, you'll end my career!

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: «+. Our computers rank Jack Rooney one of the top five quarterbacks of all time when it comes to pressure situations... At 39 he may be a step or two behind -- 12 off-season operations have a way of doing that to you -- but he still stands head and shoulders above these new kids...

dialogues.speaker: WIVES' SECTION
dialogues.text: CINDY ROONEY, a sweet-looking blonde, waves back as she notices the electronic eye gazing down on her; other wives join in.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .. Without a doubt, Tug! ‘'Rock' Rooney also happens to be married to a heckuva nice gal sittin' down there in the stands just like the star struck fan she's been since their college days together at Michigan -- that's Cindy Rooney, folks, and I can tell you...

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Stop boasting, Kev! But beautiful she certainly is, un-hunh!... Anda mother of three beautiful children...

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Coach D'Amato fumbles with his newly-mangled headset, consults his plastic-coated single-page game plan, into his mouthpiece: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Nick, where the hell are we here?! Whatta ya think -- Ace Right 90 Cadillac? 60-40 against?

dialogues.speaker: COACH'S BOOTH
dialogues.text: NICK CROZIER -- 40s, star offensive coordinator, in his first year here, handsome, a comer -- studies the game below through instant computer printouts. In the booth are several offensive and defensive assistants.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: «+. they been giving Sanderson the inside. If we roll Cap left, Les and Madman can handle the backside.

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: (into headset) I'd say 75-25. But let's try -- slot right switch and if they bring the bandit, we check to 99 max... (relays call) Okay! Slot Right Switch 90 or 99 Cadillac.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: TYLER CHERUBINI, the stoic, 32-year-old perpetual back-up quarterback relays the telex signal from upstairs, on his headset to the field via walkie-talkie -- in addition to various body signals, both legitimate and deceptive.

dialogues.speaker: HUDDLE
dialogues.text: QB Cap Rooney bangs on his helmet; something in the electronics is off. He glares at his teammates, and though at times he chews them out like a Marine sergeant, there is an unmistakable affection for his line. He tries his hardest, like an aging Boy Scout, not to curse, not always successfully.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Damn headset! Never goddamn works when you get hit!! Every damn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: time! Damnit, Madman! That sonofabitch is headhunting! (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hold him, rip out his goddamn eyes, but don't let him mess with me! I'm too goddamn old! PATRICK KELLY, his massive right tackle, known around the league as "MADMAN," bleeds from his nose, but adores his QB.

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: Cap, I'll keep him off ya even if I gotta bite off his thumb!

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: You do that! (to SANDERSON, the star wide receiver) «+. Get yourself open, goddamnit, ‘Sandman.' If you gotta coldcock him, I'll find you.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: Hey I'm there, Cap! In the wind. Just fling it, baby!

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: (to the second wide receiver) ‘Zonker'! You're number two, get open, run your dig route at 15... (to the huddle) Okay, listen up, Slot Right Switch 90 or 99 Cadillac, check with me, and kill any sonofabitch tries to cross that line before his time! On three. Ready! They clap and break. With 15 seconds to play time, the constant barrage of "voices" inside Cap's helmet ceases.

dialogues.speaker: MEDIA BOOTH
dialogues.text: TUG KOLOWSKI -- in the flesh -- is a boisterous, boozy, veteran sportscaster, alongside KEVIN BRANSON, a young an upcoming TV-type who seems Tug's opposite, bland and safe

dialogues.speaker: TUG
dialogues.text: ... But not all is paradise here in Miami. Cap Rooney may be on his way into the record books, but for Coach Tony D'Amato it's been a dismal season with attendance sliding, as the crosstown Dolphins prosper...

dialogues.speaker: WITH
dialogues.text: 13 Al3

dialogues.speaker: STANDS
dialogues.text: Reveals the stadium at two-thirds capacity. SIDELINE #5 (VIDEO AND FILM) Al3 Tony, on TV display, talking intensely into his headset, takes us past defensive coordinator MONTEZUMA MONROE -- 60s, a monument of a man, former star linebacker, now limping noticeably. He glares strongly, rarely moves. With him is 34-year-old vet LUTHER LAVAY, linebacker and the captain of the defense, black, built, and a total predator. His nickname: "SHARK."

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... With three straight losses and a slide from four years ago when they won two Pantheon Cups in a row, D'Amato's going to have to struggle to get his aging team into the playoffs! But today is looking good for the Sharks, leading the Americans in the second quarter, 21-17.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: «+. They still got those holes in that offensive line, Tug, but the biggest problem has got to be the defense, and Montezuma Monroe knows it... An ASSISTANT offers Monroe a set of digitally-produced enhancements of the Minnesota offensive formations.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Get that shit outta my face! Shark -- what the fuck's goin' on out there?! We gotta get more pressure on the goddamn quarterback! That motherfucker's splitting our seam 15 yards every goddamn time. Now fix it!

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: I'm on it, Coach. He stomps toward the defensive unit.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... there's also of course the impact of management decisions on the Sharks' turn in fortunes...  14 15

dialogues.speaker: OWNER'S BOX
dialogues.text: As seen on TV, several family friends and VPs mill around, but we only see the back of elegantly-attired blonde President and co-owner, CHRISTINA PAGNIACCI.

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No question, Kev! Since the death of ‘Big Daddy,' Art Pagniacci -- his daughter and new President of the team, Christina Pagniacci has made some -- many people think -- questionable financial decisions in letting three All-Pro Bowl selections leave town for free agency.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ++. although she did bring Julian Washington in from K.C. A big 1500-yard back...

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: JULIAN WASHINGTON, 27, an extremely strong, sexy, solidly-built, 230-pound running back, sets, his teeth blazing with jewelry and facial paint on the far edges of the Association's rule book (The Associated Football Franchise of America). He presently goes into play- motion.

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: «+. who can be great when he's not hurt. And his heart's in it. And here we go! Rooney barks out the numbers, "hot reading" the coming blitz. The clock slows, as his eyes flick from the key safety to his own team. Can they handle the confusion of the audible?

dialogues.speaker: ROONEY
dialogues.text: (audibling) Set! Blue 83... check, check... Arizona 99 Cadillac, Arizona 99 Cadillac! Hut! Hut! Hut! The Shark linemen read the shift... but Madman is clearly confused... blocking assignments are missed. Cap takes the snap and fades back to pass, but he's an inch too slow and a year too old -- his arm in the air, about to release, he is brutally blind-sided by a fast reptilian defensive end. Simultaneously, a blitzing safety hits him in the lower back with his helmet. Cap goes down hard again, landing on his own blocker's helmet at an awkward angle -- he screams loudly -- and this time, nothing moves.  16 17 18 19

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Tony is looking at his worst fear come true. An eerie quiet momentarily pervades the stadium. D'Amato breaks it, yelling at Dr. Powers.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Get the hell out there! Move! Can't you see he's hurt?

dialogues.speaker: WIVES' SECTION
dialogues.text: Cindy Rooney shares the uncertainty.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER'S BOX
dialogues.text: Still standing with her back to the window, Christina talks to a friend.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: --. well, until I'm on the finance committee, I have zero say on network negot... As she becomes aware of the hush in the stadium, she turns to look -- then up at the TV for the slo-mo replay.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... Every Shark fan has a sickening feeling in the pit of their stomach at this moment. I know I do. Cap Rooney is down and in obvious pain.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Dammit! Who was on the weakside safety?! Was that McKenna, you f -- ? She reaches for a red phone.

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Man oh man! Did you see that collision?! His body went in five different directions!

dialogues.speaker: TV MONITOR 19
dialogues.text: shows the injury in slo-mo. Xs are drawn over Cap's knees by Tug's finger on the telestrator. A big O goes over Cap's back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ouch! I've been there and that is a world of pain!

dialogues.speaker: MEDIA BOOTH
dialogues.text: Branson covers his microphone and hisses at both a technician and Tug:

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Stop showing that for Christ's sake!... (on camera) We'll be right back with Cap's condition after this word from our sponsors.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: 19 20 21 Drs. Mandrake and Powers, and Trainer #1 attend to Cap as he rolls back and forth, in intense pain.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: Suck it up, Cap...

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: My back!

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: (feeling for the injury) Straighten your legs. Wiggle your toes. Alright, Cap, they cut to the commercial. You can get up now.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: (through clenched teeth) I must've broke my back!!

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Come on, babe, you're still moving your feet. There's no way you broke your back!

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Where does it hurt?

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: (screaming) Right where you're touching, you...!! I swear... I can't breathe... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Neither can I -- it's the humidity. Do I gotta get you a stretcher now? You that old?

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: (shakes it off, pulls up) Dammit! I'm walkin' outta here!... (vising) Oww -- my butt! It's like a knife in it! The stadium applauds as Cap hobbles up to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Back-up QB Tyler Cherubini nervously jams index cards wit play calls under the clear plastic holders inside his special wristband, intersecting Coach D'Amato.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Nice and easy, Ty, okay. We're up 21-17. Hold on. Steady ‘em. Cherubini AD LIBS and jogs onto the field. Fans stomp their feet in sync with the driving beat of the inspirational "Shark Theme."

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We're back! And Cap Rooney looks to be all right. Listen to that crowd! Cap crosses towards the bench on the shoulders of Powers and Trainer #1. Tony intersects briefly, but he doesn't seem to want to confront this, makes light of it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You all right, '‘Rock'? His sometime nickname for Cap.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: (winces ) Yeah! Hurts like a...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Way to hold on to that football, kid! Take it easy, we'll finish this up without you -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Back-up quarterback Tyler Cherubini hasn't seen a lot of action recently!

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: From the BOOTH POV -- the team claps and breaks from the huddle.

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hate to tell you, Kev, it's a little scarier than that. Tyler Cherubini hasn't thrown for a first down all season!... but it's going to take a nail and a coffin to keep Cap down on the farm warming the pine. This may only be a game but to Cap Rooney it's the only game in town.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Tyler Cherubini scans the defense, sees all the signs for another impending blitz.

dialogues.speaker: CHERUBINI
dialogues.text: (long count) Set! Red 14 Ace, Red 14 Ace! Check, check! Black 90 Razor, Black 90 Razor! -- Hut! Hut! Minnesota attacks with everything they've got... Cherubini never even sees the light of day as he is buried, coughing up the ball -- which bounces into the hands of a surprised Minnesota safety -- who sprints 20-some yards into the Miami end zone for a touchdown! The fans go wild with rage, booing the fallen Cherubini.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh my gosh! Touchdown! And the Americans go up 23-21. Man-o-man! Did they nail him! He's... Cherubini's not getting up! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Two quarterbacks down, one after the other. This is crazy! I think they just lost Cherubini, too! My God! I haven't seen this since... the Aztecs and Pharaohs in '88 -- or was it '78?

dialogues.speaker: OWNER'S BOX
dialogues.text: Christina watches the fiasco with her husband, ANDY MATTER, a young handsome lawyer, and two VPs of the team -- JOHNNY POLITO, in his 50s, and ED PHILLIPS, in his 60s -- a distinguished man with a comforting aura, the family advisor from her father's era.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (into the red phone) Oh, Jesus! Vincent, get me the names of who's available out there in the quarterback market right away, would you?... and how ‘bout every available line coach -- Maybe somebody who can actually teach this line how to block!! A young woman raised to appreciate football, her outburst quiets the dozen people partying in the box. Her mother, MARGARET PAGNIACCI, an elegant older woman, who looks out of it, mostly quasi-drunk or drugged, though she does a superb job of concealing this with her fixed and dignified expression, inquires:

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: What is it, honey...?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (ignores her) «+. find out about Malloy. Why'd Denver cut him? Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: WILLIE BEAMEN, third-string QB, 26, black, sits on the bench, as accustomed, not expecting to be called on.

dialogues.speaker: QB COACH
dialogues.text: Beamen! What the hell are you doing? I told you to warm up five minutes ago! Look at your wristband -- it's upside down. Take your head out of your ass. Let's go, you're up!  13.

dialogues.speaker: A27 TUNNEL
dialogues.text: Drs. Mandrake and Powers enter the locker room tunnel with Cap Rooney when TRAINER #2 yells after them:

dialogues.speaker: TRAINER
dialogues.text: Doc! They need you back! Cherubini's down!

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Cherubini! What -- he fall off a bench? What the hell's next?! Stigmata! (to Powers, re: Rooney) -.. Just sit him out and don't touch him till I...

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: The Americans kick off.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: As the kick returner downs it in the end zone, D'Amato huddles with Willie Beamen, who is adjusting the speaker sound in his helmet.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Beamen, it's you now. Left Deuce Zig 22 Tomcat. Easy hand-off to Julian, okay?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (on helmet) Willie, can you hear me? You're gonna be all right. The Americans got no profile on you. Use it... surprise ‘em. Willie looks for Crozier upstairs in one of those anonymous boxes, lost in the roar of sound and the sea of faces. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (difficulty hearing) ++. do what?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You're gonna do fine. Look at me, son. You're gonna do fine... (tapping over Willie's heart) You hold it all inside. Stay there. Stay focused.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Right... Tony slaps Willie on the shoulder and sends him out.

dialogues.speaker: MEDIA BOOTH
dialogues.text: TECHNICIANS and assistants frantically adjust as Tug and Kevin rifle through papers during the commercial break.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Get me more stats on Willie Beamen now!

dialogues.speaker: TUG
dialogues.text: Cap's out... Man, I can't believe this...

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: You know anything about Willie Beamen?

dialogues.speaker: TUG
dialogues.text: Who the hell's Willie Beamen?

dialogues.speaker: TECHNICIAN
dialogues.text: We're back in five, guys! 32 Willie is ignored in the huddle, hesitant -- he tries to shut out the stadium noise.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: As we wait for word on Cap Rooney's condition, Miami's sending in third-string quarterback Willie Beamen. Willie is 26 years old. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A 'mystery man,'seventh-round draft pick out of Dallas, he went to the University of Houston. In his fifth year, his first year with the Sharks, he's seen four teams in his professional career... Willie tries to hear the QB Coach's voice in his helmet.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (helmet) Left Deuce Zig 22 Tomcat. Watch the mike backer, he'll probably be coming. Relax and show me you got it! Willie turns and waves to the sideline.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (helmet) No... tell them!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Awright, guys! Come on listen up!... the call is Left Deuce Zig 22 Tomcat. McKENNA (to the rest) HEY! SHUT THE FUCK UP! On?

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: (during this) .-. D'Amato's gotta be losing his mind -- a 14-point turnaround, lost his starter, his back-up, and maybe the game in two plays! What a disaster! It's an absolute...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: On?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: (intense)

dialogues.speaker: SNAP COUNT
dialogues.text: Willie is trying to suppress dry heaves.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: You all right? Holy...!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Augghh... Ugghh... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Willie suddenly rips off his helmet and vomits.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: (leaping back) Oh, shit -- !

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Shark Lavay, the middle linebacker, is standing next to Monroe.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: Did he puke?! Did he just puke on the sacred turf?!

dialogues.speaker: MEDIA BOOTH
dialogues.text: Tug is laughing heartily.

dialogues.speaker: TUG
dialogues.text: (to Branson) Oh, man! Hey, Kev' -- shades of you the night we went out after the Cleveland game. Kevin shoots him a look, and rifles through some papers.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: ... Beamen even played cornerback for a while when he was at San Diego, where he was injured in his third year...

dialogues.speaker: OWNER'S BOX
dialogues.text: Christina is now on a black field phone:

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Soon as you know, you call! If this is serious, Harvey, I need to know yesterday, you understand what I'm saying?!

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: (to Beamen) Fuck, man! I've got to get into a three-point stance in your puke?! Get it together, nigra... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: (cleaning his shoes) You puked on the logo, my man!

dialogues.speaker: REFEREE
dialogues.text: (intersecting) Come on, son, let's play ball!

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (helmet) Would you run the play already!

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: As they move towards the ball, Willie glances in several directions -- it's terrifying -- the Minnesota defense is shifting position, confusing him; the crowd is deafening, the cameras zooming in, the sun blazing.

dialogues.speaker: MINNESOTA TACKLE
dialogues.text: (greeting Willie) Better get ready, motherfucker! I'm coming and I'm gonna be picking peanuts out of your ass!

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: Come to Mama first, loudmouth!

dialogues.speaker: MINNESOTA TACKLE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah! Through you, ‘round you, upside down you, you useless mother...! Willie intensely scans the defensive alignment. All talk ceases when he yells:

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Set Red 378! Red 378! Hut! Hut! Willie steps back a little too fast and too far. He spins towards Washington, awkwardly handing the ball off on a delayed slant... Washington shoots into a different hole than assigned -- a dangerous runner, gaining ten yards from nothing. In the backfield, the taunting defensive end slaps Willie's helmet hard as the whistle blows. Willie barely has time to breathe before he hears "the voice of God" in his helmet speaker:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (in helmet) Thunder Left Smoke 90 Sally.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: in motion, of the speed and confusion of the game as giant defensive linemen close on him. He sees a brief opening onto Sanderson 15 yards downfield -- throws far too high -- almost intercepted by the safety.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Tony, concerned, beckons to his tight end, talks to him and sends him out onto the field. Tony continues to yell something into his headset at Crozier.

dialogues.speaker: HUDDLE
dialogues.text: The tight end yells something lost in the crowd. Willie has to look up the play on his arm band.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Awright, Deuce Right Split 24 Barrel Clear. On one.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I'll be coming in fast on your left, boy -- don't make me wait!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: On one!

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: At the line, Miami players immediately sense the defense is stacked up to the right for Washington's run.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: (urgently, under) Audible, man -- change the play -- Willie realizes it too -- audibles too quickly and too softly to communicate accurately.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Set! Green 41 -- um -- switch, switch... Red 70 Blackstar, Red 70 Blackstar --- Hut! The snap -- Miami is hopelessly confused. There is no such play as "Red 70 Blackstar" and players run this way and that. After several athletic moves, Willie is bounced out of bounds, eight yards behind the line of scrimmage.  41 42 43

dialogues.speaker: A43
dialogues.text: 44 19. SIDELINE #13 4l Tony is having a really bad day, about to throw his mangled headset away again.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (to Crozier and QB coach) What the hell was that?! What's he doing out there? Does he know any of these plays?

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Tony, he knows the basic package but he's only taken a few snaps.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Washington yells at Willie on the way back to the huddle:

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: What the fuck is Red 70 Blackstar, homes There is no such fucking play

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (coolly) I just figgered that out, J Man... (his nickname) but there oughta be...

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Tony has one more chance at a field goal at the Minnesota 45-yard line.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Come on! Hurry it up! Let's go... let's go!

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Willie eyes the defense as he sets, but mistakenly lines up over right guard Leslie McKenna instead of his center... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McKENNA ‘Less you tell me you love me, sugah, get your hands outta my ass! The defense picks up on it instantly and goes after Willie loudly. Embarrassed, he makes his adjustment -- but too late. A flag flies. Delay of game penalty.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Tony throws up his hands and rolls his eyes. There goes the field goal!

dialogues.speaker: PRESS BOX
dialogues.text: a sportswriter with his own local TV show, makes an acid comment on this bone-headed move to a colleague as he works his laptop. Coming off Beamen's throwing up, the press knows it has a story!

dialogues.speaker: OWNER'S BOX
dialogues.text: Christina leans forward to watch. Willie fades back to pass.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: The rush is on again. Willie, scrambling out of the pocket, avoids several tacklers, but his eyes give away the 25-yard pass... The defensive back steals it from Sanderson and runs it back 10 yards. The crowd roars with disappointment. Referee #1 whistles -- ending the half.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Coach D'Amato shakes his head, picked up by the TV cameras.

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That was bound to happen, the way this kid's movin'. Too fast, just too fast. He's gotta be nervous out there! He's ahead of his receivers... Thank God that ends the first half with the sun going down on this delayed and chock-full-of- surprises game...  49 50 21.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: With 10 minutes to go, the offense is concentrated in one part of the room on chairs, the defense in the other -- listening to analyses and looking at video pictures from their respective coaches.

dialogues.speaker: TRAINER'S AREA
dialogues.text: Madman's got the flu, and is dehydrated enough to require two I.V.s in either arm. Dr. Powers reads his thermometer.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: 101... You light-headed?

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: I was light-headed at kick-off, Doc. Now I'm at the ‘one foot in the coffin' stage.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: You're a couple of quarts low, Madman, you just need an oil change...

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, then why are my legs one big knot, Doc!? I need some cyclobenzaprine... Powers sees Dr. Mandrake hurry past, follows him.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Harvey, just a sec...! Mandrake barely breaks, waits.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: I'm worried about Cap -- he's losing ankle strength. I think he's got...

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: (surprised) What'd you do? Examine him? Look, Allie, you're actually one of the few relatives I can stomach, but you're the internist. I'm the orthopedist, remember? You leave my people alone...

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: I just think that... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Need a job description review? Bone, muscle, joint -- me. Runny nose, diarrhea, pink eye, gonorrhea -- you. Sports injuries me; anything that drips, sticks, or stinks, or stinks, you. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE 51
dialogues.text: heads toward a small exam room where Cap waits alone -- bypassing Cherubini, the forgotten QB, waiting to have his knee examined, attended to by TRAINER #2, a stutterer.

dialogues.speaker: TRAINER
dialogues.text: Doc, what about Rhodes? He's really in p-p-pain...

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: He's a hypochondriac. Give him some ibuprofen.

dialogues.speaker: TRAINER
dialogues.text: He doesn't wanna put that sh-shit in his body. He wants Demerol.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: You think I want to be banished to Siberia as an ice hockey doctor? Tell him to clench his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: CHERUBINI
dialogues.text: Doc, what about my knee?

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: TRAINER
dialogues.text: Well, I think m-m-maybe I can get him to t-t-take some Alka-Seltzer.

dialogues.speaker: EXAM AREA
dialogues.text: Mandrake closes the door on Trainer #2. Cap is with Trainer #1. He puts Cap's x-ray up on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Bad news, Cap, you're okay, it's just a bruise. No ribs broken. Back's normal. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: ++. something's definitely wrong, Doc! My butt's killing me... I think it's a...

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: «+. I'll send you over for an M.R.I. in case. (to Trainer #1) Lou, prep me 20 C.C. two percent lido with marcaine...

dialogues.speaker: TRAINER'S AREA
dialogues.text: Powers attends to Madman, who suddenly has an urgent look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (yelling out) Three minutes!

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: Doc! Pull the pipes! I gotta go!

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Can you...

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: I mean... I gotta go! Call of the wild, man! He goes, IVs trailing, Powers calls out to Trainer #1 for help.

dialogues.speaker: LOCKER ROOM
dialogues.text: With shouts of "Get out of the way!", "Coming through!", Powers and Trainer #2, protecting the I.V.'s, follow a surging Madman into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: BEAST MAN
dialogues.text: (as they go past) Whoo-hoo! Shark football! Whatever it takes!!! Other players chorus in, hooting and hollering, till the coaches shut them up.

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM
dialogues.text: The stalls are filled. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: (yelling) Hey, shitheads! It's me -- Madman! Who's on my toilet?! Madman kicks open a broken stall and finds an unlucky rookie staring back at him.

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: Rookie, this is reserved! Get the fuck out! Terrified, the rookie runs out; then Madman forces his way in, managing to squeeze Powers, Trainer #2 and himself into the stall.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Don't bend your elbows... Crozier, studying a stack of computer printouts, enters.

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: Madman? Yo! You there...? He whacks on the door, which opens on Madman sitting with his pants around his ankles, I.V.s entering each outstretched arm, ministered to by Trainer #1 and Dr. Powers. Crozier is amused but hardly surprised; to Madman:

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: The three technique is really getting up field on you. We're gonna rub him with a fullback this half.

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: Coach, let's run the draw or let me cut his ass on the screens. That'11 slow the motherfucker down. And show them what I truly am! A genius!

dialogues.speaker: LOCKER ROOM
dialogues.text: The players are gathered around Coach D'Amato, who now addresses both offense and defense. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Look, you the offense, why do you think we work on the blitz package all week? We've lost two quarterbacks in one half of football ‘cause our line can't pick up a goddamn backside bandit on max protection!! You and I know this is goddamn stupid football, and you're stressing this shit outta me! We've worked on the calls over and over again but you have no goddamn focus or concentration! McKenna, keep your head on a swivel, you've got to slide out there and pick up that robber -- roll up those outside linebackers! Beamen, know your site adjustments! Sanderson and Fox will break off their routes but you have to deliver it on time. We've had two goddamn turnovers this half, you guys are dumping on my turnover ratio. You the defense, you've got to create something out there, you've got to start flying around the fucking ball and hitting somebody. Don't let these assholes chew up the clock on us! On first down, they're killing us with the weakside slant. Corners, when we put eight in the box, you've got to jam the receivers, take ‘em on, you're hesitating! If you're gonna make a mistake, go on! Make it a big one! I'm not gonna eat your lunch for that, but don't fuck around like pussies at a pee party, you hear me?!... P.J., Mac, Beast Man, Horny, Shark! One, two yards less each time and they'll be two and eight instead of two and six! Stuff the goddamn run. They're killing us! No more stupid penalties, okay?! Concentrate. Focus. We're only down by three points. We can win this mother! I'm sick and tired of losing! Are you?! Three losses in a row. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you guys sick and tired of this?! Stand up if you're not! Raise your hand! Raise your hand if you're a pussy! Stand up, let's go! The team is poised, clenching up, except for Washington who rises laconically.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What the hell you doing, J?!

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I didn't want you to be the only one standing, Coach. A tense moment -- then all bust up laughing, including D'Amato.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, this is our house! We live here. Don't let them fuck with us in our own house! We're gonna get some points on the goddamn board if I gotta get out there myself and throw the goddamn ball! Now let's go and kick some second-half butt!

dialogues.speaker: SHARKS
dialogues.text: (as team) Football, ahhhh!!! WHATEVER IT

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM
dialogues.text: As the team roars out of the locker room, Madman is eager to rejoin his crew.

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: Doc, I gotta go!

dialogues.speaker: POWER
dialogues.text: No! Stop! Your I.V.s! Don't bend your elbows!

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: (a sweet baby look) Doc?... Do you mind? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Powers understands that if he can't bend his elbows that he... he sighs and wraps a stretch of tissue paper around his hand -- as Mandrake pokes his head in the stall, enjoying the view of Powers wiping Madman's ass.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Say, Allie, you want to get a little Chinese food later and talk about this...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winter's night has now fallen as the team hollers, exiting a narrow tunnel onto the field. The stadium is charming but decayed (1930s WPA architecture) and in need of significant renovation... Jimmy Sanderson, the young star wide receiver for the Sharks, repeatedly adjusts his shoulder pads, talking to himself as he walks; he is all hands and nerves, a thoroughbred with a sweet personality.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: I am precision-honed, muscular- tempered steel. My moves are cosmic. Time to save the day. My legs, torso and arms are energized powerthrust dominant weapons... I can save the day!

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: (bypassing Willie) Who's that you're throwing to, kid? The receiver or you got some other shit on your mind? Willie gets the message. Several fans, intoxicated, hurl profanities, peanuts, beer, seat cushions at the Sharks. One OBESE FAN in particular:

dialogues.speaker: FAN
dialogues.text: You stink! Hey, Beamen! If you could chuck a football like you chuck vomit, you'd be an all-pro, ha ha ha! Willie ignores him, but when the Fan throws his beer at him, it empties on Madman, who is rushing out last, his IVs gone. Enraged, Madman roars and tries to go up into the stands after the unlucky Fan, but is restrained by teammates. AD LIBS... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: You think that's funny, asshole! I'm gonna eat your fucking lunch, buddy!! (etc.)

dialogues.speaker: SCOREBOARD
dialogues.text: THIRD QUARTER. MINNESOTA 31, MIAMI 21. 7:14 remaining. Minnesota has increased its lead by one touchdown.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Tony paces anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: The Miami defense tries to stop a long gainer by the Minnesota running back, propelling his 230 lbs. right at Shark Lavay, who upends the running back, one on one... Shark is the best open-field tackler on the Sharks, but as he takes those few extra beats rising, adjusting his shaken frame, congratulated by teammates, his expres- sion reveals the wearying price he pays -- at 34, going on 50 -- for this leadership role.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Powers now kneels next to the defensive end, Beast Man, coming off the field onto the bench with an agonizing, dislocated finger.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: (to Trainer #2) Lou, get him X-rayed before I set this!

dialogues.speaker: BEAST MAN
dialogues.text: (vehement ) How 'bout sometime next week, Doc! How long you been here! I don't give a fuck if I'm blind, deaf, and fuckin' dumb, get me back out on the motherfuckin' field... Powers hesitates as Mandrake passes by, sees the problem, and makes the adjustment without thinking. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: (to Powers) Oh for God's sake, Allie! It's just a... (to Beast Man) Beast Man, concentrate and think of pussy. POP! Beast Man's FINGER CRACKS back into place. Beastie hardly winces.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: (to Beast Man) You're still gonna need an X-ray after the game, Beast Man, okay? Beast Man mutters something venomous under his breath, and moves off.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Using his bare white foot, the smallish Eastern European Miami kicker drills a graceful 38-yard field goal through the uprights.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Everything moves fast in the big leagues. Too fast. Willie again too quickly breaks from the pocket, scrambling the offensive and defensive lines up and down the field, tiring them... Unable to find his receiver, he takes off running; makes it over the middle of the field for a first down plus another five or ten yards before he is pulped in two different directions.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Tony, hiding his eyes as if from a car accident, shakes his head, to Crozier on the headset.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: ... Kid's fast, but he ain't gonna last, Nick!

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He was an alright corner at San Diego till he got hurt. Watch the feet. Genius ankles, like Julian. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: He may be a ballerina, but where's the brain? He just called another play that doesn't exist! Goddamn! Settle him down, Nick!

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Willie drops back, and without any pressure, throws a perfect 10-yard interception over the middle into the arms of a Minnesota linebacker. The stadium turns really sour, booing Willie as he walks off.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... No word yet on Cap Rooney. The only thing we do know is, he's being X-rayed at the hospital, but right now I'd say it doesn't look good for the Sharks...

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Tony is waiting for Willie, like Ahab himself.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What the hell was that?! You just don't fling the goddamn ball downfield into traffic like...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: ++. Sorry, Coach, I thought it was man-free and he looked open.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: We called Go Z Read! What the hell are you doing changing the play when you feel like it, without even knowing who the hell you're...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: They was waitin' for the hitch, Coach. They was there. I had to go for it. I saw daylight!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (seething) Daylight? Shut the fuck up and listen to me! Listen to me now!... You're a new player on this team. You got me? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You are nobody to me or anybody else here till you prove yourself. And you start that by doing what you're fucking told! You got that?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I got that.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Now get out of my face and next time you're out there, control the goddamn ball! He stalks off. Willie, closed off by Tony's intensity, moves to the bench.

dialogues.speaker: ON TV B64
dialogues.text: Tony is saying some pretty rough things.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You read lips, Tug?

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hell yeah. That was a major at Nebraska.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER'S BOX
dialogues.text: The box has been thinned out of associates and friends, who've obviously sensed Christina's mood on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: I don't care if you have to chopper the guy in off his yacht, Harvey -- bring him out here right away! And get me the names of the top neurosurgeons in the country. I want the best!

dialogues.speaker: TV MONITOR A65
dialogues.text: Willie now fumbles a simple hand-off to Julian Washington... The fumble is recovered and Willie calls a time-out.  65 66 67 32.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA 65
dialogues.text: slams her hand down in frustration, sharing a 65 look with Ed Phillips. She is a strong, energetic executive in her late 20s, raised by her deceased father, founder Art Pagniacci, to be a son and gain the respect of a man's world, to the point of acquiring a "take no prisoners" attitude. She calls up to:

dialogues.speaker: COACH'S BOOTH
dialogues.text: Crozier is polite, though bothered by her interference.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Why?! Why is he calling these plays?... Nick? He's got to take a chance... Nick! Tell him!

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: I'm doing my best, Miss P. I can't just...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Make some noise.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Willie, coming off the field, moves towards D'Amato, expecting the worst. Instead D'Amato throws an arm around his shoulders and walks him along the sideline -- in a paternal tone:

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Okay, what's wrong, Willie? What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: It's moving fast, Coach... but I know I can do it. I can do it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Just take a breath now. Believe me when I say you can only get better, kid -- and you don't have to worry about getting the hook -- ‘cause I got no one left, okay? He grins.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I stink. I'm not myself. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Look at me. Look at me, son... You know how to play the game. You been playing it all your life, right?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You grew up in Dallas, right?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Okay, maybe you're back in Dallas right now. You're enjoying yourself. You're back in the ""hood," right before your mama calls you for dinner. Go to the Buick, turn around and I'll throw it to you, you throw it back. A game of catch, remember that?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: «+. somethin’ like that, yeah...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: My point is -- Willie -- just forget about the crowd and the formations and the audibles and the whole goddamn playbook. Just focus on this one next pass. (carefully) Willie -- go to the Buick and turn around. There's a special, soothing tone to the way D'Amato expresses himself, when he wants. A voice that makes you believe.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Willie walks up to the line. A fierce new concentration occupying him. ALL SOUND DRAINS AWAY. He is distracted by nothing! The crowd has become a semi-real phantasmagoric beast with a thousand eyes. On his own face there is an extraordinary, savage look -- primordial. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He barks out the signals, SILENT... Soundless, he backpedals, cocking his arm, fingers tight on the laces, fingernails digging in... his eyes like radar... the read... one receiver... two receiver... a quick, strong release... a fast, clean spiral -- yet it seems to sail for hours through the air. «+. Caught by Sanderson at the 20! The beginner's luck holds when the two Minnesota defensive backs collide into each other, falling down, and Sanderson runs freely into the end zone for a TD!... Now -- an EXPLOSION OF SOUND. The first TD of a career.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: D'Amato allows himself a small smile of pleasure -- a long time coming. The offense is cheering -- alongside Montezuma Monroe and his defense, who now pay the offense a little attention.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Players slam a stunned Willie on the back.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: .+. ‘less you wanna kick the extra point, you better get off the field, dawg!

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: The Shark mascot -- a guy dressed in a huge foam shark costume -- dances the "Shark dance"... As Madman trudges up to Dr. Powers with blood dripping from his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Madman?...

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: One of those cheap mothers fishhooked me in the mouth with his thumb... I tried to bite it off but he jammed my mouth guard up and ripped up my gum... Hurts like the lambs, man!

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Willie's eyes looking for D'Amato -- who acknowledges him from a distance. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sanderson disrupts the moment, in Willie's face, twitchin as he repeats himself over and over.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: (repeating) Hey, you git it, money! You gat the magic!

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Willie, playing with some real confidence, runs an option pass right, and completes a 17-yarder to the second receiver.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: This time Willie heads left, faking well off his right shoulder to keep the DBs deep, then takes off on an adventuresome run through the Americans. He's a natural- born athlete, but the Minnesota defense exhorts a price for making them look bad -- pounding him hard after a 13-yard gainer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the bottom of the pile, the linemen wrestle one anothe going for the eyes and nuts, anything for the edge (AD LIBS)... Close to Willie, at the bottom, Madman growls:

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: Boy, do we got a dental plan for you, buddy!... Payback time! We hear the crunch of his elbow and a painful grunt from the abused party, who presumably "fishhooked" him earlier.

dialogues.speaker: REFEREE
dialogues.text: Get out of there, guys! Come on! Knock it off! Climb out!

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: The shoeless wonder boots a 45-yard field goal dead center through the uprights -- a thing of beauty as the fans revive their hopes, starting to pick up on Willie Beamen.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Tony is just a little bit happy, finally, but can't show it.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER'S BOX
dialogues.text: So is Christina, turning to Johnny Polito.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Can you believe this? A third- string quarterback... Who found him, Johnny?

dialogues.speaker: POLITO
dialogues.text: I think Arnie spotted him before he left... This sticks in her craw -- she fired "Arnie."

dialogues.speaker: PRESS BOX
dialogues.text: Even in the cynical media, there is an appreciable shift of interest in the young quarterback.

dialogues.speaker: JACK ROSE
dialogues.text: (to colleague) Can you believe D'Amato's luck? He's looking at four losses in a row and his ass is saved by this nobody? What a story! Back to his laptop...

dialogues.speaker: OWNER'S BOX
dialogues.text: Christina seems more relaxed on the phone, discreetly to the side. The game is meandering toward conservatism, close to won, and friends have slipped back in. AD LIB chatter, food, drinks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: ..-. Van Ness?! Dominic, he's a hundred years old, for God's sake! Find me a quarterback who's under fifty, who's solid, been around and can get us to the playoffs... (pause) No, it looks like some surgery on his lower back, an L-5 I think, but there's a chance he can get back by the playoffs...

dialogues.speaker: ON TV 80
dialogues.text: Miami's offense is on the field at their own 29, 2nd and 8. The score reads: MINNESOTA 31, MIAMI 34, FOURTH QUARTER, 1:54 left. It looks good.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Yet Tony prowls nervously... Trainer #2 adjusts the air in ICE HAWKINS' (tight end) helmet, who complains to Powers about the large black and blue bite on his neck.

dialogues.speaker: ICE
dialogues.text: -+. Goddamn motherfucker bit me on the neck!

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: (examines it) +. You're lucky, he doesn't have AIDS, Ice. (grins) Get me a Band-Aid and some hydrogen peroxide, it'll be gone in a week or so.

dialogues.speaker: ICE
dialogues.text: My old lady ain't gonna believe that shit! She gonna think some hoe jumped on my dick.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: I'll give you a note.

dialogues.speaker: ICE
dialogues.text: She don't believe nothing she reads anyhow.  82 83 84

dialogues.speaker: COACH'S BOOTH
dialogues.text: Crozier is a little nervous.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Deuce Left 22 Red Beast Read.

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: Come on, Tony, they're giving us the flat. Let's run smoke and...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Maybe they're looking for the pick. I'm not taking chances. Not with this ballerina.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: A bulldozing straight-ahead three-yard run by Washington. Third down and five.

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: (insistent) I know Willie, Tony! They're screaming for him to dump it out there!... It's wide open!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: That's just it. I know this coach, Nick! And he's a prick. It's a set-up. Run it again. Deuce Left 22 Red Beast Read.

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: Tony, they're stacked up for the run --

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You heard me. Crozier relays the call.

dialogues.speaker: HUDDLE
dialogues.text: Willie hears "the voice," doesn't like the call either. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Okay, same, same, Deuce Left 22 Red Beast Read. On two.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Money time, boys. Get me five and we are home and dry and flyin' high.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: Let the D win it, J-man, we don't need no first down. Punt gets us out of here.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: That's how come you don't score with the ladies, 'Two Race,' you got no showmanship.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Cut the bullshit! Red Beast Read. On two -- Ready!

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: (to Willie) I'll be flyin' my F-16, dawg, don't fuck me up! The team breaks, Washington with a particular strut about him, tasting victory already.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Tony sees the Minnesota defense stacked against the run right.

dialogues.speaker: COACH'S BOOTH
dialogues.text: Crozier sees the same thing. Especially from this height, the defensive adjustments are clear.

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: .+. Tony, take a time-out... come on! (as Tony's VOICE

dialogues.speaker: BREAKS UP
dialogues.text: momentarily; under his breath, to Willie) Audible left, kid! Just do it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Time-outs are for TV. Negative!  88 89 90 91 Ag1 40.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Willie hands off to Washington, who powers into the line, seeing nothing -- his eyes wild like a horse around fire -- He rolls along the line searching for the hole -- thinks he sees one -- goes for it. Swack! He is blindsided by the tall, reptilian defensive end, who hatchets him from high, then drives his helmet into the ball, which pops out high and loose and crazy. It is a spectacular fumble -- the kind of fumble all running backs have nightmares about -- Washington desperately dives back for it -- but everyone else is diving too, including Willie. A swift Minnesota safety makes the snag -- racing past confused Miami players -- some 24 yards, into the end zone. Touchdown.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh my God! Oh no!

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Oh yes! Your worst nightmare as a running back!

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Washington was looking for that first down. Big mistake! Willie is on his knees, unbelieving... Washington drops his head, the loneliest man in the world. A gash of blood crawls down inside his helmet from his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Tony is not so much stunned as resigned, believing now that nothing can change his luck.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER'S BOX
dialogues.text: Christina and everyone else in the box mutter quietly, in retreat...

dialogues.speaker: STANDS
dialogues.text: The fans turn ugly, throwing things onto the field.

dialogues.speaker: SCOREBOARD
dialogues.text: flashes the new score: MINNESOTA 37, MIAMI 34, 1:32...  92

dialogues.speaker: MINNESOTA SIDELINE
dialogues.text: The Americans are ecstatic.

dialogues.speaker: MIAMI SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Whereas Miami is devastated! Their very life-force threatened by this fourth straight defeat... the gods have voted. Despair and self-pity commingle.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER'S BOX
dialogues.text: Christina watches the replay of Washington going through the line.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Two hands, you showboat! Two goddamn hands -- you...

dialogues.speaker: WITH
dialogues.text: ON TV c92 The fumble as highlight... Utilizing her cane, Margaret Pagniacci leaves the room with her small, doting entourage and two white Schnauzer dogs, absorbing her daughter's passion with a detached amusement.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Oh, it's not so bad, honey. You'll wake up in the morning. We once lost a game -- two seconds to go on one of those stupid ‘Hail Mary' passes. My lord, it just stayed up there forever and this tall Negro gentleman jumped up so high like a basketball player and picked it right out of the air... I thought your daddy was gonna have a heart attack. He was so upset, you have no idea! (laughing) You know, he just lost years of his life here... (kissing Christina on the cheek) He died because of this. Don't take it all too seriously, darling, it's just a game...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (really pissed) Good night, Mother. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: c92 95 42. CONTINUED: c92 She turns to her husband, Andy, who is accompanying her mother home, and kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Make sure she gets home all right, would you, Andy? No stops. «+. makes a drinking motion.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: (nods ) How ‘bout me? Shall I wait up? I have plenty of homework.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Nah, don't bother. I'd be ina lousy mood anyway...

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: (squeezes her hand) I'm sorry... Don't forget I'm in Boston tomorrow for two days.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (having forgotten) Oh!?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Maybe three. Complicated deposition -- insurance company. I'1l call you.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (sadly, as he leaves) Kick their asses!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'Amato walks through like an undertaker.

dialogues.speaker: D'AMATO
dialogues.text: (yelling) All right, everybody, let's huddle! As the men slowly assemble in various stages of dress, pre and post-shower, some totally nude, D'Amato crosses to Willie's locker, who seems off in his own world, undressing slowly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: D'AMATO
dialogues.text: Let it go, Willie. You played strong.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I can't believe we blew it. I shoulda kept the ball myself.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Listen to me, kid... (waits till Willie gives him his eyes) On any given Sunday you're gonna win or you're gonna lose. The point is -- can you win or lose like a man? Out there today you played like a man. That's what counts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard for Willie to accept a compliment of any kind.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I'm sick of losing, Coach. Tony doesn't quite understand the motivation there; the rest of the team is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: When you're my age, kid, you get used to it. (to all) Awright, everybody, lissen up! You played your hearts out! No blame... nobody! Let's get on our knees... Father... The team assumes a collective prayer position; Tony signals the team CHAPLAIN.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPLAIN
dialogues.text: Tough one today. I know how you're taking this. I went to my play book and the book says: The rain falls on the just and the unjust alike. You're not specifically cursed. Joy comes in the morning. There are no atheists in foxholes. Let's pray. Our Father who art in Heaven...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a cell phone, Dr. Mandrake stitches an uneven, buckled suture onto Julian Washington's forehead -- who yelps out in pain. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: I was using a seven iron...

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Ow! How ‘bout another number, Doc! This hurts.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: (veaching for the novocaine) Doctor Caine on the way, you pussy! No you, I was talking... Powers, in the b.g., observes Washington's budding scar, concerned, says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: TRAINER
dialogues.text: (to Mandrake) Doc, ‘Horny’ won't shut up. Can we get him some...

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: (irritated) You tell 'Horny' his perk days are over! He knows Association policy -- it's a ‘schedule 5' drug. Give him two Motrin and tell him to go toa ‘witch doctor’... (as "Horny" suddenly makes an appearance on his behalf) You know you're gonna sue me anyway for the Motrin, you skinny fuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HORNY, a white, runty defensive back and punter, is rather upset at the large flap of skin hanging from his foot, which he proudly displays.

dialogues.speaker: HORNY
dialogues.text: Look at my fucking foot! Come on, Doc! Would you want to go on a double date with ‘Tank Top' looking like this?

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: (seeing the wound) Get that out of here.

dialogues.speaker: HORNY
dialogues.text: How do I get some attention round here? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: (rolls his eyes) Try suicide. (rushing to leave; to Powers) I gotta get down to Cap at the hospital. They did the M.R.I., looks like the disc ruptured. They're going in tonight. Could you finish Julian for me?... Knowing what he's left behind, Mandrake rushes out with the phone; Powers sidles up to Julian's suture.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Hey, J, I'm not gonna shit you. I know this guy, he's a top plastic surgeon... I think I can get him to see you tonight.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: What the fuck for?!

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: (how to say this?) You got a TV contract, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: You know I got a fucking television contract.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: -+. It is on-camera?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: (suddenly looking for a mirror) M'fucker... I'll sew his asshole to his lips!

dialogues.speaker: COACHES' OFFICE
dialogues.text: In progress, a dozen or more press -- among them Jack Rose -- are gathered around Tony, in a lousy mood, giving out his postgame interviews from his cramped office.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (pseudo-amicable) «+. So, Coach, what's on your mind when you run the exact same running play twice deep in your own territory? You nervous about your quarterback's arm? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You know, Jack, I've always loved the running game, but I read so much about it ‘cause of you, I decided I'm gonna give it up.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon. The running game?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No, reading you. (as they all laugh at Jack) The pass is great, but it's 2-3 guys involved. But a sweep -- y'ever really study a sweep, Jack --

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Student of the game, Coach.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Eleven men pulling together, concentrating... like a mind machine in perfect sync, hitting every block and hole, it's so damn beautiful! Football, Jack, at its purest.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Does that mean you're in disagreement with management, Coach?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (looks at his watch) No, it means I'm late to see Management. Tell you what, if I don't have the job tomorrow, you'll be the first one to know, Jack, okay? He leaves abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: P.R. GUY
dialogues.text: All right, folks, that's it for today... Grumbles all around...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The quiet of the empty stadium fills the humid air. Distant ECHOES of the roaring fans fall off into BIRDSONG and FROG CROAKS out of the swamps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coach D'Amato enters to find Cap Rooney in bed, his lower back and legs supported, a morphine drip in one arm and an IV in the other, unnaturally white and swollen from the hits -- doing his stoic best to abide the searing pain in his back. Flowers fill the crevices of the room. He's on a speaker phone with the boss, Christina -- while Cindy, his concerned and devoted wife, acknowledges Tony with a head nod.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: (to Christina) «+. but did you see the wires? I mean, why is this being played up like it's the end, Christina? I just don't understand -- it's a minor injury. That's all. Can't the front office control the spin?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Cindy, look, stop worrying about this! The important thing is this thing, this... microdisectomy, went well, it's under control. We'll make a strong statement in the morning, okay?... Cap? (as Cap acknowledges) I've been researching vertebrae. And guess what? -- There's a great doctor in Minnesota. Rosen. A specialist in rehab. I'm gonna fly him out tomorrow. I found out two important things... Cap?

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: (mutters ) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: One -- you can live without the L-5 disc, and two...

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: That's good news... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tony quietly tucks in Cap's sweaty, strewn bed sheets, preferring not to signal his presence to Christina. He notices a large black and blue discoloration around the point of surgical entry in Cap's lower back.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .+. And two, it all depends on you. We got the bye week. You could be ready as early as San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: That's really good news. Tony gives Cap some water.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I want you to rest up for tonight and we'll talk tomorrow, okay. Night, Cap... Cindy. She hangs up. Cindy disconnects the call.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: How ya doing, Rock?

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: (dopey) Man, I thought that guy's helmet would come out through my ass. I thought I was going to die! They went in -- took out my L-5 disc. No big deal ... Did we win? (as Tony shakes his head) The kid didn't cut it?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Nah, Beamen did okay. It was Julian fumbled, they beat us by three.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Shit! Julian, man... (shakes his head) -.. What'd the kid throw?

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: TDs?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Two. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Holy moly! (awkwardly tries to sit up, screams) Oh God, shit!!... (then calmer) I can beat this!...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: The pain's bad, kid.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Comes and goes. I can control my morphine intake... but I can't get enough.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I could use a drink myself. He pours himself some water distastefully, as Cap plays with his pump.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: (yelling with pain) Cindy, did you call the nurse!? Is this working! Jesus, tell ‘em I'm a football player! Pump up the goddamn volume! (laughs) «+». and Christy thinks I'll be ready to play in three weeks...

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: (on phone) We've been waiting...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: She's dreamin'.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: What is her deal? All these flowers. I've known Christy since she was in braces, man. If Art was alive he'd be here, not a bunch of flowers.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: She's President now -- what's more to say.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: She just didn't want to bother you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Montana, he had something like this. I'm in better shape. A few weeks of rehab and I'1l be there, Tony. Playoffs for sure.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You just gotta get over this Montana thing, Rock. You're never gonna be that good.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Screw you. If I had a decent coach, I'd be...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Take it easy, will ya! Don't overachieve. Breathe. Even at 50 percent, there's nobody better out there...

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Playoffs... I'll be ready. Tony touches Cap gently on the head.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: It's late. I'1l stop by in the morning. Get some rest. ‘Night, Cindy. She acknowledges him.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Tony... (as Tony turns back) Don't give up on me.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (beat) You're like a son to me, Cap. I'll fight for you till the day I die. He exits as the PHONE RINGS and Cindy follows Tony out.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Cindy! Can you get the phone!

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Finally! What do you do for heart attacks? Wait till they pass? 20 minutes ago we rang... Cap closes his eyes. He can't find a spot of stillness -- the pain boiling up again.  98

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a high-rise apartment above the bay, sporting a glorious view of the curve of the city against the ocean, shadows play off the balcony from the TELEVISION within -- a MUTED "End Zone Weekly" plays (NOTE: This is not Jack Rose's "Sports Corner," rather an ESPN-type national show).

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (on the phone) Mom, I didn't know I was going in... sure I woulda called you... She wants to talk to you. He laughs and hands the phone to his attractive girlfrien VANESSA STRUTHERS on the couch next to him -- a longtime sweetheart, she is studying marketing.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: (into phone) Mrs. Beamen, hi!... Yeah he was great!... No, I think he was just nervous...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (UN-MUTING the TV) Tell her I'm on again!

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Oh, Mrs. Beamen, right now! It's on! You gettin’ it? (to Willie) I don't think they have that cable channel in East Texas, honey.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Here it is. I'm about to do it.

dialogues.speaker: ON TV A98
dialogues.text: Shots of Tyler Cherubini going down... Shots of Willie stepping in.

dialogues.speaker: TV VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... in stepped third-string QB Willie Beamen, and after a very shaky start, Beamen hung in to deliver a surprising game, coming up just short in the fourth on Julian 'The Slicker' Washington's catastrophic fumble. Not that Willie didn't have his own nauseating moments! (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The infamous vomit in the huddle on national television. Willie covers his eyes. We also hear upset SCREAMING from MOM on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: You didn't tell me you threw up!

dialogues.speaker: TV VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: «+. the Sharks are now looking at a 7-6 record with a very tough schedule comin' up, but Tyler Cherubini with an ankle sprain looks like he'll be ready next week. Let's hope in any case that Willie Beamen remembers his Tums for the Chicago Rhinos next week! Willie MUTES the TV, taking the phone back from Vanessa.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: .+. It was moving so fast... you're a cruel woman, Mama! (more serious) Uh-huh... No probably not... No, I don't know yet. (growing tenser) Mama, I... look, I'm number three, there's nothing I... They don't wanna look!... Yeah, yeah... you keep prayin', okay. Say hi to everybody... Uh-huh, you too, right... (hangs up, looks at Vanessa, deflated) She wants me to start.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Oh, baby, she just wants the best for ya. She hugs him like his Mom might.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark walls in this high-class hangout are filled with celebrity photos, especially the Sharks and Dolphins. Caricatures of the football crowd hang over the bar where D'Amato, Nick Crozier, and Montezuma Monroe drink. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ON TV
dialogues.text: Jack "Ripper" Rose, the local expert on the Sharks, who seems to prove that the more you know about a team, the less you really understand, interviews a guest on his local "Sports Corner."

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (on TV, to guest) ... Frank, Frank, Frank, you gotta wonder why D'Amato called that play when everyone knows J-Man likes to pick his spot when he runs... and you're running the same play twice in a row? Come on! There's a reason this team has lost four in a row. Forget about the offensive line and Cap Rooney. Forget about money- grubbing greed-head Christina Pagniacci who sold three of last year's stars. And forget about the defense -- there is none! This team is just not in sync. They remind me of my ‘ex.' She had 21 different personalities. Seven of them hated me... (as his guest laughs) No kiddin', I think D'Amato's play books have consisted of the same 11 plays since 1971. It's gotta be a shorter list than 'The History of Jews in Sports,' but lucky for him, the Sharks have a couple of teeth left in their head, otherwise these guys would be bottom-feeding at 2-14 instead of thrashin' at 7-6...

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Glancing away from the omnipresent television (several others dot the bar space, all tuned to sports), Tony drinks Scotch -- one of several -- his thoughts depressed and fatalistic tonight. Four losses in a row is a phenomenon that has never happened to him before. MANDY, a young glamorous woman, sitting down the bar with a girlfriend, catches his eye.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (re: TV) Glad he's not talking about me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: (during this) «+. you play safe, you lose. It's just not a theory, they can prove it. You feed a computer all the games where a coach protected a modest lead -- 10 points or less -- 300 games, 10 years, there's this guy he did this study at Harvard... it came out the coaches lost... 71 percent of the time!

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: 71 percent my ass! It can't be more than 40 percent, probably less. What's the information they put in those damn things?!... Shit, what're you guys gonna do next -- stick computer chips up my players' butts so you can monitor what their shit's thinking?

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: (sweetly) That's a great fucking idea, Monty -- if you had any neuronal connections left after what -- 20 concussions? -- I might actually take that as an insult, but...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (signals the bartender) You get any more stats in those goddamn computers what the hell you need a coach for anymore? I mean it's like we're all rushing forward here -- faster, bigger, smarter. We're all thinking too damned much... we're not even looking around at what we're passing by, leaving behind... You know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: I sure do. The BARTENDER pours another Scotch, beers for the others.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Here you go, Coach. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Thanks (nickname)... (to all, noting his caricature above) Y'know, I'm starting to look like that guy. That's what's fucking scary.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Yeah, a little. Crozier clears his throat, needs to talk business.

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: Y'know, Tony, I think we gotta simplify the playbook for Cherubini. These Rhino linebackers are fast little ATVs. We gotta pick ‘em apart with precision -- Cherubini to two tight ends; ask the wideouts to go short over the middle... More screens, traps...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Nick, I'm not re-doing the whole goddamn game plan for Cherubini with three more games. The linemen aren't that quick, y'know what I mean?... and when Cap comes back for the playoffs, he's gonna go crazy with a whole new calling scheme, different rhythms, shit!...

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: Tony, what I'm saying is if we don't redo the game plan, we won't make the playoffs... and what happens if Cap doesn't come back this year?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (starting to anger) Hey, Nick -- when you get your team, you do it your way. But don't let me catch you telling anyone Cap Rooney's not comin' back, okay? I don't care what Mrs. Pagniacci Junior says. Stay out of it!... I've seen Cap do this for years. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He leaves. 56.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When he sets his mind to it, he'll walk right in there -- maybe ‘gainst the Emperors -- and he'll shine just like a new dime, that's how fucking great this guy is! Never underestimate 'Rock' Rooney, okay?...

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... But we need a game plan, Tony, that...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (changes subject) +. y'know every time I drink more than two of these, I think of Jeanette...

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: How is that gal?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (grimaces ) We try talkin’ but we sound like two undertakers talkin’ shop...

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Great lady, Jeanette. You gave her up too easy.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Y'ever try living with her, Monty...? She was nuts. Went fundamentalist on me.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: (finishes his beer, to Crozier) They say a coach needs three things in this life -- a wife who shuts up, a dog who licks him whenever he wants, and a quarterback who don't get hurt... So, this turkey's wife took a hike on him, his dog got run over, and his quarterback ruptured his goddamn back, talk about luck. Gotta piss...

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: Mind if I join you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Only if you hold your own dick, kid.

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: So tell me, Monty, did you really play with leather helmets in the good old days?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
