dialogues.text: (chimes in) You forgot the fourth thing, Monty -- a defense! I know it's old- fashioned to keep the other team from scoring, but it's effective.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Kiss my ass, D'Amato. Lemme tell you something, kid, those leather helmets were fucking great! They held our brains in, ‘cause back then men knew how to hit and get hit. When they allowed face-guards for you punks, that was the end of the game that I knew... As they move off:

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: Do you defensive guys ever move your lips when you speak? Or is it true you all like grunting better...?

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: I like grunting better than that techno-babble bullshit you offensive weenies talk... Tony's eyes wander, against his will, back to the TV.

dialogues.speaker: A99
dialogues.text: Jack Rose continues to talk a mile a minute -- on camera and then in background V.O. as we return to Tony. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: «+. I tell you right here and now -- Chicago's gonna wipe us out! They got a playbook with 200 variations on the pass for chrissake! Sure D'Amato likes to act tough and ‘keep it simple, stupid' for our Sharkies, and some people even think he's a genius with his book of 75 plays, but hey, a lot of us think, you know, like this is no longer the '70s and the '80s -- hey we're talking the late '60s when this guy started coaching -- and you all know by now how much of a fan I am of D'Amato getting himself a lobotomy or maybe cloned with some goat because anything... even Jack Kevorkian, would be better than what we got! Give me some smack! (high-fives his guest) Give me a pound. Give me some love... Tony's eyes have shifted back to the caricature of himself on the wall, a man fatter, older, and more degenerate than he actually looks. Mandy, the young woman he noticed earlier, slides up next to him, sits, sipping a non-alcoholic blue-ice number with a straw.

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: You're that coach, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah, Tony D'Amato. He shakes hands.

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: Wow! Hi. I'm Mandy Murphy. I can't believe it. I thought it was you but I wasn't sure. You look different on TV.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: Yeah. You look much better in real life. You're always yelling at people on TV. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (pointing to the caricature) Yeah well at least I look better than that old fart... I think?

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: You do...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (starting on another Scotch) Thanks. How old are you, Mandy?

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: How old do you want me to be? (as he shrugs; smiles) I don't think age matters. I really don't. I think older guys have a certain thing.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Older guys are the nicest guys. At least in my experience... (she gently touches his hand) You know, I always wanted to meet you... ever since I was about 17, I was going with this football jock -- and I saw you on the sidelines. You were winning this big game...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You mean the Pantheon Cup...?

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's it! That was wild. (as Tony laughs) I'd never repeat this -- only to you, you promise to keep this a secret -- ?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I promise. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: (whispers into his ear) .+. I uh... started masturbating to football games watching you... (also: AD LIBS)... Tony's taken aback. She touches his knee, goes further.

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: «++. you wanna go out with me... ‘Coach'?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You mean like on a date?

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, like on a date... (leaning close) I got a place -- close by, quiet... It's a thousand... five thousand for the night. You won't regret it... (pause) What do you say, handsome?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Thank you. I'm flattered, but...

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: You sure? I got friends. (indicating Monroe returning alone from restroom) I could do your friends too.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mandy... some other time maybe.

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: (disappointed) Fair enough. Hey, good luck with the team. I'll be rooting for you... ‘Tony' A plucky kiss on his cheek. She slinks away, as Monroe sits, enrapt by her legs.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Mmmm! Dang! Don't tell me you passed on that, D'Amato? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: .-. I must really be drunk.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: ... I heard sex helps your coaching instincts. But let's get genius boy to run a stat on coaches who like hunting and fishing better than snatch, see what he comes up with...?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (laughs, segues) ++. you think we're slowing down, Monty?

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Shit, we're not getting any younger. These are long days, 16 hours, something's gotta give.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: »+. you think you can lose your coaching instincts?

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: (chuckles) You never had ‘em anyway, so how can you lose ‘em?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Well, that last play today, there was a moment when... I didn't know what to call... that's never happened to me like that before... in 22 seasons...

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Come on, we were on our third quarterback, Christina was throwing plays at us every five minutes, and Julian's about 10 years old upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: All I have are my instincts. I lose them... I got nothin’... (noticing) Say, what'd you do to Crozier? Stuff him in the toilet?  100 62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The letter "L" is written with a black marker next to the Americans on the season schedule (Miami is now 7-6). Ther are only three games left in the regular season: Chicago, California and New York. Tony cradles a cordless phone while drinking Scotch, as a COMPUTERIZED VOICE introduces Jeanette's voice on the answer machine.

dialogues.speaker: JEANETTE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Please leave your full name and a message after the tone and we'll get back to you.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (into his cordless) Hi, Jeanette, it's Tony... I was hoping you'd still be awake. What time is it out there anyway? I tried to call earlier but things got... never mind. Listen... He walks into his bedroom, emptying his pockets on the dresser. Pictures of the past confront him -- Jeanette, a boy and a girl; another of Tony with Cap Rooney and Art Pagniacci winning the "Pantheon Cup."

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: «+. tell Tommy we gotta game in L.A. In a couple of weeks. I'm hoping we could maybe get together?... I don't have his new number but... the thing is I'd like to see him and... and you...? (he weaves, stumbles as he looks for something he dropped on the rug) I really miss the shit outta Timmy and Melinda... Y'know, love to see them, Jesus! Grandkids, Jeanette, we got grandkids... Anyway, what's there to say? Cap got hurt Sunday. Just another heart-breaking Sunday right? (pause) Okay, well, bye... He has crossed to the toilet, where he unsuccessfully tries to urinate -- all over the place. A COMPUTERIZED VOICE suddenly cuts in to tell him:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: .+-. Your call has been cancelled. Please leave your full name after the tone and record again. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Aw shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (NOTE: Potential one of three football practices -- a brief montage set to music, that leads us to:)

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Tony drives up to a beautiful mansion on one of Miami's bays in an older, elegant car. As he talks into an audio-video monitor, the gates roll open.

dialogues.speaker: ACTION
dialogues.text: In a large cross-shadowed private office, Christina and Johnny Polito listen to Ed Phillips on the phone -- noticing Tony's drive-up on the indoor monitor... The walls reveal pictures of Christina with various high- powered individuals in the city; an MBA from Stanford; others that are competitive at tennis and golf, on safari and skiing with her husband; shots of her as a young girl with her dad. In these images of fishing, riding, hunting, perhaps one senses that Christina was raised as an only son by Art Pagniacci and forever embodies the hardness of that fate.

dialogues.speaker: ED PHILLIPS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (into phone) Well, we think 100 million is extortion too, Governor... Then will you file a friend-of-the- court brief on our behalf if we go up against the League's transfer fee?... Great!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: «+. you're sure? No public bond issues -- no extra tax assessments?

dialogues.speaker: ED PHILLIPS
dialogues.text: (waves her off, nodding) -+. couldn't ask for more than that... good talking to you, Governor. Say hi to Teresa. And Christina sends a big kiss! Okay. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hangs up. 64. 102

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (excited) So let me get this straight: the Governor of California's saying there's nothing for the public to vote on, right?

dialogues.speaker: ED PHILLIPS
dialogues.text: (pleased) That's what he's saying. He's got a way to finance a new stadium in Hawthorne, with lottery and casino money! As long as we partner with this realty company he's pushing...

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY POLITO
dialogues.text: Sure. He owns all that shit land he wants to get rid of.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: +. he gives us the full concession, parking, signage, sponsorship money?

dialogues.speaker: ED PHILLIPS
dialogues.text: (nods ) --. and 100 percent from the luxury boxes and club seats!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (amazed) My God, L.A. is a dream! You realize they're giving us the world, Ed?!

dialogues.speaker: ED PHILLIPS
dialogues.text: (downplaying it) Well, it's certainly good enough to leverage the City of Miami into a new stadium.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Oh, Ed! It's more than that... (pause, seeing Tony's car pull up) I just don't trust Smalls backing this stadium bond. Dad always said he was a thief in a tuxedo... She glances at a picture on her desk of her late father. Beneath it in the silver frame she has had engraved: "Whatever It Takes." (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ED PHILLIPS
dialogues.text: What do you expect? Smalls is an asshole, but he'll deal. He always has. And he knows we've got a big glitch anyway.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: We don't really, Ed, we can...!

dialogues.speaker: ED PHILLIPS
dialogues.text: You keep underestimating the power of the franchises, Christina. They don't want us! They want an expansion team in L.A. which they can make a lot more money with!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY POLITO
dialogues.text: Bullshit! They want an established team with a fan base. A new stadium with a multiplex theater shopping mall. We're in the entertainment business, Ed. Think football in the 21st Century.

dialogues.speaker: ED PHILLIPS
dialogues.text: Johnny, have you got some sleazy little side deal I don't know about yet?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY POLITO
dialogues.text: Ed, you're getting old.

dialogues.speaker: ED PHILLIPS
dialogues.text: «+. And you're getting greedy, Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: The Association will listen to reason. L.A. is an entertainment empire! It can easily handle two teams. Here, what? The wrong fan base. No Hispanic players, no Hispanic fans... (off silence) Ed, if ever you owed Dad a favor, make it this one! This team will be born again in L.A.!

dialogues.speaker: ED PHILLIPS
dialogues.text: What about the Rosenthal bid?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (thinking about it) $250 million?... It's so low. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Christina, Tony in. 66.

dialogues.speaker: ED PHILLIPS
dialogues.text: Wasn't so low when your dad and I started.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY POLITO
dialogues.text: With a new stadium and a winning team, Ed, we could sell the team for 800 million.

dialogues.speaker: ED PHILLIPS
dialogues.text: (disbelieving) You're like your father that way, darling -- a dreamer... My advice to you is, sell the goddamn team. You don't really want to own a football team, Christina. You're still young -- start a family. conflicted, watches as her housekeeper shows

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: I still like this business. Let's keep this quiet for now, Ed, can we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony looks hungover and bumps into something, as Christin crosses into the giant-sized living room.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Come in... Morning, Tony.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Christina... Ed. You know, I keep looking for the A.T.M. machines in these houses...

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY POLITO
dialogues.text: I never find one that works.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Alka-Seltzer?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (rolls his eyes) No. I already had breakfast... at four this morning.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: ... Hell of a loss, we were so goddamn close. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Remote in hand, she flicks on a state-of-the-art video screen.

dialogues.speaker: ON TV A102
dialogues.text: The shot of Washington fumbling in excruciating slo-mo.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: You know, I can see why my mother somehow got herself into a drunken stupor watching football games all her life... but this kind of play makes you want to jump out the fucking window!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You can run that play a million times, Christy, but it ain't gonna change a thing. On any given Sunday...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (overlapping) ‘You either gonna win or you gonna lose. The point is can you win or lose like a man?' Dad said a lot of catchy things.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Actually I said it, but...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: But he never could stand losing, could he! (as Julian fumbles again) «+. But J. just couldn't resist going for his bonus yards?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Blame me, not Julian. It was my call.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: +. I know it was, Tony -- but I'll tell you this -- Julian wasn't thinking about you, he was thinking about the extra million dollars he gets when he hits 1500 yards... (glancing at Ed) Which, by the way, definitely helps blow out our fucking salary cap for next year... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You're the one who negotiated his incentive clause.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: «+. which is why I'd like you to sit him out -- then maybe he'll get his head into the game. And save us some dollars in the bargain.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Pretty smart move, Christy. You want me to bench my All-Pro back? Any other suggestions? A testy edge to the dialogue, as Christina freezes the image of Julian fumbling. She shows him the sports section of USA Today -- folded to a condemnation of the team, specifically Tony. Although raised to treat Tony like an "uncle" in a large Italian-American family, the team comes first and foremost.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Sarcasm is not a solution. Four in a row, Tony. They want your head. Without Cap, it's gonna take a miracle to make the playoffs.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (re: the newspaper) .». Your father'd laugh at this jerk, Christy. We're a solid team, and we're gonna get to the playoffs. This is not the time to panic.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: I'm not 'panicking' -- but no surgeon I know in the country is saying Cap'll be back by playoff time -- even with the bye week...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (waves it off) Doctors are like lawyers, always protecting their asses against malpractice! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ED PHILLIPS
dialogues.text: Tony, without the playoffs there's no more TV money. And frankly, I don't think we have a chance in hell of getting this new stadium bond issue through...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (wearying of Tony) «+. the economics just don't work -- the fact is this season is a disaster, a write-off. It's over! Now Tony's headache is getting worse.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: It's 'over'!? The hell it's over! We been there before -- I can pull this out. I always have. Worse things than this have...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Dad used to say, 'No intensity, no victory.' Where the hell is your intensity, Tony!? We were always in the playoffs. Four years ago the only thing we worried about was winning a third Pantheon Cop! Now what? We're a second-tier team, Tony, that's what! (as he objects) .-. No, admit it! You're not being honest, we're the fifth, sixth team in this league. We just don't get the respect anymore. For chrissake, Tony, just four years ago we won the Pantheon Cup! Do you remember! We beat the pants off Massachusetts! Dad would be shocked to see this mess we created...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony is fuming, but a part of him knows she's right.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (darkly, pacing) I was there, Christy -- remember? We're solid, we're just not inspired. We got too many free agents... (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (indicating the frozen tape) .-.. Julian's a 'merc' who's here for the money and he brings that attitude with him to the team. The end of the season, he goes. And we rebuild our running game and...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (pissed) Running game!? Okay -- you always talk about a running game. But who cares as long as you win! People want to watch passes, touchdowns, high scores! That's the game now, Tony!... We paid a lot of money to get Nick Crozier here from Minnesota specifically to modernize this offense. But when I look down at the field I don't see any new play calling, I don't see him doing what he does best. And frankly, what is most disturbing, is I don't see you even listening to his calls from the booth...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Football is played on the field, Christina, not in the goddamn boxes! You knew that when you had candy stuck in your braces. When'd you forget it?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (bristles) So you know everything about everything, right, Tony? Another silence. Ed coughs. Christina regrets the atmosphere, throws up her hands and paces.

dialogues.speaker: ED PHILLIPS
dialogues.text: (excusing himself) Listen, why don't you two...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (in a yielding tone) Ed, stay... (to Tony) You gripe about Julian Washington but you completely ignore the problems with Cap and Shark? I don't get it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: If we'd gotten the linemen I wanted in the first place, our first two quarterbacks might still be walking.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Think about the future. Do you know what we could get for Cap right now? Probably a first anda third draft choice. He's still got an arm, and people respect him. We know he's finished but if we're smart, we can...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No, I don't know that, Christy, I don't! Cap's got two, maybe three great years left in him. This is football. Today guys in their 40s are playing... (a silence) Do I gotta remind you he helped build this franchise, which you benefitted from? That he's a hero to the working people of Florida. And one of the greatest pressure players of all time. You just don't cut a man like Cap Rooney!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Excuse me -- Cap and Shark were great, but memories don't pass and tackle like they used to...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Shark changed linebacking forever! He made a quantum leap in the game!...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: ... And we can say good-bye to both of them with dignity! With class! We'll give ‘em positions in the front office, retire their numbers. A going-away day that...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (angry) That goes without saying. But I am not cutting Cap Rooney or Shark Lavay. No matter how much ‘'class' you do it with. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My contract is very clear on this point, Christy. I coach my way. I never tolerated interference from the front office and your father never interfered when...

dialogues.speaker: ED PHILLIPS
dialogues.text: (politick) Tony, Art spent money like water. He never really cared about the bottom line. He wanted to win at any cost. In the modern game, with marketing costs high as they are...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Tony, I am not re-signing a seven- million-dollar-a-year, 39-year- old quarterback no matter how big he was. (pointing to a stack of budget sheets on her desk) I crunch those numbers every month till my fingers bleed. We make less money than 90 percent of the other teams. The economics simply don't make any sense!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (intense) Fuck the economics! Your father, you hear me! Your father never interfered! He made it work!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (equally intense) «+. Because you were a fighter then! You had intensity, Tony! But today he'd cut your ass! Because that's just the way the game is now. I love this team as much -- if not more -- than you. I was born into this goddamn business, so don't try to make me out to be some heartless bitch in a skybox bleeding my players dry...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What's your point, Christy? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (drawing up) The point is... as much as I respect... my famous ‘Uncle Tony' -- the team's just not responding to you, and I'll be damned if I'm going to let everything my father fought for slide down the drain with you at the helm. I will do anything -- you hear me, anything -- to bring this team back to greatness!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I guess I had nothing to do with that. It was all your dad... Am I excused now? 73.

dialogues.speaker: A102
dialogues.text: He throws a hard look at Ed, who looks away. Tony stalks to the door.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (after him) Who's playing the child now, Tony? Do I have to remind you of what kind of ground you're on? Everybody's got to negotiate... you too.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (at the door) Are you saying my contract's up at the end of the year? And the ‘economics aren't there'? Is that what you're saying, Christy?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: +. You know, you're not offering me a whole lot right now, Tony... ‘Whatever it takes.' I'm just doing it the way he did it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You're not even close... You know how your dad and I used to negotiate my contract? We had a beer and we shook hands.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: I don't drink beer, Tony.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (exits) No, I guess you don't. Christina shares a look with Ed. She shakes her head: "Beer?"  103 104 105 106 74.

dialogues.speaker: MIAMI SHARKS
dialogues.text: Miami QB Tyler Cherubini releases his throw far over the head of Sanderson. The crowd boos.

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... this has been a tough start for Tyler Cherubini, who has yet to find his rhythm.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: «+. only two for eight so far and sacked three times. Ouch! 14-3 Chicago. Second quarter. Eight minutes left...

dialogues.speaker: STANDS
dialogues.text: Shark fans are sullen. Signs read: "D'Amato is a Dinosaur"... images of D'Amato in Thanksgiving turkey feathers, etc. The capacity, again, is at best two-thirds.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Coach D'Amato talks quietly with Tyler Cherubini and Cap Rooney, using a cane in civilian clothing. Willie, ignored, watches from the bench, not warming up. As Cherubini wanders off, the QB Coach fetches Willie. D'Amato's eyes now flash on him...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Get Beamen.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Shark rages up and down the defensive line, faking a blitz, baiting the young Chicago QB.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: Hey you, white-bread! Got your cup on? ‘Cause I'm gonna runneth it over!! (to Chicago lineman) I'm gonna stomp you, B.J., and then I'm gonna stomp your million- dollar bonus baby white-ass quarterback and then I'm gonna go up in the stands and stomp both your mommas! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Chicago QB, made a little nervous by Shark, bobbles the ball slightly... Shark, reading the trap, finds a lane through the Chicago line for a crushing hit on the baby-bonus QB, who pops the ball loose... Miami's "Beast Man" instantly pounces on it. Shark, congratulated by his teammates, rises hurting, and hiding it... In a brief, micro-moment:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: reveals: BLURRING (SPX) ON teammates and stadium.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Willie, in his oddball way, walks up to the edge of the sideline, with Tony.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I always feel good.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Feel like throwin' up?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Hell no!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Hey, last time you puked you had a hell of a game.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: That was last time.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Make a ritual out of it and people'll respect it... Go right at ‘em. Go with the spread. What I want from you is concentration. Focus. Downfield. Every inch. See it before you do it. You see it, you do it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I got it. I feel it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: So... What are you waiting for? Make me a believer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Willie heads out onto the field.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Set Black 33, Black 33, go! Willie, on a play action pass, takes off running, gesturing to his blockers, directing his flow like an experienced back... He is slammed hard after a big 32- yard gain to the Chicago 43 yard line; the crowd roars with lusty approval. Julian Washington eyes Willie wearily as he bounces up. Is this kid going to be another runner in his backfield?

dialogues.speaker: COACH'S BOOTH
dialogues.text: Crozier on the headset upstairs:

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Will you teach the kid how to slide, for Chrissake, Nick! Before he kills himself! How many times I gotta tell you, I don't need another Julian out there --

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There must be a reason why this kid was cut from so many teams. Sooner or later these kinds of quarterbacks get themselves hurt with wildman stuff like that! For a few extra yards it sure doesn't make sense... but that they gotta learn...

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: At the Chicago six-yard line, Willie surveys the defensiv alignment.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Set, Green 68, Green 68, go! Julian rushes forward left of Willie for the hand-off -- but Willie doesn't give him the ball -- Julian breaks for a confused micro-moment, then throws himself forward into the pile -- as Willie races right, as if to run, then loops a high, curving pass to the second wide-out in the end zone. Touchdown!

dialogues.speaker: SCOREBOARD
dialogues.text: reads CHICAGO 14, MIAMI 10. THIRD QUARTER. 02:41...

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: The stadium PA SYSTEM explodes a triumphant "SHARK THEME" as Willie jogs past Tony on his way to the bench, crossing the kicking unit on their way in...

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (into helmet) Good play, baby! Good call!!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (to Willie) What the hell was that?!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Bootleg.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I know it was a goddamn bootleg! Julian passes Tony, shaking his head... Willie gulps down Gatorade as Tony comes after him.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: «+. Bootleg? Very creative. I never thought of that in a million years. In fact, I didn't call that! I called a goddamn Double Tight Regular 22 Fox. You know what that is, son?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know what that is. Tony gets right in his face, indicates the game plan in his hand. There is no backing down.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You run the plays I call -- you with me, son?!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I'm with you, boss.

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Glad we don't have a microphone down there, folks, ‘cause I wouldn't want to be on Tony D'Amato's dark side now, would you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As Tony stalks away, Willie's expression is one of quiet anger.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (on headset) Is he fucking with me, Nick, or doesn't he know the play!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC is UPBEAT, as Willie slices and dices the L.A. defense:

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Willie steps back and throws a precise 25-yard spiral, aimed for the pocket on Chicago's 5-yard line -- it sails perfectly to a place where Jimmy Sanderson accelerates to reach that sweet spot in time where ball and man meet -- sailing right PAST US into the end zone, the Chicago safety trailing. Touchdown!... Willie races down to the end zone for a celebration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie fires a crisp bullet of a pass to the tight end in the chancy seam of the zone.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (helmet) Hustle Right Switch 60 Bravo. Hustle Right Switch 60 Bravo.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (to team) Okay, Switch 60 Bravo -- hold it. What's Switch 60 Bravo?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Sprint draw regular group. It's moneytime. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: ‘Sandman,' your guy's laying back --

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: All day.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: How about 88 Turbo?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: That's what you want, money, that's what it is.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Hold it -- that my play.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: That was your play. These guys are done! Let's kill some Rhinos. Twins Right 3 Zig 88 Turbo. On two. Ready? They clap and move to the ball, Washington upset.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Tony watches the new formation, amazed.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (headset) ... Now what in the holy see is he doing... Crozier?!

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: (actually delighted) Hell if I know, Tony...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Set, Red 88, Red 88, go! Sanderson races for the left corner -- Willie not taking his eyes off him, he pump fakes the ball to him -- but once the Chicago defense commits to his sleight of hand, Willie bootlegs it towards the right end zone. Two defensive backs reverse and run right at him. It's going to be a race to the wire. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STUNT
dialogues.text: The DBs have him beat by a yard or so. But Willie leaps into the air at the 2-yard line to avoid the diving tacklers. Then, finding himself having to go yet higher, he flips in mid-air, taking himself over their heads, pads and all, into a somersault, landing scot-free in the end zone. TD! Amazing!

dialogues.speaker: OWNER'S BOX
dialogues.text: Christina can't believe what she just saw, looking at the:

dialogues.speaker: TV REPLAY A118
dialogues.text: Willie's somersault is something that is going to make the highlight reel for a long time to come -- his second week in a row!

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Kev, did you see what I just saw?!

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I sure did, Tug! And Miami goes ahead, 23-17.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (to Ed, genuinely puzzled) Where's this kid been all this time? In D'Amato's doghouse?

dialogues.speaker: PRESS BOX
dialogues.text: Jack "Ripper" Rose also senses a turn in the destiny of his team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: downstairs AT Willie --

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: -- inspires him to rap excitedly at his laptop, a poet in disguise describing a new major athlete... Insert (TBD).  120 121 122 123 81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie trots off the field, looking for D'Amato, about 15 or 20 yards away, with daring in eyes that say, "You want to win or not? Go fuck yourself!"... Cap, next to Tony, reads the situation, but the rest of the team, standing and milling, is simply awed by this new discovery.

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: If I'm Tony D'Amato right now I'm looking to the football gods saying, 'What did I ever do to deserve this?'

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You bet! Tony must've been good to a lot of widows and orphans over the years. A back-up quarterback like this?

dialogues.speaker: ON TV 121
dialogues.text: Tony watching, deeply perturbed at having his plays changed by this young, arrogant enigma. He keeps it inside. END OF MONTAGE #1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stars are out tonight. Establishment Miami meets football jocks meets business supporters meets politicos, meets sex and alcohol. It's also a charity event, designed by the Sharks' P.R. Department to deliver a Children's Needy Fund some million dollars a year, most of which is being raised tonight -- with, naturally, the colorful Mayor Tyrone Smalls in attendance. Julian Washington ROARS up to the dock in a dramatic CIGARETTE BOAT -- product logos for his sponsors all over it. Four gorgeous girls cling to him. Flashbulbs explode, the paparazzi eating this up as much as Julian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cap Rooney and his gorgeously-attired wife Cindy now enter, the glamour couple of the party, though Cap still struggles with a cane. The photographers descend on them, clicking. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Watching all from a discreet corner is Tony, interrupted by three FANS/BUSINESSMEN coming up to him for autographs; unsuccessfully, he tries to duck away.

dialogues.speaker: FANS
dialogues.text: Hey, Tony!... Coach!... How ‘bout an autograph? etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A banner reading: CHILDREN'S FUND OF MIAMI. Flashbulbs and camera idolize Christina presenting a check to MAYOR TYRONE SMALLS, a boisterous Afro-American in his 60s.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: .-. So, on behalf of the Art Pagniacci Foundation, (with a glance to her mom) I'm glad to present D.A.R.E. with this $250,000 contribution... Much applause.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR SMALLS
dialogues.text: (dramatic) The city of Miami would like to thank Christina Pagniacci, you are a great Miamian! You have done as much as anyone to eliminate drugs and crime from our city streets... -+. and your Sharks have provided wonderful role models for our inner-city youth to look up to. I'm all for it, honey, now let's get down and party!! Raucous laughter. People have long come to accept the Mayor's idiosyncracies. Smalls greets Christina's mother, a blitzed Margaret, on the podium, escorted by Ed Phillips. Also there is Andy, Christina's yawning, tired husband. Observing this in the crowd are Willie and Vanessa, who feels herself out of place and underdressed for this affair. She excuses herself to the ladies' room... as Willie walks over to Sanderson and Julian.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: (at Christina) Definitely some nice hams -- like to pork her when she ain't lookin’... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: She don't want your ass, man! That husband dude of her's got her snatch locked up like Fort Knox anyhow...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: «+. If you gonna be with a white girl, might as well pick the right one, got some pull, the one on top.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: (overlapping) I'm already on top. I just want to fuck her.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: (re: Margaret) The ghost, baby. The High Priestess of the Paycheck! Oooh, tell me there aren't some fine- looking 'dimes' here! I gotta get me some phone numbers ' fore Heather closes me down. What about you? (looking) Vanessa policing your ass?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Don't worry your little brain none, ‘Sandman,' I got a skeleton key end of my dick fits all locks. Fans now envelop them, singling out Julian... Vanessa, returning from the bathroom, her makeup even worse now, can't help but notice Willie openly gazing at women of beauty, with finer clothes and jewels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shark sits next to Dr. Mandrake's girlfriend TRISH, a buxom 20-year-old, talking with a very rich ELDERLY COUPLE and several OTHER COUPLES, who don't notice Shark's hand finding its way beneath the table between Trish's thighs...

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: (to Elderly Couple) «+. The point of the game, see, is really about contact -- the more intense the better. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OLDER WOMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Does it really hurt when you hit someone?

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: Sometimes, but it's all good! Trish squirms in her chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christina is trying to get the Mayor's attention, surrounded by his entourage.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: So, Tyrone, can we talk now...?

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR SMALLS
dialogues.text: (for all) So, where is that bold and beautiful quarterback of yours, Christina? Christina, put off, turns impatiently to Cap and Cindy, approaching.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Cap, say hello to his Honor.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Pleasure to see you again, sir. You know Cindy...? They shake hands, AD LIB. As photographers snap pictures.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR SMALLS
dialogues.text: (to Cap) Show me some love!... (to Christina, sotto) ... I meant the other quarterback. You know -- the black dude.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: (overhearing) He means Willie. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Oh, of course. (sweetly) Cap, do you think you could find him...? Thanks. Cindy, you look beautiful. Cap and Cindy share a look of disappointment as they go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony and Margaret Pagniacci, leaning against an upstairs railing, take in a view of the party below; Margaret commenting on the AFFA Pantheon Cup ring that Tony wears tonight, part of his formal wear.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: ... These kinda places I keep looking for an A.T.M. machine...

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: «+. do you wear it often?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (offering her the ring) Nah. Just special occasions. Looks too weird. I get ona plane, I gotta check it...

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (holds it lovingly) Art wore his in bed. You know he spent hours designing it himself... (ambiguous ) .+. he cut my cheek with it once. I bled. Tony is unsure how to respond.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Margaret, we need someone... a football person out front who can...

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Tony, stop. Christina's in charge now. It's the way Art wanted it. This catches Tony off guard.  128 86.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: .-. it's like, have you ever seen a woman giving birth? -- lotta blood, sweat, and tears, right? -- Well, football's a man's way of having that baby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trish's hot, flushed face says it all. She adjusts her panties under the table, allowing better access for Shark's hand. The others listen intently to Shark.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY MAN
dialogues.text: (impeccable accent) What was your best hit, Mister Lavay?

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: +. Well, one time playing in pouring rain, I'm deep... (his hand moves) «+. deep in the zone... They're on top, driving. Their fullback is stuffing the ball down our throat every play... Murmuring slightly, Trish stretches, wrapping her lips around a strawberry from her dessert plate.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: He comes inside again... I'm jamming full force into the hole... wham! Fumble!

dialogues.speaker: TRISH
dialogues.text: (breathless) Ohhh! Right there...!

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, right then and there!.. Now the ball's bouncing free. I'm groping for it, fingers all slippery wet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Mandrake approaches the table.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: The fumble comes my way... only a few seconds left on the clock and... He sees Trish's look. He sees Mandrake's distance. Racing the geometry! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY MAN
dialogues.text: «+. Well, did you score? Trish orgasms just in time -- sinks into the chair, muffling her sounds with a napkin.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: Hell yeah, I scored! Mandrake sits next to Trish, sensing something. Trish conceals her expression when he fondles her.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: What do you say we hit the road, hon?

dialogues.speaker: TRISH
dialogues.text: «++. Oh come on, Harvey, don't be a fuddy duddy! You're always in pajamas by... Mandrake protests. Shark has removed his hand, but notices Madman nearby, coming on strongly to one of the local society dames who impresses him with her face jobs and jewelry. His pregnant, pathetic mouse wife sits alone in a corner, wanting to cry.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: (vising, to the table) Don't go away! (indicating Madman) This guy's turning into my night job. I'll be right back. He moves towards the dance floor...

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: (to the lady, AD LIB) ... What's wrong, let's you and me cut the rug, honbun! (pause) C'mon, I'm not good-looking enough for you? What do you think, I'ma damage case...? Shark grabs him by the lapels and smacks him fairly hard across the face -- not discreetly. Madman registers it, then wants to kill, but when he sees Shark, he grunts docilely... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: Yo, Madman! I can't take your ass nowhere!... (emphatic, as if to a schizophrenic) Patrick's wife is in the corner, Patrick! It's not the time to be "Madman,' is it? Shark looks sheepish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayor Smalls embraces Willie in an extravagant bear hug, as Christina and others look on.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR SMALLS
dialogues.text: Be proud! You are the future of football in this country, son! You are a model for your people now, Willie Beamen! A black man unafraid! Stand tall and gimme some sugar, boy! Willie laughs, hugs the Mayor back.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: You're pretty cool yourself, Mayor... A photo op develops. Vanessa goes unintroduced -- She feels very hurt, not understanding why Willie would ignore her or is he that embarrassed by her? She wanders for the wrong solace over to Cindy and the other wives, chatting in a small group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The once pristine bathroom has deteriorated. Guest soaps are crushed on the floor, towels in the tub. Julian and Sanderson cavort with some girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drs. Powers and Mandrake walk together.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Sanderson's been after me for stuff? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: He's like Jell-O. Just say no and he'll ooze off. Guy's got an insecurity complex the size of China.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: What's he on?

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I don't know. Rits, vikes. End of the season I'm gonna put him in ‘the laundry bin' (off Powers, puzzled) «+. Clinic... (for Powers' benefit) «+. quietly, Allie... Mandrake senses Powers doesn't understand his approach.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Y'ever play hurt, Allie? (off his puzzled look) College, high school, whatever?

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Not really. I played baseball at U.C.L.A.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Ugh! I hate baseball. Nothing happens. Bunch of farmers standing around scratching their nuts looking for fly balls. In football, we all go one way till we get there.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Where's that?

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Who the hell knows, but what counts is...

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Sounds like socialism. Y'ever see spikes fly in your face, Harvey -- or a line drive coming at you 100 miles per hour? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: (teasing) U.C.L.A. baseball, ooh, brutal sport! (seriously) Allie, we gotta work together more -- make sure the guys get there, know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: (pause, concerned) «+. We've always kept our patients informed, Harv, it's part of the deal...

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Where, in Palm Beach? This is Zaire here! These guys are stealing hubcaps while you're writing prescriptions. They have four years to make a million dollars, that's it. A short life but it's a goddamn glorious one! -- as long as you don't mess with their minds!

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: I don't understand. What'd I do?

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: You messed with Zanucky telling him he'll be ready in two weeks. What if he's ready in one week? Then because of you he'll be thinking he's not really ready.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Well, he asked me, and I...

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: You what?! You know, Allie, I know young guys would die for this job. You're making me think I made a stupid mistake, and I'm gonna be embarrassed here...

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, Harvey! I gave up a lot of income to come here, I... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Did you now? You still don't get it, do you, sport? This is not F. Scott Fitzgerald in white bucks time! This is a privilege to be here! This is a spectacle of gladiators with brains for the masses! It's a fucking brilliant concept! And I don't care if every one of ‘em has to play hurt -- you, me, the team, we all play hurt, that's life, sport...! So do me a real favor and get off your high horse, and get down where the worms feed...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crozier tries to snag Christina's attention span.

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: (changing subjects) «+. Can I be honest with you, Christina? It's a waste of my time. I come up with the edge we need -- the stats, the probabilities -- and he just looks at them and shrugs -- it's like he doesn't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: It's really frustrating. It's all gotta be him -- little Napoleon with his 'instincts'!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (looking for the Mayor ) Be patient, Nick, when the time comes --

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: I just want you to know I'm getting offers, Christina, you gotta know that. I want to stay, but I won't waste another season under Tony. She now sees the Mayor free! and goes quickly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (cryptic, to Crozier) You won't...! I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WIVES hold court.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: If my husband doesn't get it five or six times a week, we have problems at home.

dialogues.speaker: PREGNANT WIFE
dialogues.text: We were at that pace, but we've slowed down a little.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER WIFE
dialogues.text: Except on game day.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: That's when I want it most -- but with everything he's on...

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: Dexamethasone?

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: And extra-strength hydrocodeine.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Oooh, that mix makes Jimmy crazy. Can't get it up.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Count your blessings. What's it called again? Cindy, at the top of the food chain, takes notice when Vanessa appears.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Willie managing to keep his food down tonight?

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: (doesn't get it, smiles) He's just fine! Hi. I'm Vanessa Struthers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Jack had such a laugh about that! I'm Cindy Rooney.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Jimmy had to order new shoes. (shaking hands) Heather Sanderson. Vanessa now understands the reference to her fiance.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Are you and Willie married?

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: No, but we've been together for --

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Doesn't count until you're married, honey -- and your name appears in the paper as ‘and wife.' They all laugh.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: And not even then, most of the time.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Do you have a job?

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: No, I'm still studying for an M.B.A. in sports marketing. At Dade Community College. But Willie and I have had to move so many times to...

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Marketing? You're a smart one, I can tell.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: And what do you do?

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Me? Oh, I'm married to the best quarterback in the A.F.F.A., that's all. I consider myself part of a team really...

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: (not sure of her attitude) Oh, that must be very fulfilling for you...  134 94.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christina is at last alone with the slightly-inebriated Mayor.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Why have you been ducking me?

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR SMALLS
dialogues.text: I always forget how pretty you are, Christina.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Cut the crap, Tyrone.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR SMALLS
dialogues.text: What's this bug you got?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: «+. I want the 250 million you promised me... (he looks like a sphinx) You know I can get the rest with the bond. You said you'd give me 100 percent support and now you're getting cold feet just because...

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR SMALLS
dialogues.text: «+. how you gonna pay it back, darlin'?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: I already told you -- we'll split revenue on the club seats, the corporate boxes, all the concessions, the stadium-naming rights, and the increase in ticket sales. There'll be 10,000 new parking spaces. And we'll be pulling in almost 40 million in personal seat licenses over ten years... The concept of a new stadium, T.J., funds the whole deal. Without it, no...

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR SMALLS
dialogues.text: (mocking) ‘Personal seat licenses' -- that's the biggest bunch of bullshit! -- how the hell can you sell the same seat twice? I seen some pretty smooth scams in my time, but only a white man could come up with that one. The fans gonna burn you, honey. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (patiently) .-. All the fans really care about, Tyrone, is winning. And if I don't have the money I need to stay competitive, then this team is finished! That's the bottom line!

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR SMALLS
dialogues.text: There ain't no bottom line, baby. It's an endless fucking pit! (genuinely) Your team's not doin' what the Dolphins are doin'. The schools're howling for money, roads need redoing, a new stadium's the last thing on the city council's mind...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: I'm not asking you to vote, T.J. I'm asking you to deliver! We've been backing you since Dad's time, getting your people passes and money they never dreamed of. We were there for you, and... (delicate) .».. and if you're not there for us, T.J., I'm telling you this... we'd seriously consider leaving this town.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR SMALLS
dialogues.text: (smiles infuriatingly) Sweetheart, you outta here when the city and the county says you outta here. Your lease ain't up for two years so don't start setting fires you can't put out...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (sure of herself) Oh, there's 'loopholes,' Tyrone. Like the goddamn stadium is falling apart, you know -- you haven't contributed one fucking penny to maintenance on that relic! I remodeled the practice facility out of my own pocket. I... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR SMALLS
dialogues.text: (smiles ) Now that's the Pagniacci I believe! I see your teeth! Get down, girl!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (resisting) -.. We're a pro team, T.J., and we're playing in a college stadium built in the '30s, and we're losin' a ton of fucking money. When are you...

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR SMALLS
dialogues.text: Yadda, yadda, yadda! Daddy's girl, you are a relative baby in this town. Go slow. First you get along... then you go along... (puts an arm around her) Come on, honey, you and I known each other too long. Your roots are here in Miami. Why would you want to leave? Your dad created such love, such a foundation...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Tyrone, I'm telling you again -- time is running out and you are playing with fire.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR SMALLS
dialogues.text: (grins) That's the only way I play it.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (grins back) Then we'll see how you like it. She leaves, pissed. It looks like L.A. for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party is getting rowdy as Julian, Sanderson, Madman, Shark, and others heat up the dance floor. Cindy turns to a NASTY WOMAN whose breast implants are as big as her hair. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NASTY WOMAN
dialogues.text: Nice dress. Nice party.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: (bored) Thank you. Did you come here with Julian?

dialogues.speaker: NASTY WOMAN
dialogues.text: (threatened) No, but I'm leaving with him. So don't even think about it, honey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montezuma Monroe intersects Mayor Smalls; they know each other.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Hey, Ty.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR SMALLS
dialogues.text: What's up, brother?

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: (indicating Christina) Hi, Ty... Couldn't help hearin' that Christina conversation...

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR SMALLS
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Same old story, brother. Owners crying broke, y'ever met an owner who ain't losin' money? These guys make extra sure the team loses money. They share a knowing laugh.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: I tell ya I wish I had a fraction of those stadium rights -- I'd take the concessions and parking and tickets -- that's some real bread there... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR SMALLS
dialogues.text: Stadium's where it's at. Now they invented these ‘naming rights' and 'P.S.L.s'. It's all tricky doo. We don't have the money for that stadium. You guys gotta fight through it till you have a successful season. That's the reality... ‘Lady Di' there thinks she's pulling the wool over my eyes and going to L.A. He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: (cautiously) -+. Now I did hear somethin' about that?

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR SMALLS
dialogues.text: (grins) -.. She ain't going nowhere. Keep it tight, Monty. Either way, you got a job here a long time to come. The Mayor returns to the party as Monroe looks down into the gardens for Tony. MUSIC WAFTS OUT from the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret Pagniacci's holding onto Tony's AFFA ring, alone with him; he's had a little too much to drink.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: ‘Life begins with a kick-off,' Art used to say that... He was a great man, Maggie. He was there at the beginning. His kind, forget it! -- dust! Now they're all... (sees Christina approaching) know-it-all-E.S.P.N. analysts.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Hi, Tony... We better get going, Mom. It's getting late. Margaret rises, handing the ring to D'Amato.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes it is... (to Tony) --. too late. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Christina wants to connect with Tony as he toys with his ring.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: ... I remember when my dad designed that... (an awkward silence) I guess I'll have to wear mine on a chain around my neck, huh?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: How ‘bout you win one first?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: I was just trying to --

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (getting up) No. Win one first. He walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie and Vanessa are fighting, tension in the air. The TV is ON to the Jack Rose's "Sports Center" as Willie tries to analyze his playbook, an icebag wrapped tight around his right shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYBOOK
dialogues.text: Shows the complexity of the system, the number of plays, the mumbo-jumbo, which would be tough enough for any student of the game to learn -- but for Willie, who is unschooled, it comes hard; his frustration mounting, as is Vanessa's.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: (volatile) ... were you embarrassed by me, were you ashamed to introduce me to the Mayor? Is that it... Willie? (as he doesn't respond) Was it my dress...? ... what the... Willie?! Willie changes the subject, indicating the playbook. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ON TV
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, his guest. 100. 138

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Goddamn book! Thinking is dying on that field. Doing is feeling. Feeling is what it's all about... (flipping pages) I think like this, I'll get killed out there! I gotta play my way -- like 'I'm the shit'! You don't believe that, you are...

dialogues.speaker: A138
dialogues.text: the deranged Jack Rose is going on and on to

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... At his press conference yesterday -- and with a straight face -- Coach D. says that there was no problem with the plays and that Beamen audibled only twice during the game. Uh-huh!... We all know Tony the Tiger's a demonic dude who combs his hair every which way but up, but I tell ya this guy could put a positive spin on toxic waste. Is he for real? Or is it just me who feels he was probably coaching the day Ray Nitschke dislocated Y.A. Tittle's shoulder? Scary? You starting to get the picture here, Joe?... 138

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: -+. You're ‘the shit' all right, Willie, lemme tell you joined a whole lotta shits on that team! Did you see the way that Cindy Rooney talked to me? Was my dress too cheap? Did you give a shit!... She just about made me feel like a field hand! Who the hell does she think she is!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: What's her ass gotta do with your ass? Jealousy look ugly on you, Vanessa. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: (stung) Oh? What was I so jealous of her about?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I tell you what -- you're jealous of anything! You're jealous any woman who walk in a room with a better rap or a bag or a fuckin' hairdo! ‘Cause it's always ‘bout class with you.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Class!? You're talking shit! I got more class than 90 percent of those skinny wrinkled bitches in that bullshit party of yours!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Sure you do...

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Bad Ass Willie! I seen you in action tonight, chasing the tail on that Heather Sanderson. (as he protests) Why didn't you introduce her to the goddamn Mayor, Willie, you too ashamed to introduce me... (near tears) ... after all these years! Goddamn your ass, Willie Beamen...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Baby, I wasn't even thinkin’ about the Mayor. And I don't care about any of those crackhead hoes! I got one thing on my mind and one thing alone! I gotta concentrate on the game or I ain't gonna be around too much longer, ya hear! It's my shot, baby, I've gotta grab these chips while I can.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: So whatcha really saying, ‘baby' -- I don't look so good to you anymore? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: bedroom. 102.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: No, you ain't listening, you... I'm sayin' this is my time -- now! I gotta rope the ring and that means I can't be fucking dealing with you running these bullshit numbers in my head.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: No! What you mean is I'm not good enough for you, Willie, that's what you mean!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: There you go again! Man, for a college graduate you are plumb dumb! '‘'V,' you got so many damned problems, you gotta blame everybody else but yourself -- Cindy Rooney, Heather Sanderson, me! Baby, you gotta learn to chill!

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: (infuriated) ‘Chill'!? Jesus Christ, Willie, you know when you get finished sucking your own dick and playin' ‘bad ass football nigger,' give me a call sometime?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (blowing up) You mean your ex-fiance give you a call! You wanna come at me now! When I'm facing this... (hits the playbook) Get the fuck outta here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie stands, slams the playbook shut, stalks to his She tries to grab him and they struggle.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Watcha want!... Don't touch my arm like that or I'll bust your ass!

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: You gonna hit me? Oh it's like that now? Yeah! Go ahead -- get real, motherfucker!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: ‘Real'!? Gimme a break! Lemme the fuck alone! (AD LIB) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: I see you turning into one of them ‘shits'! I tell you this, I'm gonna call your mama! Willie looks at her, disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Tell my mother what! Don't let my success get to your head, bitch. (as she protests, "bitch!") Go right ahead! And while you're at it, go find yourself some ‘wigger' who'll put up with your petty, ‘educated’ hype, ‘cause you gettin' on my nerves!

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Yes I am educated and you can't even read a goddamn playbook, Willie Beamen, ‘cause you're nothing but a big-ass Mama's boy and you can take your football -- it's the only ball you got anyhow! -- and shove it up your stuck-up ass! ‘Cause my big, beautiful ass you can kiss good-bye, baby! (at the door) And you know what! -- I will find me a smart, m'fucking gentleman! I'm gonna be sleeping at Darlene's from now on. She might fuck better'n you anyhow!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: You got an ugly mouth on you, woman! I'm real glad I gotta chance to see it ‘fore our kids heard it. Get your lesbian ass outta here! She slams the door violently on her way out... Willie is really upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'Amato wanders back from the first-class section through the aircraft. Some nap, others mingle in a subdued atmosphere. He spots Willie sitting near the back of the players' section by himself, wearing his headphones. He approaches, waits. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Willie finally sees him, or pretends to, takes his headset off, clears his CDs from the empty seat.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Mind if I sit down? (as Willie nods, Tony sits) Whatcha listening to?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Rap.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Anyone I know?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Biggie.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Y'ever listen to jazz? (as Willie shrugs "who?") .-. Coltrane, Monk, Miles Davis, Billie Holiday?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (doesn't know them) Don't go much for that old stuff.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Maybe I'll put together a tape for you -- my favorites...?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I don't use no tapes. I got CDs.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: So, we'll forget about that... How ‘bout your mama, she ever gonna come to a game?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: .+. She thinks Sunday's for church. He waits on Tony, who goes the extra yard.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: «+. I don't know if you know this, I lost my dad when I was young, too... (waits) -.. in World War Two... (waits again) ... if you ever want to talk about stuff like that, I'm around...? Okay. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I'll get at ‘cha.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You know where to find me... Willie nods, mumbling something incoherent.

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT SECTION 140
dialogues.text: D'Amato rejoins Dr. Mandrake, reading his Wall Street Journal.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Hell if I can figure him out.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Beamen. I look in his eyes and I see... nothing. (beat) Man never even heard of Miles Davis.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Tony, he probably never heard of Joe Namath. You look like shit. You sleeping?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I'm too tired to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: I got some great new samples for that.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I bet you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony, in his game suit, has breakfast with his son, TOM, a bland mid-level executive in his late 20s, with a Christian fish on his lapel.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: ... Really, it's no problem getting tickets? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (uneasy) Well, he's really more into basketball now.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (defeated) .»». Yeah? How old is Timmy now -- nine, ten?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Eight. But we don't really call him Timmy anymore...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Oh, okay... and Melinda? How's she?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: She's fine...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You look good.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I'm trying.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You talk to your mom lately?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Dad -- what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What do I want? I wanted to see you. You're my son, for chrissake. What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I haven't talked to you for a year. A year ago Christmas...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: +. Christ, gimme a minute, Tom, okay? I haven't seen you in what...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Six years.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You never picked up the phone either -- so don't... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Why would I?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: All I ever did was...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (on edge) Please don't!... When you do that you sound like a broken record, Dad. I get really upset... Tony looks at him, wondering what he's wrought. They hush as the WAITRESS brings coffee and danish. She leaves

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Coffee, danish? Why the long faces? (off no response) Enjoy your breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: «+. You know I'll never forget a big mistake I made once as a coach. I hurt someone and... I couldn't change what I did, so I denied it. Threw some money at it... and then tried to forget it, block it out. (beat) You know what? It never goes away.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (now he's upset) No it doesn't and it's too late, goddamn it, okay! It's too -- excuse me for my foul thoughts, Lord! They come not out of me -- but it's too goddamn late for that! My son and daughter are doing fine and you had nothing to do with that, and that's all there is.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Tom, come on, I... I'm sorry. I... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Where were you on my Sundays, when I was playing ball? Just... just don't even try, okay!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (now at the end of his rope)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I just... see them? They're my grandkids, Tom!... Please?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (a grim pause) +. With a child psychiatrist...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Game 3. Miami Sharks at California Crusaders.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: The Crusaders' wide receiver runs deep against the Miami DB, nearly catching a 50-yard pass at the Miami 5-yard line... A yellow penalty flag flies through the air.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Interference on Miami. That will hurt! A tight game here! Looks like a man's down now... At the line of scrimmage, it looks like the 'Shark' -- Luther Lavay!

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Tony is livid at REFEREE #1, not noticing Shark.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Where was the interference                        !... Do you realize... No!... You are giving away 45 yards! Get the replay! I'll trade you a time-out for it, you... ugh, ugh! REFEREE #2 trots by Tony, who jogs alongside, to get his attention. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Charlie, give me a goddamn break. I know this is L.A., I don't know nobody here, but give us a chance anyway! (indicating Referee #1) Where's that guy from? El Cajon, Hawthorne, Beverly Hills, what?

dialogues.speaker: REFEREE
dialogues.text: Get back in the coaching box... Tony shares his frustration with Cap Rooney, in street clothes for the game, and Crozier upstairs; Cherubini is relaying the signals to Willie on the field.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What can you do? What can you do? The system's fucked! I mean games are being decided by zebras in stripes. It's just not fair! (then) What the fuck is ‘fair' anyway? 144 Shark lies on the field, moaning. Mandrake, Powers and Trainer #1 test his joints.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Squeeze my fingers. (as Shark does so) Great! Do you know where we are?

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: (woozy) -+. I know it ain't Munchkinland.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Who we playing against?

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: Those ugly motherfuckers.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Who's your quarterback?

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: That pretty motherfucker. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Well you don't see me playing possum, do you, Shark? I think you can get up now.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: Fuck, this is embarrassing! Doc, don't let me pull a Willie Beamen. 110. 144 Powers and the Trainers help drag Shark to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: The crowd cheers for Shark, coming off, as..

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (at Monroe) What the hell is going on, Monty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're leaking and you don't know where. Fix it, goddamnit. Don't yell and don't make faces and all that bullshit! Just fix it! He leaves Monroe a study in total, betrayed frustration...

dialogues.speaker: HUDDLE
dialogues.text: Willie feels loose.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (singling out Sanderson) Okay, ‘'Sandman,' they should show cloud coverage here and lock Ice on the cross. The middle will be open. Right deuce gun, F-shoot, 60 Snake Eyes. On three. Ready!

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Hey, man, we can't run Snake Eyes in the red zone!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: J-man, you can get on my page or you can shut the fuck up! On three. Ready! They break. Sanderson hangs back a beat.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: How the hell you see that? 145 146 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I see things better, brother. I see the future. Your guy trailing you on your inside route. Bend a little and hit the slim post. As they move to the line of scrimmage, Madman is lost.

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: I block the outside backer? Les'... help me? McKENNA You got the nose guard.

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: Nose. Face. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Set Blue 468, Blue 468! Hut! Hut! Hut!

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Montezuma Monroe is rampaging up and down before his unit, pissed beyond words.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: They think you're a bunch of low- brow Neanderthal shitheads! They think they're gonna gut you and leave you lying on the highway with your insides hanging out for the buzzards -- !

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: (a huge migraine of his own) Coach, you're gonna have a stroke.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: I don't GET strokes, motherfucker, I GIVE ‘em! A cry of grief from the crowd stops him. Monroe spins to the field to see a mad brawl of players for a Shark fumble -- a Crusaders player comes up with the ball! And worse! At the line of scrimmage, Leslie McKenna, the right guard, is down.  112.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: As REFEREE #3 signals the California first down to a joyous echo from the home crowd, Tony is screaming at Referee #3 who jogs over to him.

dialogues.speaker: REFEREE
dialogues.text: (wearily) What is it with you, Coach?!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Goddamn it, Sammy, his knee was down! He was down by a mile. Both knees were down. Give me a goddamn break in this town -- that was no fumble!

dialogues.speaker: REFEREE
dialogues.text: To be honest, Tony -- I didn't really see it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (a beat, shrugs) To be honest, Sammy, neither did I. Referee #3 shakes his head and runs back to the field as Mandrake hurries over to Tony.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Tony -- bad news! Looks like McKenna's got a distended knee, torn everything, bloody nightmare -- he's out!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: How long?

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: If he's lucky -- Easter. Tony hurries towards Leslie McKenna in great pain -- being helped off the field by Dr. Powers and trainer #2.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Julian and Willie are going at it hotly.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: The play was Snake Eyes Right -- Right!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I knew the goddamn play! -- Couldn't you see them adjusting?! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: You didn't audible shit!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I called the color, man! You just missed it ‘cause of that wax in your ears. Hey, 'Sandman,' didn't I audible?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: I dunno, man. Don't get me involved. Tony approaches, dominates.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Knock it off -- all of you! This goddamn screw-up cost us McKenna for the season! Why don't you both think about that for one goddamn minute! Sit down -- the bunch of you! (walking away, to Crozier, on the headset ) Goddamn it, Nick, you do your job and get him under control before he gets anyone else hurt! He notices a film crew in his face, recording all of this; this brings him to the very edge.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Whatta you doing!! Get outta here before I kick your butts!!... Get ‘em out! Security quickly closes down the lens.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: The Crusaders sweep towards the Miami sideline, its big offensive line leading. This time the Miami defense penetrates them and gang-tackles the running back.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (to Monroe) Awright! More like it! You look alive! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He turns away, eyeing the scoreboard, as his offense runs out.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Thank you, boss.

dialogues.speaker: HUDDLE
dialogues.text: Willie suddenly breaks from it and pukes quietly, into the turf, clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh my God. He's done it again! (needling Kevin) You know, that reminds me of the night... Willie walks back to the huddle, to his teammates.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I apologize -- I had to get that out of my system.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Hey, man, if that's your thing, just stay off my shoes...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Okay. Let's go. Deuce Right Dog 90 Smoke. On three. Jimmy one, Andy two, J-man outlet flat.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: Right. Don't force it in if --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I_got it! I'mthere! I'ma righteous motherfucker! On three! Ready?

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: They break and move to the ball. Willie scans the defense, loose, enjoying himself. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Set Green 21! Green 21! Hut! Hut! Hut! Willie checks off his receivers as they speed downfield, pumps once; the offensive line protecting him strongly. Two L.A. corners blanket Sanderson -- but Julian is open, waiting in the flat.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Willie!! Willie ignores him, his eyes downfield -- a Crusaders' lineman is almost on him when Madman slams him aside at the last moment... Willie takes the shot -- it's a dead perfect pass, threading the microscopic gap between two Crusaders' defenders. Sanderson spins in midair so that the nose of the ball crosses the goal line just as he is slammed backwards by the backs -- too late -- the Ref's arms shoot up -- touchdown! Willie races down the field and grabs Sanderson, both of them breaking into a funky dance.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Upfield, Julian, not very happy, heads for the sideline.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
