dialogues.text: As Willie comes off, Tony hugs him in a familiar, paternal way, which surprises Willie. Cap Rooney witnesses.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Don't fuck with a man's ritual, right?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: ‘Blaze the hot sands.’

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I never understand a goddamn word you say.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: It's all good, boss.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Willie runs an option pass for 26 yards, and when he is pounded into the turf, jumps right up and taunts the defense.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: You_gotta hit harder than that, baby! I can't feel it! Which makes them want to kill him -- but Madman and several others step in to separate Willie.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Willie, pursued by linemen and almost off balance, throws an incredible long bomb, hitting his third receiver; the ball travels almost 60 yards in the air. The receiver runs it in for a touchdown!

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Wow! As the Sharks go into their bye week, the story here has got to be Willie Beamen! He's running -- he's throwing -- he's rockin' and rollin' and shuckin' and jivin'. He's flat out steamin'. This magic Sunday, he's 'Steamin' Beamen' !

dialogues.speaker: GUEST OWNER'S BOX
dialogues.text: Christina, with local friends, studies her new phenomenon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Shark locker room seems too small to contain the combustible energy of these larger-than-life men. Sanderson and other "Dawgs" rally to the BOOM BOX. Perhaps Willie joins in briefly... Coach D'Amato circulates, congratulations all around... Cap doesn't have much to do, hanging. In the b.g., the doctors and trainers are busy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Madman opens a locker which is a shrine to the band Metallica. Madman puts one of their CDs on a portable player.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: Oh, man, not that shit again!... I don't know why I even acknowledge this m'fucking psycho!

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: (to Shark) Metallica are gods! We live to serve them! We should bow! As the MUSIC of "SO WHAT" CRANKS, others protest loudly (AD LIB). Madman ignores them all, banging out the rhythm on his locker. Elsewhere, Smitty, the Christian, walks up to Willie.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: (coming up to Willie) Say, Willie, some of us guys, we have a little Bible study group that meets every Monday. It's no big deal, we just read some and talk. They say ‘There's no atheists in foxholes. (chuckles) We'd sure like it if you could join us?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: Oh super!... May I ask if you're a Christian?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Smitty.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTY
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: How long I been on this team -- six months? In all that time you ever spoke to me? Now I win two games and you want me to join your Bible study group? Fuck you. Smitty moves off...  118.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN WASHINGTON 157
dialogues.text: is throwing on his $3,000 suit, busy on his cell, while Willie watches nearby.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Forget Doritos! I can do Ruffles, too. One's a corn chip and the other's a potato chip, don't you get it? Tell them I got two different burger franchises and they don't give me no static like that!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie catches Julian before he exits.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Hey, J-man, can I talk to you a sec? (off no response) Say, good game today. You know if I'm faking the hand-off to you, it looks stupid you don't act like you're getting the ball, money...

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Whatcha you saying, you...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Y'ever see a movie? You know, there's the king, right? But he ain't no king till the other actors bow when he walk in the room, right? He's just this actor dude... same with us, J. I'm the Q.B., but you gotta act like I am the Q.B., you get it, ‘cause if you ain't pretending, it's a fake, it make me look like some dumb-ass turkey out there runnin' around trying to throw a pass they all know is comin’...

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Who you talkin' to, you afro m'fucker! You a king in your own mind, bitch! You out there ‘bowing' to settle your own bullshit, don't ever approach me again, faggot!!

dialogues.speaker: TRAINING AREA
dialogues.text: Dr. Mandrake stitches Sanderson's cut chin, pulling out a tray of bandages: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: (agitated) I gotta come down, Doc. My teeth are ice cubes, man!

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Try sex, you're making me look bad. League's already questioning my benzo prescriptions.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: Man, you're useless! What the fuck we need a doctor for then?

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: You don't! We're just corporate automatons anyway. No fault. No choice. No lawsuit. The way all society is going. It's you overpaid m'fuckers wrecked the party anyway -- ‘my body is worth 50 million in bones, muscle, and tissue, blah blah blah!' You prescribe some spoiled crybaby the wrong thing and you're on your way to re-education camp in Hanoi.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: Hanoi?

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Vietnam?... Never mind. Or is it New York now? Corporate culture, baby! I'm actually one of the few good guys left -- I stretch it a bit for you boneheads.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: (reacting to stitch) Ow!! You sure stretching this stitch, man!

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: (musing aloud) You have no idea what it was like in the old days, 'Sandman' -- nobody'd give a shit. I mean we were kings. No goddamn random urine tests, no ‘spook police’... (laughs) Shit we'd force you to take the pills -- like candy. You could walk onto the field with a syringe in your ass and nobody'd notice... but it's over -- like the weather. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: Weather?

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: El Nino!... Current change? Global warming?... Hello?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: You out of your mind.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: -+. All ‘cause the association's worth too much money -- now it's bigger than Coca-Cola or Disney... (as Sanderson is puzzled) Forget it. (re: the bandages) So what do you want -- Bugs Bunny, Daffy Duck, Tweety?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: You got Spiderman?

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: If I had Spiderman I woulda said I had Spiderman. I got Batman.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: (brightening up) Oooh, fox alert at 4 o'clock!... Daddy's girl ambulating... Queen Christina is here!

dialogues.speaker: LOCKER ROOM
dialogues.text: The mood in the locker room shifts quickly as Christina Pagniacci enters, escorted by two security guards in suits with earphones -- along with her VPs. In a good mood, she passes most of the no-name players, signalling or calling out to some of her stars (AD LIB)... Cap notices her not "seeing" him; Joe Polito makes up for it, coming over to him, as she approaches Willie.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (at her charming best) Willie, congratulations, you were great! Really exciting to watch out there!! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (a winning smile) I thrill to chill, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Two in a row! ‘Whatever it takes' -- right. You make me excited about the future again... Others look on at the two of them. Willie, in his jockstrap, is coming on to Christina ina cheeky, street way, showing off his muscles. Christina, accustomed to locker rooms and not seeing her players in any way as he doesn't competitive with her husband, ignores the fact add one stitch of clothing to his jock. Willie senses this gulf and will come to resent it as another synecdoche for the owner/player class structure.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (quietly) «+. I hope you don't mind, but you handle yourself real good in business and all. I don't B.S., Miss Pagniacci, but you do it to me. How'd you like to hook up for a drink, or something quiet...?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (a little surprised) .-. I'm flattered, Willie, I really am, but I'm married. I've just never dated players. It gives the wrong impression.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: You mean you're influenced by what other people think?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: I think we all are, in business, Willie... So, come by tomorrow and we'll talk. I think you'll like what you're gonna hear... okay? (smiles, corrects his punctuation) Pagniacci. She exits. Her eyes catching Tony, on the fly, through a cubicle window -- huddled with Rooney, Crozier, and Julian in the cramped visiting coach's office.  122.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: «+. Reebok got this whole ad campaign ready to go the minute I hit 2,000 yards. But it's ABC, man, I don't get the ball -- I don't get my stats -- I don't get my money -- and I like gettin' my money.

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: This team isn't about your damn stats!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: For that matter, you're lucky we're not keeping track of your blocking 'stats,' J...

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: What's that mean?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What's that mean? It means y'ever try blocking for a change, J? It's not that bad an idea...

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I'm sick of hearing that shit! I'm tryin', but blocking's for those Clydesdale horses, man. You don't use a thoroughbred to block. You run his ass.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: That's a winning attitude, kid.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: How much you payin' that 300-pound blocker, man? Let him block, ‘cause he sure can't run.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: (to Tony) ... Look, J-man's got a point -- Beamen's not doing his homework. He isn't studying the playbook, he doesn't come in to look at any films, he doesn't even know the damn names of the defensive players he's facing. He doesn't give a geewhiz about anything or anybody! He just wants to make the plays by himself -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: He's young! He doesn't know how to ‘read' like you do, Cap.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Fuck that! He's changing the plays, man -- all the goddamn time!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What? What do you mean he's changing the plays?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I said he's changing the plays -- in the huddle. The plays you designed that I loved. Just does what he likes.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: In the huddle?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I'm not talking audibles, Coach. Today he did it all day long. Kid's dissing this play, that play, saying, 'I gotta better play.'

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: Hey, guys, we won. What's the point here?! Tony's thinking about it.

dialogues.speaker: SHOWERS
dialogues.text: 161 Players dance to a BOOMBOX PLAYING in the shower... Madman tries to join in but looks ridiculous and they trash him cruelly. Willie showers next to Shark, who, unseen, seems to lose his balance, grabs onto a shower head...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (to Shark) So guess what? Coach suddenly asks me to dinner. Orders me morelike. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Hey, that means you made it, kid! When Coach D. thinks you're the real deal he brings you over to his house and shows you his trophies and shit and makes the most godawful jambalaya you ever tasted. One thing though, you better bring flowers -- Coach gets really pissed off if you don't bring flowers.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Flowers?

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: Some petunias or something. Trust me... When?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: That's cool, I'm having a bash at my place for bye week. Wife and kids are up North. Gonna be a lotta trim, so don't go bringin' no sand to the beach, dawg...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm a born again ladies man! Madman now retaliates, throwing a baby ALLIGATOR into the shower, the tiny reptile terrifying most of these behemoths with its HISSING jaws.

dialogues.speaker: LOCKER ROOM
dialogues.text: Cap Rooney catches Willie's eye as the latter throws on some frayed jeans, a beeper and cell phone hooked to his Adjusting his shades and headphones, he's about to leave when:

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: The thing about a team, kid, is you can try to lead ‘em. But will anyone follow? You don't play for the team, the team's not gonna play for you. Go out there on your own, you'll die out there on your own... 'kimmo sabe'? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Say, Cap, how old are you now? Willie rolls on out -- barely avoiding the press -- who gather around Shark. Shark, in his underwear, puts his sunglasses on, bothered by the camera lights.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK REPORTER
dialogues.text: Say, Shark, what were you thinking when you came out of that concussion?

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: What was I thinking? What're all these white guys doing standing around here looking at me, that's what I was thinking, what a dumb-ass question! Next? Which cracks up the reporters.

dialogues.speaker: TRAINER'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Cameras mounted, the room lit, Jack Rose has the first go at Tony, a tiny tape recorder in his palm.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: So what were you telling Beamen on the sideline, Coach?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (warily) I was telling him how much I loved him. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: ("friendly" smile) Follow-up question. You think your boys could've won the game without him, Coach?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Why is it every time you ask me a question, Jack, it sounds like, "so, did you beat your wife?' You goddamn know I don't have a wife, Jack, and you know I don't play golf and I hate fishing, barbecuing, and boating. I guess... wall-staring, I'm pretty good at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: You still didn't answer the question, Tony...? It's like a routine between them -- on the edge of danger.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No I didn't because I tell you what, this is what I got to say to you about the game, Jack: Fuck you, you stink, you know you stink, you wouldn't know the truth if it was in your own shit -- so go talk to one of these poor innocent schmuck kids you can misquote and destroy... Okay?! (loud, walking away) Hey, didn't we win! Didn't we beat L.A.! Two in a row! We're back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reporters are somewhat stunned by Tony's erratic behavior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Mandrake is exiting quickly, but Dr. Powers manages to catch up to him.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: (to Mandrake) «+. There's something wrong with Shark.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Wow! Brilliant deduction! Did you go to medical school for that?

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: He's having trouble focusing. His hand-eye coordination's deteriorating and his memory, when I...?

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: He's fucked up! They're all fucked up! Their job is getting fucked up! The crazier they get, the more the crowd likes them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: (undeterred) Harv, this is not professional wrestling. He needs a head M.R.I. and M.R.A. Mandrake stops.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: You're not even here six months, Allie! You're gonna order a 20 thousand dollar test for every nutcase on this team?

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: He could have a subdural hematoma, intracranial bleeding...

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Or he just could be a crazy fucker, okay! Listen, every Sunday these guys walk out onto that field, they only got one thing and one thing alone going for 'em -- their confidence! (beat) You start chipping away at that with a bunch of unnecessary testing and we can kiss the playoffs good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Who's ‘'we,' Harv?

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: ‘We'! The team! Heading into the playoffs, you... you innocent! Television income triples. Yes! Bonuses! B.M.W.s! '‘We,' -- the team, what's wrong with that?! Mandrake, agitated, resumes walking. Powers follows.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Are you saying I can't give Shark the tests?

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ!... I'll take care of it, I'll get you the results! (as Powers starts to object) I've earned their trust, Allie. You haven't. Good night.  165 166

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madman now walks out, wearing an upside-down jockstrap around his forehead. The waiting fans and miscellaneous REPORTERS love it, snapping pictures... Willie, following is surrounded and held back by a mob of fans and shouted questions, requests, photographs (AD LIBS). He tries to accommodate, but is overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: TUNNEL REPORTER
dialogues.text: Willie!... You got 100 yards rushing today, how ‘bout that?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (over the kids) Ain't it amazing how fast a human body can move when it's being chased by 4.6 raptors who weigh more'n my mama! They're laughing.

dialogues.speaker: TUNNEL REPORTER
dialogues.text: Hey, Willie! What's it feel like one day to be nobody, next day the whole world knows you? The question gives Willie pause. He fields it gracefully.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I was always a star, you just didn't know it. But who says it's ‘the whole world'? -- How important's football when two billion Chinese never even heard of it? He has a natural charm and the press seems to like him for now... Other players walk by, ignored -- Shark among them, with Monroe, spotting Willie.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: Baby, the sharks are in the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Set to a RAP SONG, "I'm Willie Beamen."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Met-Rx image tied to Willie appears on the side of a Miami bus as Willie exits a beautiful hotel, two babes in tow, and enters his shiny new yellow Suburban, accompanie by a new agent, Wayne Mercer. Pointing to the moving bus: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Y'see, while you're sleeping I'm working. There he goes! Bus boy!... Creamin' Beamen!... They can't help laughing at the hugeness of it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the SONG CONTINUES, our players fool around at a touch football game against a group of sexy beach girls. Goofing off, Willie -- the cynosure of many eyes -- suddenly pulls up, grimacing, his throwing shoulder cramping on him. He conceals the pain and continues on.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The flash and THROB of MEDICAL MACHINERY as Dr. Mandrake supervises Shark undergoing his MRI...

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: American women don't fuck 'cause they're too fucked up to begin with... (removing the comic book Shark's reading) We don't want to confuse your brains with Spawn's, now do we?

dialogues.speaker: ACTION
dialogues.text: In his state-of-the-art home gym, a sweating Cap Rooney is going through an intense workout -- fly- motions and windmills on a Swiss ball. A supervising, sleepy trainer #3 reads a magazine in the corner, as Cindy Rooney enters in a sexy nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Yo, Rocky, enough! You're gonna hurt yourself... Cap ignores her.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: You're gonna hurt yourself... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cap comes off the ball, checks his body fat and heart rate on an intricate sports computer showing him at 7.5 percent body fat.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: (finally) .+. kid's breathin' down my neck.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: (confused) He's not even close! You're the man. Cap looks at her hard, his look saying: He's closer than you think.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS ACTION
dialogues.text: Willie works out with a crew of powerful teammates... Later, he is still there, alone. His eyes burn into the wall-size mirrors with compulsive determination.

dialogues.speaker: ACTION
dialogues.text: Willie now shoots a "Met-Rx" commercial. He's ina bathing suit, body beautifully chiseled as girls by the dozen surround him... singing his own rap song.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (song TBD) ‘My name is Willie... Willie Beamen... an' I keep the ladies screamin', oh yeah!... creamin' for my semen. Say hey, I'm Willie Beamen! etc... As the SONG and MONTAGE #2 END AT...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coach D'Amato and the QB Coach watch Willie and Rooney throwing side-by-side. Cap is still feeling pain in his lower back and legs; his passes are off, and he realizes it; whereas Willie's passes are on the money, sometimes too much so. One bullet pass bounces out of Sanderson's gut, burning his fingers, cursing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (to Willie) .-. less on the ball, Willie! You want a cool, tight spiral... and don't pat the ball, you...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Tight as fish pussy, Coach. ‘I'm the man'!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: ‘You're the man.’ I repeat, don't pat the ball so much. They can see it! (to QB Coach) What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Said I'm as tight-ass cool as the other side of my pillow, Coach... Tony shakes his head as Willie this time completes a hard, precise spiral to his tight end.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (to QB Coach) I need an interpreter... Awright, Cap, sit it out.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You got the balls, we all know that -- now take a rest. Rooney, pissed, moves to the sidelines, Tony, sensing his unrest, follows... as Christina, keeping an eye on her ne star, arrives with Willie's agent in tow...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What do you want! You're off, but...

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Hey, I've been on for twelve years and two rings, gimme a break. I've played hurt before. No big deal.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: We're gonna go with Willie against the Emperors... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me?! Are you... (wants to swear) kidding me -- ?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Rock...

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: I'm ready to play, Tony! Goddamit!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Listen to me. I want you to rest up until the playoffs. It doesn't mean enough against the Emperors for you to risk...

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Home field advantage don't mean enough? Since when...?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: It's not the big one, Cap. We can win at home or on the road with you. You know it's the smart thing to do. And one thing you always were was smart, Cap -- smarter than you were dumb.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Is this how it starts, Tony? I know the way your mind works, man. ‘Rest up.' Let the kid take a few games. You were great, but time marches on, huh?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: That's not what I'm saying --

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: The heck it's not! I know the game of football! Cap walks away, crossing Willie on his way off the field. He slaps the back of his helmet hard.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Get all pretty for the cameras, poster boy!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: What the -- ?! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: ... They love you today but a season's 16 games, kid. It's how you live through the bad ones that makes you a quarterback, not a punk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandrake walks alongside Christina, through an empty locker room. Mandrake,

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: «+. the bottom line is Rooney's some kind of medical miracle. He really could be ready for New York.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: You told anyone, Harvey? thinking she would be pleased, shakes his head, realizes what she's really thinking.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: -.. ‘Course he'd have to take a lot of pain and his ankle's not 100 percent. But he will. He's got the mind of an ox. He's so freaked about Beamen stealing his job, he'd probably play with a fractured neck.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Harvey... could you slow him down? Tell him he's not responding to rehab well enough -- just till the playoffs. Give Beamen his shot...?

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: (pause) Well... everyone knows herniated discs are 'iffy.' I could recommend...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (moves on) What about Shark?

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: He's still woozy, got bad migraines. Post-concussive syndrome. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Can you clear him?

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: (almost laughs) «+. you mean which shell is the real peanut under? (hesitates) Three concussions the last five months? There's no way to predict what another head-hit would do, Christina...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: How come Dallas had their quarterback practically in a coma last month just before he played one of the greatest games of his life...?

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: (backtracking) «+. Well no question he wants his tackle and sack bonus bad. Theoretically, his brain's at increased risk, but it's theoretical, and I can pump him full of cortisone to catch the swelling and let him finish out the season... without a malpractice suit of course -- (off her look) I'm joking. I don't really think anything's gonna happen... but I'm not a complete prick, you know, Christina, I do have some kind of conscience.

dialogues.speaker: A168 EXAM ROOM
dialogues.text: If she thinks so, Christina stays cool-eyed about it. They enter a small exam room.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: I'm not looking to screw him, Harvey. But I gotta have him in the playoffs -- and he wants to play for chrissake, so everyone comes out...

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: ... long term?... What are you thinking? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (a beat, eye to eye) I'm thinking we'll probably cut him in the off-season. The word's already out there, everyone's seen him take the hits. No one's gonna take him at his price... I think he'll be happy just to have his old job back at 30 percent of what he makes. That's if we want him back. (off Mandrake's waiting look) Dad always used to say, 'To make money, you got to spend money.' You do the math, Doctor. What you help save us we won't forget at contract time.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Smart man, Art. But you got him beat by a Miami mile, Christina... What do I tell Tony?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (exiting) Tell him what he needs to know. Shark can play. Cap can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony's in his kitchen when the DOORBELL RINGS, laboring over a pot of jambalaya, wearing an apron reading: "Kiss My Chef." A BILLIE HOLIDAY RECORDING PLAYS. He goes.

dialogues.speaker: AT FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Willie waits, carrying flowers.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Hi, got you flowers. He thrusts the flowers forward. Tony looks at them, a little taken aback; then takes them and shows Willie into the living room. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: For me? Thanks... I guess I better put these in water or something. Come on in. Tony goes to the kitchen, looking at the flowers. Willie now gets it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (to himself) Shark, you motherfucker! !

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Nice place.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You wanna beer?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony brings beers to Willie, glancing at Ben Hur on television; the irony slave ships and gladiators is not lost on Willie.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: The gladiators of their time... (to Tony) Cute apron.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (removing it) My ex-wife got it for me. It was a joke. I don't cook so great -- so don't expect anything too...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I'd be happy with a peanut butter and jelly sandwich. When'd you divorce her? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Almost twenty years now... (off silence) Same old story, she got fed up with me working so hard. You know where they served the divorce papers? On the sidelines of the divisional playoff game in New York.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (chuckles) That's cold.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Fuck her, we won the game.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: That's what it's all about.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You ready? Tony leads Willie into a dining room, Willie glancing around, noting many football photos that grace the walls.

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM 172
dialogues.text: Tony and Willie eat from two steaming plates of jambalaya

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: ++. My own recipe. Sort of adapted from Paul Prudhomme's. Ever been to his place in New Orleans?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (disguising his distaste) No.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Maybe get ‘em next season. Like no place on earth, New Orleans. How you like it?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Hot! It's terrific, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: .»». Well, thanks for coming by. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: You're going to yell at me, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No... no. I just wanted to talk... (a beat) Willie, look, if I've been an asshole I'm sorry. Cap going down was really tough for me and maybe I've been taking some of that out on you. I know you're still learning the system and the pressure's incredible --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I can handle it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I know. But we need to talk about this. I think you got a great future in football but first off we gotta deal with some basics. Like if the play book is too complicated we can simplify it for you --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Man, that book is too slow. When I am out there on the field I just gotta feel it. I can't be thinking about nothing but the juice. I got to let it out.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Listen, you're too fast out there as it is. You need to wait for the plays to develop. Our offense was built up over years, it's like Chinese water torture, taking apart the other team a little ata time, it's the death of 1,000 cuts.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I like things I guess a little more muscular, suits my style...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (stops eating) Is that why you been changing the plays? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I'm trying to read the defense, Coach, it's...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I'm not talking about audibles... Look, I know you like making the big plays. I understand that. But our game plans are the result of a lot of work and a lot of experience.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I know that --

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I know you do. When you change plays you're showing disrespect to a lot of people in this organization --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I don't mean to --

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: People who've worked for years in this club and around the League. People who've sacrificed more than you will ever know to be in this game. Willie sees where this is going.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I'm trying to win, Coach! I been warming the bench ever since I got to the pros, and I don't plan on going back there. I don't wanna disrespect nobody but... winning is the only thing I respect. Tony looks at Willie with a singular, quiet intensity.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Okay, son, listen to me very carefully and remember what I'm going to tell you. You can forget every other goddamn thing I ever said if you remember this, because someday you're going to realize it's the truest thing you ever heard: This game has got to be about more than winning. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie says nothing. Tony takes

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (relaxes a little) «+. I guess that's what I wanted to say. You're part of something here! A tradition. Lombardi, Unitas, Tittle, Sammy Baugh, hundreds of great players! Those men on the wall, you're part of that now. And along the way I want you to cherish that... ‘cause when it's gone, it's gone forever, and...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: You know, I look at all these pictures and trophies and stuff and it just makes me... sad. Like the room is full of ghosts. When I'm done with the game, or the game is done with me, I don't wanna be no ghost up on a wall. I want more'n that. a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: «+. Looks like Cap's gonna make it back in time for the playoffs... I'm gonna start him.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (long icy pause) Yeah, I figgered. That's why I'm here, right? I knew you was gonna sell me out.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Cap's a leader... a team player. You need a team to win in the playoffs.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Bullshit! He's not half the athlete I am! Look me in the eye, Coach, and tell me Cap's the better player...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Cap's the better player. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (derisively) Sure! I guess that was another guy winning the last two games. I put points on the board! He lost four in a row. I lead by doing!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You kicked ass, kid, but Cap Rooney has been ‘doing’ it for years and he goddamn deserves his day in the sun, so don't start...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: And I deserve the bench, right?!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: «+. He's been the quarterback of this team as long as...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: And his time is over! And yours is too... ‘less you start taking some risks! Start playing the game the way it is now. It ain't all those pictures on the wall anymore --

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (seething) I've lived this game for three decades, kid, I know football. Those men --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Wanted to win -- just like you do! You can feed the press and the fans all that ‘sacrifice and glory, grand ol' man of the game' crap! You sell it good, everyone bought it. But I been there, Coach, I seen a long line of guys like you from college on with that bullshit halftime speech!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (furious) It's bullshit, huh! You think you... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, it is! And you know it is! ‘Cause it's really about money. Rakin' in the TV contracts, fat- cat boosters sittin' in their skyboxes and coaches uppin' their salaries, all of ‘em looking for the next black stud to get ‘em in the Top Ten, put ‘em in the bowl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: games -- It's just like the pros, ‘cept in the pros, the field hands get paid...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Don't play the race card with me, kid. Twenty-five years I've worked with men of your color. You're good because you're different, not because...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Maybe it's not racism, maybe it's placism, but the black man still gotta know his place, right, Coach?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What are you saying? You don't trust anybody ‘cause of what happened to you in college? You knew the rules, Willie, you broke ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Broke 'em?! How'd I break ‘em?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You broke ‘em. That's how you broke, ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Man, I lost a million-dollar signing bonus ‘cause a booster gave me a three-hundred-dollar suit to go to his kid's wedding. I didn't even know the guy. Hell, everybody was getting something! How's a black man supposed to get through college when he don't got the money to get clothes, go on a date? They all had their hands out but it was me they suspended. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I dropped six rounds in the draft ‘cause of that. And the coaches rapping me ‘troublemaker,’ ‘arrogant, ' ‘won't play ball,' all that corporate shit they hit the brothers with when they won't kiss the money. Shit, I coulda made millions of dollars if I'd kissed that big ass Julian's kissing all the time. You talk about 'sacrifice'? I sacrificed about ten million dollars is what I sacrificed, ‘cause of those dumb rednecks like your coach friend at San Diego who makes me corner back ‘cause I got fast feet! It was him separated my shoulder, fucked up my throwin' arm tackling some 250-pound bullmother. I was a great football player but nobody gave me the time of day or the season I needed to heal that shoulder. They traded me right outta there!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Blame anybody but yourself, Willie! yY'see, that's what a leader is about, the times he's gotta sacrifice because he has to lead by example, not by fear or...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (challenged) Fear?! Who you talking to?! I hung in there when nobody gave a shit about me. I rode the bench for five fucking years! And now I get my one lousy shot, I'm 26 years old -- half my football life is over -- and now you tell me ‘You go on back to the bench, son. ‘Cause you gotta sacrifice for the greater glory of Cap Rooney.’ Well, fuck you, Coach! I'm not buying that brand, ‘cause you're some scared old man who won't let me play my way ‘cause I might just win! And then what the fuck was your life all about?! Tony fights to control himself. Outside, the evening crawls through the twilight. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (quietly) You're not some flash-in-the-pan

172 receiver or corner back or even Julian Washington, kid, you're a goddamn quarterback! You know what that means? It's the top spot, kid, the guy that takes the fall, the guy who everybody's looking at first, the leader of a team, who will break their ribs and noses and necks for you ‘cause they believe! ‘Cause you make ‘em believe! That's a quarterback.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (caustic, overlapping) Yeah, I'm the leader of your team till Cap's back up! Then I'm back on the bench. Shit, you ain't said two words to me all season ‘til Cherubini went down -- then it was...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating D'Amato) ‘Son, just pretend you're throwing a pass on the street in the ‘hood and your mama's ringing the dinner bell' -- all you done is talked at me, man, never listened to a goddamned thing I said! So don't have no coronary ‘cause I'm gonna stay who I am -- 'Steamin' Willie Beamen'! ‘Cause with the time I got left I'm gonna play my way and I'm gonna get my dollars up there so's when you motherfuckers trade me, waive me, injure reserve me, or whatever the fuck you do to me, I'm gonna be worth ten times what I was worth before! A long pause. Tony's eyes, moving past ego, scrambling to understand.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I don't know... you are a very, very young man. And you are very, very stupid.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Tell me I'm wrong. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You're wrong. I know better than you think, Willie...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: You don't know one thing about me... You couldn't even begin to imagine me. He leaves Tony -- drained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valet parkers attend to the numerous expensive cars and limos that pull into a circular driveway, unloading beautiful laughing women and exuberant football players.. Willie drives his Suburban right up onto the front lawn, enraging the valets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie is met with a ferocious explosion of MUSIC and mayhem; players dance and drink and pursue the opposite sex through the house... Shark bounces up to him:

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: Make yourself at home in 'The Pit,' Dawg! Blowjobs upstairs. But if you want to hit the skins, trawl the beach. Whatever you do, don't mess up my sheets, cause my old lady's comin’ back Tuesday and she gonna kick my butt she see any semen or blood round here!! In a lively mood, Shark stumbles off. Willie makes his way through a packed living room... women immediately perk when they see him, whispering, some predatory...

dialogues.speaker: ACTION
dialogues.text: Willie gravitates to Washington, Sanderson, a few others: The dialogue is fast, overlapping.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: What up, Willie B?! Coach give you the Vince Lombardi speech? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: He's in my face like I lost the goddamn game! Mother...

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: Told you! Hey, he's having a shit year, what do you...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: You know straight up we'd be top dog this season if the defense would step up --

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Hey, lay off the D, man. Shark hear that shit he'll tear you a new asshole.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: You think I give a fuck! Hey, I wanna win games, not kiss some overrated loser's ass. But what do you care anyway, J? You ain't playin' for this team. You playing for yourself, like everybody else round here...

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Who you talking about, punk?! Watch that mouth of yours or I'll kick your fucking ass! You gotta earn the right to diss someone on this team, boy!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Team? Shit. All I see of this team is a bunch of rich superfly brothers tripping in this white man's world, driving their BMW, getting their dicks sucked by 100 dollar hair jobs... and the clock's running and no one's giving a shit ‘cause they're all dying inside... You were a great athlete, J, but you become a_joke! You're playing, but it's like you're dying inside. Willie walks off -- his thoughts contradicting what he said at Tony's place; a troubled man, his confusion brewing to the surface. Julian, on the other hand, is a furious man, restrained by Sanderson and the others. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: What the fuck you mean ‘dying inside'?! Kiss my Armani ass, m'fucker! Talking to me like that! Who the... does this nigra know WHO I AM?! What I done for this team?! I'm gonna kill you, motherfucker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the hot tub, players are cavorting with the women, and Shark is telling stories, as Powers listens in.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: -.. So then Madman loses it -- starts reaming this guy out and then decides this hotel has GOT TO DIE! Stomps into the hall, grabs a fire ax and starts chopping through the wall. By now Styne, he grabs him, he's about to eliminate Madman right then and there, so I gotta jump in, I got to protect my baby, be the hero and save the fuckin' guy, when whap! thwack! Styne throws two quick punches that weigh about 150 pounds each and nails me right in the fucking head! Cracks my fucking skull! Check it out... (indicates his temple area) ... Bitch! From then on, guess what? Styne and Madman are like this dynamic evil duo who...

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: (interrupting) He cracked your skull?

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: Yeah. So those two sonofabitches decide they're gonna rule the world...

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Hold on, Shark. He actually cracked your skull? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: Yeah, Doc. I hate when that shit happens... So now we got these two locos on the offensive line and Coach D'Amato is about ready to call an exorcist when... Dr. Powers, disturbed, leaves without being noticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dozen beauties are lined up at the giant mirror, making themselves up, "doing blow," chatting, gossiping...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian, still angry, slides up to Shark.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Beamen disrespecting you, talking shit about you and the D...

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me? Are you fucking kidding me?! He goes after my D, I'm gonna break him off!

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Motherfucker punkin' every damn one of us. We need to smack the m' fucker! Shark thinks a beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: What's that motherfucker drive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAY FIELDS, former star linebacker, now using a set of canes, approaches, Crozier, talking to Willie. Fields' wizened face and eyes are a little too desperate for attention. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FIELDS
dialogues.text: Hey, Nick. How's it hanging?

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: Young and hung, Ray.

dialogues.speaker: FIELDS
dialogues.text: Steamin'! My man -- lookin' good. Does my heart proud to see a young brother in the pocket.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (interrupted, doesn't know him) Havin' fun, baby.

dialogues.speaker: FIELDS
dialogues.text: (checking out Willie's chick) Yeah, yeah, havin' fun. I hear ya. Say, Nick, I was meaning to talk to you ‘bout some new plays I got --

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: Not now, Ray. It's party time, okay? Willie notices the dominant Pantheon Cup ring on Fields' hand.

dialogues.speaker: FIELDS
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah -- party time, uh huh -- not the right time... (catching Willie's eye) Yeah, Pantheon Cup twice -- '79, "81. Fields emits a strange, oxen-like laughter -- they split looks, Willie horrified; Fields knows it, refers to his emaciated fingers.

dialogues.speaker: FIELDS
dialogues.text: Gotta get a chain for this one, try to buy 'em off me all the time. Had to sell one of ‘em, but no way I was gonna let this sucker go. Without this, shit! You wouldn't even know who the fuck I was, now would you? I been there, Willie. Done that. You ‘steamin'' now but this is one dance they all play the same last song... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: Hey, Ray, give it a rest, willya -- enjoy the party. It's his time... You had your time, it's his time.

dialogues.speaker: FIELDS
dialogues.text: Sure, Nick, but you a coach -- (pointed) If you ain't helping him, you're hurtin' him... (to Willie) Don't bull with the shit, righteous, there's plenty of it. (again that humongous laughter) Ha ha ha ha! (high fives) Stay cool, little brother...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (gives it back) You too, Ray... His eyes burning like candles, Ray shifts his intense, almost blind gaze off Willie, and staggers back into the chaos of MUSIC and flesh on his canes.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: That really Ray Fields?

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: Used to be Ray Fields.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Man! I watched him on TV growing up. Every Sunday. Like Tarzan. He was huge!

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: Yeah. Like he said, he was just too long at the dance. Like the rest of ‘em... Thank God, those days are over...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: He give you plays?

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: (shrugs, dismissive) -+. I humor him. Gives him something to do. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Guy took a lotta hits -- lost everything to booze, painkillers -- his family, all his money, typical shit... was out on the street for a while, then the press got hold of it and management gave him a few bucks. He gets by... Don't get down, Willie... I'm pushing real hard for another OT or pulling guard in the draft. Moved, Willie's eyes remain on Fields, talking to someone else; he's also rethinking Crozier's attitude towards the players.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I like it, sounds like some big changes coming next year, Coach. Maybe you be stepping up... Washington strolls up to him.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Say, Willie, that your 4 xX 4 outside?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: You mean my Sub? What's up?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Well, it's more like a 4 X 3 now. Smiling, he strolls back out the front door. A beat. Willie follows fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LOUD, GRINDING, BUZZING sound. Partygoers are assembled. Shark bestrides Willie's Suburban with an enormous CHAIN SAW in his hands, literally SAWING the VEHICLE in two halves. Sparks shoot out, upholstery, plastic, and metal fly... Willie can't believe, then rushes Shark, wanting to kill him! (AD LIBS)... but others jump him; it takes several strong players to restrain him. The car now tears open at a jagged angle. Shark TURNS OFF the CHAIN SAW, removes his safety goggles... to Willie: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: Kid, in football you got an offense... (jumping down, points to the severed front of the car) And you got a defense... (indicates the back half) You don't got one without the other, do you...? Respect will be paid. Now call this m'fucker a cab and get him the fuck outta my house!
Tony sits with Monroe at his favored sports bar. Monroe is drunk.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: «+. I just can't get through. Used to be I could take anyone -- rookie, vet, bad-ass parolee -- didn't matter -- I could make them... see what I see.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: (more revealing than usual) It's a new world, Tony! In my day we were just happy to have the goddamned job. I shoveled liquor in the off-season, used cars, insurance. Some guys used to wrassle... Now, shit -- Prima dawgs! Bodies are year-round great but break like china! Mandy, the young beautiful woman who approached Tony previously, enters with a friend. Monty.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: TV... It changed the way we think -- forever. First time they stopped the game because they had to cut to a commercial was the end of it. I mean it was our concentration that fucking mattered, not some fruitcake selling insurance... Tony notices, as does (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: «+. Getting those big salaries, the bonuses, these rooks come in here thinking they deserve respect before they play a goddamn down --

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (passionate) Damnit, Monty, I don't know what more I can do. I've sweated blood for these men. I've given up my wife and my children for these men. I've given up everything I have to be on that sideline every Sunday. Everything! The game is all that matters to me. ‘Cause it's pure! Four quarters. You cross a line, you score. It's sane. Life isn't, it isn't... It doesn't make sense for me not to have a home, a life... you tolerate the madness for the game... but if that's not enough, then this game is asking for too goddamn much!

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: It always did, Tony... I coulda held on another two, three seasons. But one day in Chicago, the wind was blowin' off the lake -- man was it cold! I cracked my head right up against that frozen turf, and I knew -- right then -- I wasn't gonna do this anymore.. shit, it wasn't any fucking fun! -- You gotta know when to get out, Tony. ‘Fore it takes your soul.

dialogues.speaker: A180
dialogues.text: Willie's commercial explodes over the bar, with LOUD MUSIC -- stylish, slick, sexy.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: -- Speaking of the devil!

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE 180
dialogues.text: They watch for a moment, then Monroe drains his beer.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Gotta get out of here... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He goes. Mandy.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Come on, Monty, one more.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Can't, Tony. Lady's got a curfew out on me.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (snorts) Curfew! How the hell do you and Sheila do it anyway?

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Well, we came to an agreement early on. All day long I live, breathe, and shit football. The moment I come home, I live, breathe, and shit family.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) +. It's impossible!

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: (rises) Hey, who the hell wants to think about blitzes and crossblocks when you're holding your grandkids in your arms...? (pointed) You gonna miss your boss embarrassing you in front of your players? (as Tony doesn't acknowledge this memory ) That's why I want to coach high school, it's back to basics, the kids don't want nothing but to play. Like you say, it's pure... See you tomorrow, my friend... Tony sits for a moment, and then glances at

dialogues.speaker: D'AMATO'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Tony gazes at one of three wall TV's; Mandy on an exercise bike in the corner, semi-naked in his pajamas. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: ... So Jeanette was 20, 21, I was just making it as a lowball assistant with San Diego -- Jock Harris was running the place then -- and one day we been romancing a year about and I says to her, 'So what about marriage?' And she says, ‘What about it?' And I says to her, ‘Well, I gotta see you backpedal first.' And she says...

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: Backpedal?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You know. Quarterback gotta be able to drop back -- ? Run backwards? You shoulda seen Jeanette's face. She gets up -- bless her Albanian soul! And she does it! She backpedals for me. In high beautiful heels too! All the way! Jeanette! Can you do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: it? Don't try -- I'll marry ya!

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: (crossing to bed) Your genes, her genes... did you get a quarterback out of it?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Nah. Not even close. I had an insurance executive. (as they both laugh) How can you have one of them? Came out with a briefcase. (beat) .-. Nah, he's a beautiful kid.

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: (props herself over Tony) You know what you need?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: ... yeah, a pump.

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: You need to be... young again! She attacks him, tickling him all over. Like a boy, Tony giggles; it's been a long time since he'd been tickled.

dialogues.speaker: ON TV A181
dialogues.text: Willie, wearing gold chains and a new diamond stud earring, is being interviewed by Jack Rose on "Sports Corner."

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (on TV) «+. The coach in Houston didn't dig black quarterbacks too much, he was kind of a redneck dude... (laughs) Thought black people's brains were about the size of his dick (bleeped)... Then at San Diego -- that coach was a real genius -- he makes me into a corner ‘cause he says I got fast feet... (a bitter edge to his laughter) Then I got injured and that screwed up that year. By the time I got to Oakland my third year, they didn't know what the fuck (bleeped) I was!

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (on TV) Sounds like ‘a conspiracy,’ Willie! Are you saying black people are being dissed here?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) ‘Conspiracy'? (laughs) Man, you is media-believing. Just let the facts speak for themselves, Jack -- 70 percent of the League is Afro-American and how many black head coaches? A few. How many black owners? Zero. You do the math, my man... But I ain't bitchin'. Fair's not what I'm looking for. ‘Cause nothing's 'fair' in this here life.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Come on, kid! It's a free country! Black dudes can buy teams. You have the green, you can buy a team. Black, white, or inbetween. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Football teams are corporations, Jack, but black kids are raised to be individuals, stars -- they don't learn to work together...

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE 181
dialogues.text: Tony, made happy by Mandy, gets out of bed, puts a robe on with his name emblazoned, like a fighter's, on the back, about to turn off the TV.

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: Leave him on. He's cool.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (mocking) ‘Cool'? My quarterback? He thinks he's Joe Montana already.

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: I like him. He doesn't buy into the bullshit... I like his eyes. He's sure of himself -- makes him sexy. Tony looks at Willie, wondering. Being with someone as young as Mandy permits him to understand. He pulls a blank check from his robe.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Thank God I'm old. Check alright?

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: (laughs) Is it good? Prefer credit card or cash, but this one time -- okay...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (filing it out) You want a nightcap or something?

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: (starting to dress) No, I don't think so, but thanks...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: How 'bout some coffee then?... Just stay for some coffee. Five minutes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: (senses his need) Okay. Coffee'd be great. He goes as she continues to dress, watching.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: «+. I like looking downfield, Jack. I'ma big play guy. That's what the fans want. Sometimes the old timers like 'Coach Stone Age,' they don't go for that, but the scoreboard don't lie, Jack...

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ‘Coach Stone Age'?, that's terrific!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That's my little nickname. Don't mean no disrespect to the man, but to me it's all about winning. That's what this country's all about. Being number one. Every kid can grow up to be President, right? Who the hell wants to grow up to be Vice-President? There ain't no number two in football. You tell me who lost the Pantheon Cup last year? You tell me who came in second in the 100 at the Olympics? Where I come from you're number one or you ain't shit (bleeped)! This country was built on kicking immigrant ass. African ass, Chinese ass -- don't- Matter-who ass. Only reason I made it out of Dallas is I wanted it more than the other guy. There ain't no grey area! Either you make it and get the big car and the nice home or you're on the bus and in the funeral home, ‘cause losin' is dying!

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: -+. But ‘Coach Stone Age,' you smack me! So truthful, brother... Gimme a pound. He tries to high five Willie, who doesn't respond... Meanwhile,

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: Tony crosses back with the coffee. 183  159.

dialogues.speaker: TONY'S BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Mandy is on a cell phone to her service (AD LIB), brushing her hair, closing the phone as Tony enters.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I hope you like cream with your coffee... Mandy...? I like you. I'm wondering if we could maybe make this a more regular thing?

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: Sure. I've got a few clients like that. We can book a regular time. I'll give you my service number and they can set it up direct with... Writing...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I sort of meant... not like that. Without money.

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: Oh, honey...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I know, but --

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: You don't really wanna do this.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I really like you.

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: I like you too, Tony, but you really don't want to do this. A beat. She gives him her business number in lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You got pretty hair, you know... Tony lingers for a moment, then sets his coffee down and leaves. Mandy watches after him in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: TONY'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Tony crosses OUT past: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: No doubt you're chewing up the gridiron, but on the sidelines it seems like you and Julian Washington got pretty heated during the Texas game?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No, J-man and me are just fine. I'1l bet you a hundred bucks and that ugly tie that he'll have another 2,000-yard season.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanderson talks on a cell phone, feeding the numerous sharks in J-Man's specially-designed pools, as he heads inside, accompanied by a frightened beauty... At the party, there are no men -- only some 20 beautiful women, most in lingerie, dancing and making out among themselves

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upstairs, at the controls is Julian, propped on his bed, with several more girls, watching Willie on TV coolly.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Not without getting the ball, you lying prick!

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: -.. But isn't this an awesome Emperor pass rush coming up Sunday? I mean these guys don't need much of an invitation to eat the greenery? Is there fear there?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Jack, I told you, they ain't gonna touch me, ain't gonna see me, ain't gonna smell me. Don't matter if it's T-Rex or Terminator out there, I'll just turn on the invisible juice and steam right by ‘em!  185 186 187 161.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Willie, you are indefatigable! Madman, on his cell phone, is heated as he watches the TV, amid an atmosphere of CRYING BABIES, BARKING PIT BULLS, and a pregnant, miserable wife.

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: You selfish asshole! If you don't think you're gonna get touched, I'm dancin' on a moonbeam!

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (in closing) «+. Well good luck to you, ‘Steamin' Willie Beamen' -- what a great young kid!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Game 4. New York Emperors at Miami Sharks.)

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Willie goes smashing into the mud, taking the hit on his throwing shoulder. A painful sack, he drags himself up... Dazed, Willie goes after the linebacker who nailed him... The 49er players sprint over to protect their teammate, but the Shark team does nothing to help their QB.

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Welcome back to the Monsoon Bowl, folks! The Emperors have been eating Shark patties all night long. Smashmouth football -- this is what it's all about! On the way to the huddle, over the DRIVING sound of RAIN.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Can I get some fuckin' protection here! If you're not going to block -- could you at least stay the fuck out of my way?! Madman goes for him, Sanderson and the others holding him back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: Loudmouth, showboating, MOTHERFUCKER! Where's your steam now?

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Coach D'Amato glares at the field, the rain pouring over his face.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (to line coach) Get_'em to stand up and block, goddamnit, Hank! What's going on?!

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: As the Emperor offense sets up, Shark urgently calls for a defensive realignment -- Miami players hustle for new positions -- the veteran Emperor QB sees this and quickly barks out an audible -- A quick handoff -- the Emperor running back shoots through a hole in the confused Miami defense -- Shark tries to make the diving tackle but his knee gives and he goes facedown in the mud, as the running back splashes right past him for 25 yards. Touchdown!

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What is with the Miami D of late? They are going belly up, fins flapping. Glug-glug-glug!

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Shark Lavay just can't find the old magic down there. The running back turns back to the downed Shark and his D, and points his fingers like a gun -- Bang! Bang! Bang! The trainer and doctors run out to Shark, grabbing his knee in fierce pain.

dialogues.speaker: HUDDLE
dialogues.text: Willie, reading a signal from Cherubini on the sideline, takes the team on with a dead stare.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Y'all want to make it tough okay, I can take it, m'fucker! ‘Cause I know come contract time there gonna be some big changes round here -- and, baby, it's either gonna be you or me! The call is Twins Right 90 Ringo Slide. On one! Ready!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (yelling over the RAIN) Set! Black 671, Black 671! Hut! Willie splashes back through the mud to pass -- an Emperor defensive end slips through full speed -- Willie is blindsided, his helmet goes flying off, he crashes to the turf, his face slammed once more into the mud.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: D'Amato is wholly demoralized, can't look... Neither can Cap Rooney, now in uniform, recognizing something he'd rather not. Or something he'd perhaps forgotten -- the sheer, frightening violence and impossibility of the QB position.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: They won't play for him, Tony. Tony looks at him, frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (walks away) Then let him fucking learn!

dialogues.speaker: OWNER'S BOX
dialogues.text: The visiting Mayor Smalls shares his feelings with Christina. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR SMALLS
dialogues.text: Shucks! There goes that black dynasty you been promising me, darling...

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Blood seeps down Willie's face from a scalp contusion as he pulls himself slowly to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... And there goes home field advantage for the Sharks! Although their season ends on a low note, there is still life after death. Two weeks from now, look for the underdog Sharks in the playoffs in 'Toughtown U.S.A.' -- Dallas, Texas -- football capital of the world -- on that fast astroturf that never forgets to break a bone or two!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The locker room is silent and depressed as players undress and shower.

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM/SHOWER
dialogues.text: Willie, dazed and steaming with anger, crosses Shark.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: You lead. But did anyone follow, nigga? Willie ignores him, but not Julian on his other side, when:

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Whatsa matter, boy -- forgot your ‘invisible juice'? Willie explodes, takes a wild swing at the big man. They struggle. They slip... players pull them apart, Willie bleeding. Tony storms into the shower with Monroe, sizes up the situation. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: All right! Stop this now! Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Players freeze. Showers continue to run.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: This kind of bush league crap doesn't cut it with me! Anybody who thinks otherwise can pack their bags right now! ‘Cause this shit is never gonna happen again! Ever! Is that clear...? You don't do that out there! Men get killed out there! (pause) «+. Thirty years in football, I never seen something that stinks like this! This is a violation! ... Today -- out there, you embarrassed yourselves and you embarrassed me. Today I am ashamed to be your coach! He stalks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unnaturally bright lights are on Willie and Cap Rooney in pads, side-by-side. They wear TV smiles, surrounded by a gang of children in Shark jerseys. Willie's cheek is stitched.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: -+. So please give generously to your Child Fund of America.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: .-. And let's make every kid feel like a superstar!

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Because giving -- like football -- is a team sport. Thank you. They smile. And smile. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That's a wrap, thanks, guys. Rooney and Willie split in different directions... we PULL BACK to reveal a small TV crew shooting a public service commercial. Christina talks with the Sharks' PR director and a TV producer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Julian Washington watches the shoot from the bleachers, brooding, upstaged by Beamen. The children from the commercial follow Willie for autographs. Willie's agent notes this to Christina as they leave. Rooney crosses to Cindy.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: You should've fought for that superstar line.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: No -- 'giving' -- ‘team sport’ -- those are the lines.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: (noting the kids around Willie) Meanwhile... You used to do this spot alone.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) Okay... you finished? Walks away. In the bleachers with the rest of the media, Jack Rose observes with his two-man TV crew. Julian studies the kids, who seem to adore Willie. An OLDER KID, 11 years old, intersects.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: Hey, J-man! Is it true you making 10 million a year? (as J-man smiles, nods ) «+. That true then ‘bout you not blocking no more? It's part of your contract? That's what my Dad says. He says you don't have to catch no passes over the middle either ‘cause you don't want to get hurt? It's also in your contract... Right, J?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: (a look) .»+. Yeah, your dad's got it down, kiddo...  198 167.

dialogues.speaker: ACTION
dialogues.text: Tony sits with Dr. Powers, Monroe and Shark Lavay -- his MRI's spread on Tony's desk, the mood glum.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: --. So what are the odds?

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: There's no telling. It's an ‘odontoid fracture’... (off their looks) Basically, he broke his neck and it never healed right. Coming after the 20 to 30 concussions he's had over 14 years, you can't predict this type of thing, but I can say this: the wrong hit could result in paralysis, Parkinson's... even sudden death.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: Hey, what else is new...?

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: In my opinion, he shouldn't be out there... (pointed at Shark) You could be braindead, your speech slurred or you could have weird personality changes for the rest of your life... you understand what I'm telling you, Luther?

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: (offset by his sanctimony) Luther do, but 'Shark' don't, Doc! I been playing with fire since you was shitting in your diapers, and right now I need one sack and three more tackles and I get my bonus. Then we'll talk, okay, motherfucker!

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: (to Shark) Y'ever seen an old punchdrunk boxer, stumbling around and drooling -- no memory of what he done in his lifetime... you want that life, Luther? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shark looks from Monty to Tony, who is conflicted, holdin his feelings close.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I can't make this decision for you, Shark.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: I don't believe this... You need me against Texas, Coach?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (pause) ‘Course I do, Shark, but no, not at this price... no.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: (pleading to play) Look, you goddamn know well as me she gonna cut my ass anyhow in the off-season! And no one's gonna pick me up for any kinda money. I'll be back here begging to play for field wages, Coach... Tony doesn't deny it, silent.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: I gave you 13 years of my best, Coach, you know you owe me... For a million bucks, shit! I'll shake like a coconut tree the rest of my life if I got to... just lemme play... please?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (pause) You'll have to sign a waiver, Shark.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: (relieved) Bring it on... Monroe shakes his head, disappointed. As he goes out with Shark:

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: (to Tony) We need to talk about Harvey, Coach... He pulls out an envelope with X-rays.  199 169.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Mandrake's on a cell phone on the sidelines with his new girl friend COURTNEY, when Tony walks up on him, furious, followed by Powers. Christina has long left the practice field.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: (into phone) +. honey, don't believe a word your mother says... don't ever say your Pappa didn't believe in you -- Me too. I...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You evil motherfucker -- !

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Tony, what are you...? (to daughter) I'll call you later, princess. Tony pulls him out of ear-shot.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Shark's film! I know what you pulled, switching the results so Powers wouldn't pick up on it!

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: (realizing) «+. Granted. It could look like that to a lay person, but to be honest, Tony...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I want you outta here. Today. Now.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Oh, I see -- you're taking the high road! Who's bullshitting who here, Tony?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Did you bother consulting him! He could get killed out there!

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: (overlapping) I knew his answer!... And getting

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: killed? Maybe, maybe not! It's one chance in a thousand, 'but nobody blitzes like the Shark,' right, Tony? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You walk off this field and you get into your car and you go far away -- I never want to see you near one of my players again. Do you understand me? Never.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Come on, Tony, most of them couldn't piss in the morning without pills.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No more -- !

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: So now you're gonna play innocent?! You know something -- fuck your innocence! This explosion draws looks from the team. Jack Rose tries to move closer to hear, but is blocked by Monroe.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: You're better than me all of a sudden?! You're better than me?! What about Beyer?! What about Nielstrum and Manzicki... and Logan... and Krause?! All these years you been turning a blind eye!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I will not have this discussion. Get out!

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Sure, Tony, don't ask the question if you don't want the answer, right? Mandrake glares at Powers.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: .+. And you, you fucking snitch! Did you ever think about him putting food on the table? Or his kids going to college?

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: You lied to me! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: (mocking) Oooh, I lied! The President lies all the time, Allie!

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: «+. and you lied to the players, and doping them, changing X-rays and --

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: And making them heroes! That's what I been doing. Who am I to tell these men they can't live their dream? These are big boys. This is triage out there, asshole! Let the man die a goddamn hero if he wants.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ! You didn't give hima choice, Harvey, you gotta give him his choice. It's a doctor's ethics.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: Since when?

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: The Hippocratic Oath, that's when...

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: You mean the one that starts: Do no harm...? With all due respect, I didn't have to ask him. I knew his choice. Was there any doubt whatever what this man must do? These players are freaks of nature -- they will not live with shame like you. These men are gladiators, warriors! And long ago they made that choice, not me. Or you! And I'm not taking that responsibility of standing between them and... (switching the approach) Did you ever have a fucking dream,

dialogues.speaker: POWER
dialogues.text: (a beat) .--. I'm living it, Harvey. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (quietly) This I mean -- get out. Mandrake is genuinely sad to leave; he looks at Tony, not without affection.

dialogues.speaker: MANDRAKE
dialogues.text: (quietly) «+. Oh fuck it! But hey, we won the Pantheon didn't we, Tony? See you around the nursing homes... (to his girl friend watching) Come on, sweetie.

dialogues.speaker: COURTNEY
dialogues.text: No, I wanna stay, Harvey... Please. Dr. Harvey Mandrake smoothes out his expensive jacket and walks away with some dignity, leaving Courtney behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony heads back to his office, unfortunately intersecting Jack Rose with his crew, and several other reporters.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: So, Coach D., what's up now -- mutiny in the medical ranks?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (blind and sudden) Get the hell out of my way, you piece of...!! He shoves Rose out of his way and storms past. Rose slips into the dugout, smacking his head on the bench. Tony doesn't turn around, but everyone else tenses, expecting trouble.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Hey!... Hey!... That's just great!... (to his crew) Did you get that!?

dialogues.speaker: HUDDLE
dialogues.text: Cap Rooney claps his hands, breaking the spell. Madman and Sanderson have been watching this, worried and confused, their doctor suddenly exiled from their lives. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Awright, guys, wake up!

dialogues.speaker: PRACTICE FIELD
dialogues.text: They move to the ball. The team is running light contact scrimmages, Crozier supervising on the sideline... Rooney scans the defense.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Blue 44. Blue 44. Hut! The snap -- the red-shirted D comes with a blitz. Rooney paralyzes, showing a moment of pure terror in his eyes as “Beast Man," the DB, pulls up short; the WHISTLE SHRIEKS.
