dialogues.speaker: BEAST MAN
dialogues.text: (reassuring him) C'mon, baby, nobody's gonna hit your pussy ass!

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Yeah -- shucks -- I know. Got happy feet. Must be gettin' old. But Rooney's grinning eyes speak of a sea change churning him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie makes his way through layers of steam. There is only one other player in the bath -- Shark Lavay. Willie considers leaving but sits... Shark gazes dispassionately at Willie, who won't look at him.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: «++. You know punks come and go in this league. They get picked up right out of the ‘hood ‘cause they can run or fight, ‘cause they're fast and strong and big. And suddenly they got all the money and the foxes that chase the money -- and they get to live ‘the dream.' But for every sucker who makes it -- for every Jerry Rice and Barry Sanders -- there are a hundred nigras you never heard of. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And when they get a step too slow or a year too old -- baby, the game tosses them back onto the street with nothing and just keeps on going like nothing happened. Sure, the game's taught ‘em how to strut their shit and talk trash and hit -- but what else?... Suddenly there's no more money, no more women, no more applause... No more 'Dream.' Shark knows it's ending for him.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: (quietly) This is what I'm saying to you, Willie: when a man looks back on his life, he should be proud of all of it. Not just a few years in pads and cleats. Not just memories of when he was... great. That he gotta learn in here... (indicating his heart) «+. or he ain't aman. He just another punk. Willie listens, lets it sink in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cap Rooney cooks hot dogs on the outdoor barbecue of his massive suburban home. The lawn is far removed, as most of the outdoor activity takes place on concrete. The three Rooney kids (two boys, one girl) are tricycling, screaming, running through doll houses -- as a busy Cindy Rooney surveys it from an upstairs balcony on the cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (entering) Hey, kids are growing, Cap. Johnny's already got big hands (the kid corrects his name, TBD).

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: My name is Johnny, Coach.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I forgot, Johnny, sorry, I got so many names in my head. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You never remember my name, Coach.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Don't shoot me.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Keep your hands off my kids willya! I'm gonna teach ‘em some golf... The kids mumble chaotically, as Rooney serves early dinne on some strange space-age plastic table.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Who wants the mustard on their hot dog...? You see the news? This guy Rose says he's gonna sue you for a million bucks! (laughs, shakes his head) If it was me, I would've left him so he couldn't remember zip -- ina

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: coma. Think they're gonna suspend you, Tony?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: «+». Do me a favor. I'd get some sleep... So, Doc Powers cleared you for Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Yeah? Great! (calling out for help with the kids) Cindy? A little help! Cindy acknowledges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony and Cap walk around the edges of a man-made lake facing the house. During the dialogue, they approach a veranda area.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Papers got us as six point dogs, you believe that? I can't wait to strap it on and stick it to Dallas like we used to. Show ‘em what this game is all about. Right there in the playoffs! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Yeah... Tony picks up on a vulnerability in the air.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Sure --

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (suddenly) The Doc got it wrong about your back?!

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: My back hurts a whole lot more than I thought, Tony, I pushed it too hard.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: We all play hurt, Cap. You just need the needle.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm sure that's it. (laughs) Maybe you oughta go with Willie though? You know, I been off -- my passing -- the whole deal --

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I seen you in practice, Cap. You're ready now. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cap doesn't respond or look at him. He sits on a swing. Tony is stunned as the realization hits him.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Cap, you don't want to go in? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Tony, it's not that, it's that... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: «+. You didn't get any phone calls I didn't know about did you?... from Christy? (as Cap shakes his head) «+. You seeing a psychiatrist or something?

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Then where the hell is this coming from, Rock? (vaising his voice) You wanted to play. I fought for you! Why didn't you tell me something, do you realize what I...

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... I didn't know.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: «+. I went out on a long limb for you, man! I took on Christina. And Willie. And the media. And you do this to me?!? I had four weeks, I woulda gone another way... Rooney swinging back and forth, proceeds with great difficulty:

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: I didn't know! I didn't know... You don't know how much I wanted to come back, Tony. You have no idea. This is all I have in my life. Everything. It's not fun anymore. I'm not what I was. Tony, the first time I got hit in the pros I thought my heart was going to stop. You're never the same after that. After all the hits and concussions, I have these blank spots in my memory. I haven't been able to straighten my good leg for years, even on a good day I shake... Sometimes I can't even hold a spoon right. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I'm on pain killers all the time ‘cause of my elbow and my ribs and my neck and my torn thigh and now my ruptured disc. But even now, with all that, I'd go back in a second... if I could only be what I was. But if I go out there, I'm gonna fold... in front of everybody. The team. My family... You. (struggling) I just can't do that. It's my body. It's my body. Tony's disgusted and moved at the same time; relents and puts a comforting hand on Cap's shoulder; his quarterback's breaking down right in front of his eyes -- he's never seen him like this. But Tony, ever the coach of men, won't allow Cap -- or himself -- to quit.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: The things you're saying are in your head, Rock -- they're not real... You know you've got it in you, because I know you do!

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Tony... if I could only be what I was? It's my body, Tony, it's just not there... Please...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I need you, Rock -- to lead this team. The team needs you. I need you... Cap dries his eyes, looks at Tony hard.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: One last time. You and me. Together... Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: (finally) «+. You need me, Tony, I'll do it for you. Ridden with doubt, Tony hugs his boy, tightly.  179.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In their screening room, alone:

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: (carefully) I don't get it... Jack?

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: I'm saying... I got my rings, we took care of our money, the kids are all right -- we had a good run... I just think it's time for me to get out... after the season...

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: And do what?

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: I talked to the guy from one of the networks --

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: You're a football player.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Cindy -- will you hear me out?

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: You are a football player and you have two, three years left in you!

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Honey, you're missing the big picture --

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: There is no 'big picture'! You are the goddamn quarterback of the Miami Sharks! You are a legend and you're talking about quitting?!... You know what that means to the kids! To me!

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: My whole fucking life I've always done what other people told me to. Ever since college... what do I do? This is my decision, not yours!!! She suddenly slaps him across the face.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: I_will not hear this bullshit from

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four sexy women in short killer skirts sway like vampires into the next club... Miami. A world outside American culture. Willie entertains his agent, Mercer, at an outdoor club overlooking the beach. Two beautiful models accompany them. Attractive people stroll by. Various ETHNIC MUSIC PLAYS, a warm, highly-artificial setting that Willie senses, as he listens absently to the dialogue at the table, a vocabulary reduced to words of expansion, contracts, and greed. On the table are covers of Sports Illustrated and ESPN sports featuring Willie.

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: «+. they'll do it, you know why? They want you!... and we'll make ‘em swallow the beer distributorship too... the thing is no one really knows how good you are, man, Willie. You get in the playoffs and you score, you get your moment? -- You can forget about this team -- they gonna lose anyhow -- but you get that one shining moment when they notice you, ‘money, when they really see you -- then you are a 'star' in this culture, baby, and you are looking at five million serious dollars next year someplace, anyplace! Maybe L.A. I'm talking intensely to L.A. Shit, Christina'll extend you right now at two million for the year... but we're gonna wait! That's why you got me, Willie B. To think about these things...

dialogues.speaker: MODEL
dialogues.text: (to Wayne) Honey, let's go dancing... I'm bored. Willie muses at the passing parade.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (absently) I hope you're doing a lotta that, Wayne, ‘cause what if I'm not made of steel?

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: Say what? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: You know, what if my arm starts hurtin'?

dialogues.speaker: MERCER
dialogues.text: (flummoxed) Where you coming from with that?

dialogues.speaker: MODEL
dialogues.text: Baby, that arm's gonna last you forever. Willie suddenly spots his old girl friend, Vanessa, movin towards the ladies' room. He jumps up, follows.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (catching up to her) Vanessa...?

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: (turns, afraid) Willie...?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: . (shy ) Hi... been a while.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: (awkward beat) Yeah... So, congratulations!...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah...!

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: You getting what you wanted...?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I was pretty stupid about it...

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: No, I don't think so. You were just...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I blew it, Vanessa. I was a fool... I'm sorry. You know it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: all happened so goddamn fast. I just wasn't ready for it... Vanessa looks over Willie's shoulder. He realizes, follows her glance to a well-dressed, middle-aged African-American businessman waiting at a table. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: +. Vanessa, I'd really like to talk to you -- when you have a...

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: I don't think so, Willie. No.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Okay. I understand... or do I?...

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: I really don't think we belong together, you're just too volatile for me, Willie. I'ma simple girl, I like simple things. Truth be told, I don't like football. I just liked you... I'm sorry. She goes, sadly. After a brief moment of indecision, Willie follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vanessa sort of expects Willie to follow.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Willie, get the... outta here!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Vanessa, listen to me, please! At the mirror, an older woman, with a bushel of white hair, looks disapprovingly at Willie.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Whoa, Barbara Bush!? Willie Beamen. You know, I always wanted to meet you ‘cause I always had this thing for... Despite herself, Vanessa laughs. "Barbara Bush" exits in a huff.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: That's it, baby -- let me see that smile!

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: (smiling) You are such a jerkoff...! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I know. Just tell me I can call you, Vanessa, come on! You gotta tell me here and now -- or I'll leave you here alone and never call you again...

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: (laughs) You bullshitter! Alright, call me -- if it'll get you the hell out of here!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (jubilant, goes) I'll be callin' you, sweetpea, you hear me? ‘Cause that date of yours... (makes a face) +. look like a pallbearer and that worries me...

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: At least he's tall. You're just jealous... Oh, I'll just be sitting by the phone, waiting...! She laughs to herself when he's gone, delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony's desk is covered with play diagrams. He's drawing new routes, as an old JAZZ RECORDING plays softly on the CD PLAYER. printouts. .. Crozier enters with a pile of computer

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: I took the probabilities on Texas. Some really promising stuff on the weak zone coverage. They run left 85 percent in the red zone when... (noticing the diagrams ) What's this?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (snorts) Nothing! I been trying to come up with some plays that Willie can't possibly fuck up. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (as Crozier laughs, sits) Nick, I don't know what the hell to do? I've tried talking to him every way I know -- yelling at him, reasoning with him, inspiring him -- the whole bit.

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: Have you tried listening to him? Try to be sensitive to what he's --

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: ‘Sensitive’? I don't know from ‘sensitive’! I only know one way to coach. Sooner or later they've got to start acting like men.

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: ++. Someone comes at you with a chop block, chief, and you stiffen, you gonna get hurt. You gotta bend... like bamboo in a monsoon. Tony doesn't answer, fingers Crozier's printouts.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: All these fucking numbers -- he runs left 18 percent faster than he runs right. He plays better on odd numbered days. Next we're gonna calculate the angle of his dick! What're we here for, Nick? We're technicians! Unexpectedly, HEELS CLICK down the corridor, and Christina suddenly walks in, furious -- throws USA Today Sports across the desk.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Congratulations! Was I the last to know? My own team?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: If you're talking about Rose, I'm gonna bar his ass from here to fucking... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: We'll see about that! I'm talking about Willie! What the hell are you doing startin' Rooney? He hasn't played in six weeks and you're going to throw him into the playoffs against the best pass rush in the league?!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Cap's my starter, Christy.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: And if we lose this game because...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (vaising his voice) I'1l do you one better: in the off-season I'm gonna trade Willie!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (stunned) You what?! That is not your option!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah, it is. The kid can sella lot of T-shirts, Christy, but he is tearing this team apart!!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Then you hold it together.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I can't! Not with him.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Then I'd say we have another problem!

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: (standing) I think I'll --

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (cising instead, to the door) Sit down, Nick! You want the big chair, get used to it first...! Hey if you feel that way about it, Christy, I don't know what the hell I can do for you -- except take a leak. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Will you stop this... posturing! Where are you going? I'm not finished. The Commissioner just called me. (as Tony stops) He's gonna fine you a 100 grand...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (stunned) For what?! Shoving that talking turd out of the way? A hundred G's!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: .-. And he wants a public apology from you to Jack Rose!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: That'll be a cold day in hell, baby!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: You will apologize, Tony. The days when ‘Uncle Tony' could just do what he wants -- calling all the shots, firing Mandrake when he wants, smacking sportswriters -- those days are over! You start Willie on Sunday and you make the adjustment to modern times -- or you're out, Tony! And that's...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (explodes ) You think you're gonna tell me what to do?! Your father never told me what to do! AND YOU'RE

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (not backing down) Will you stop using my father as a scapegoat! Do you think you don't have to deal with me by raising my father all the time? When are you going to listen to me! 'Cause I'll tell you this right now -- I'd cut my father's ass if we were losing like this!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I bet you would, too! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: «+. And you know what? I wouldn't lose a night's sleep over it. ‘Cause like you he was sentimental. And I can't afford to be. I'm in the business of holding this team together. That means selling! Selling tickets, skyboxes, players. Selling. That's why Willie works for me. He sells tickets. And that's why he's starting Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You know, I'm really sick and tired of you calling me an old asshole! Your father was no genius. He acted like he was. And he took a lot of credit for things he didn't do. But let me tell you something, he at least respected me and he respected the concept of the coach coaching and the owner owning. I can't even imagine what he'd think of you right now with this... ‘act’ you're putting on, but my hunch is he'd be ashamed!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (in a danger zone) Here we go again! You don't listen, do you --

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Ashamed!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Why the hell do you think he left me in charge, you bullheaded moron?! He could've made you General Manager -- but he didn't, did he?! Why? Because he knew you didn't have the guts to do it without him when he was gone alright! He told me so himself. Right there on his deathbed. That's why, Tony -- because he didn't trust you anymore. Because you got old! These words cut Tony hard. He puts on his game face. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (deadly quiet) Well, this old asshole has a playoff game in two days. A game which Cap Rooney is going to start and finish. Both of you -- get out. Crozier stands, a glance to Christina. They go. Tony is alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christina walks along the tennis court and enters the house through the back door, bypassing the housekeeper.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (to housekeeper) Beatriz, I'll be in Dad's office... Don't bother Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christina sits at her father's desk, living in the past. We FLOAT PAST a large portrait of her father TO the living room, where we overhear the VOICES of Tony and Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony consults with Margaret. The thick velvet drapes are always drawn tight here -- banishing the blazing Florida sun and permanently shrouding Margaret's elegant parlor in shadows... Today she burns with an oracular power.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: What is it you fear...? (pause) You have so much fear, Tony.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I'm losing the team, Maggie. I'm losing control. Everything in my life is about control. I lead men. I control men. (a pause) Did Art think I was past it?... Is that why he made Christina President? Did he think I couldn't win anymore? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Do you care? (a silence) I need your help, Maggie. Christina is going to destroy this team.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (cryptic) Yes. In order to save it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (bewildered) We can't let that happen. We owe that to Art.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: You never understood Art, Tony... He wanted a son more than anything in the world... (a considered pause) When you truly contemplate what Christina is, it really is a tragedy. Believe me, she will fire you and sell the soul of the team -- and everything her father stood for will die... and that is as it should be... and neither you nor I, or maybe even Christina herself, will ever understand her real motives...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her intensity is unnerving.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: «+. What will you do, Tony? After football? What's out there for you? With no one to control?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Stop it.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (quietly) .«+. I blame you for a lot of things. You were, like Art, a monster. You've gotten older... better, but for a long time I hated you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (as Tony is taken aback) Yes, that game took my husband, my daughter, and my youth and left me... with what? (looks around, the drapes drawn) The memory of a blazing sun all those Sunday afternoons out there at the stadium... (disconnected) Where time just slipped away. Tony looks away, betrayed, hurt.

dialogues.speaker: SIMULTANEOUS ACTION
dialogues.text: Christine cries quietly, also devastated by her mother's revelation of her character.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SONG plays through the house, ghost-like. Tony drinks whiskey, pausing, as he goes through his personal mementoes in his chest of drawers, the TV turned to:

dialogues.speaker: TV
dialogues.text: On "Sportscorner," Jack Rose, sporting a dramatic bandage across his head, similar to a Revolutionary War icon, talks to Sanderson.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: «+. Thanks, 'Sandman,' for asking -- my head is still hurting, got some migraines... and the ribs are sure sore. (grins) But hey, I play hurt! If you look at your monitor... The station runs the famous "shot" again, the ending blurry with Tony "pushing" Rose into the dugout. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: .». You know this 'punch' was more than just aggression, it was a sign of decay I think, because... Tony roars at the TV.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Aggggh! If I'd punched you, you'd be shitting out your teeth right now -- you vampire prick! He picks out Mandy's lipsticked telephone number on a piece of paper and, after a pause, tears it up.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: «+. To tell you the truth -- this is me speaking from the heart now -- I feel a little sorry for Coach D'Amato. I always hoped he'd leave this game with a little dignity left. Rose continues to rattle on in the b.g., but Tony ignores the babble of our time, removing from the drawer a small wooden box and a framed picture of a younger Tony with Jeanette, Timmy, and Melinda. He sets the box aside and picks up the picture. It is clear now that he is crying. He looks at it for a long and difficult moment, then sets the picture down and opens the box -- in it are two glimmering Pantheon Cup rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MUSIC THEME moves over a deserted field -- the night TURNING to dawn. IMAGES slowly move. Ghosts. Men who once played the game, heroic and shimmering, a thing of glory... We don't know who these ghosts are, but we sense what they represent. Some in old leather helmets, the '30s, ‘40s, ‘50s, each era unfolds its changes... le plus ca change, le plus ca reste le meme... the diving catches, the magnificent tackles and blocks, the astounding runs and passes become really the same through time -- accompanied now by the GROWING ROAR of the FANS... The MUSIC reaches a CRESCENDO with the dawn breaking, and the ghosts fade, and the stadium enters time present...  211 212 213 192.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Game 5. Playoff. Miami at Dallas.

dialogues.speaker: STADIUM
dialogues.text: The Dallas Knights stadium, with its artificial, exaggerated green Astroturf, is spectacular. The fans are stomping in anticipation. INGO McNAUGHTON (V.O.) (Dallas anchor) «+. Controversy swirls around the six point Shark underdogs. Willie ‘Steamin' Beamen, the sensational third-string miracle-mile quarterback who's held the sinking Sharks together these last four weeks, is not starting and is said to be feuding with his beleaguered Coach, Tony D'Amato -- who is being investigated by the League for having 'hit' local reporter Jack Rose at practice earlier this week... Meanwhile, immortal but vulnerable Cap Rooney -- only six weeks off a microdiskectomy on his lower back -- is definitely starting for the Sharks against the toughest pass-rush in the league. Watch for the sparks that are gonna fly! We'll be right back!

dialogues.speaker: SAME TIME
dialogues.text: Coach D'Amato stands at a podium in front of the large press corps. Jack "Ripper" Rose accepts his apology with a smug smile and a nicely-dressed bandage on his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: «+. Well, clearly the tension of the season got to me and I overreacted to an innocent question from a journalist we all know to be of the highest caliber... I only hope that one day I'll truly be able to show Jack Rose just how much I treasure his invaluable contribution to the sport of football. Thank you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He leaves the podium, eyes down... Christina and the tall, dignified AFFA COMMISSIONER, PHIL JOHNSON, are not exactly pleased with the apology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything we see suggests uncertainty, doubt, and tension... Willie reads X-men... Cap Rooney is stretched out, towel over his head, asleep...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brief MONTAGE of JUMP CUTS shows Madman's tape preparation: Ankles, knees, shoulders, jock and shorts, wrists and fingers, shoes and socks -- are heavily taped by trainer #3. In his final stage, Madman is the complete zombie warrior... Another player (OTIS), finishes praying, crosses himself, turns to Madman.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: Hey, Madman, do you really think God's on our side these days?

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN
dialogues.text: (in his growliest voice) No! Goddamnit, God's on the side of those who love themselves!! Har raa!

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM
dialogues.text: In the mirror, Sanderson is a wreck, eyes closed, whispering to himself.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: I'm the best wide receiver that ever lived! I can catch anything -.. I'm the best wide receiver that ever...

dialogues.speaker: LOCKER ROOM
dialogues.text: Trainer #1 wakes up Cap Rooney from his slumber. He rises, stoic. 213 214 215 214  216 194.

dialogues.speaker: TRAINERS' ROOM
dialogues.text: The door is closed. As the huge CROWD upstairs makes its presence known, STOMPING and ROARING, the ECHOES surging through the tunnels and pipes of the inner stadium, Dr. Powers, in temporary charge, inserts a large 18-gauge needle of cortisone directly into the swollen, scarred knee of Shark, who winces in great pain. Powers drains a straw-colored liquid into a Dixie cup.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: (hissing) God, I hate Texas!

dialogues.speaker: HORNY
dialogues.text: (poking his head in) Whoa! What the fuck they doing to you, man!

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: M'fucker, they're taking a cyst outta my ovaries!! Now get the fuck outta here... please... Powers now shines a beam of light into Shark's eyes, moving his finger back and forth in front of his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: How's that headache?

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: It was okay till you started doing that shit...

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: What about your balance?

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: You talkin' my check balance? Look p-h-a-t, baby -- 'phat.' Powers retracts the needle.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: «+. you're done.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: Gimme another one.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: (astonished) Shark, you don't need it, it doesn't make any sense medically. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: (seriously grips Powers ) I don't give a fuck about medical, Doc! Give me another one. Just for this game... please! A moment passes between them, then Powers relents, goes to get a fresh syringe. Ironically, he begins perhaps to understand Mandrake's dilemma as both a doctor and a huma being.

dialogues.speaker: LOCKER ROOM
dialogues.text: Trainer #1 harnesses Cap Rooney into a flak jacket, as creaky as El Cid in his armor, stuffed and mounted for the last battle.

dialogues.speaker: ALL TRAINERS
dialogues.text: All right, everybody! Three minutes!... Gather ‘round! Coach D. got something to say...

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: Coach D'Amato stands before the team, humbled, hiding nothing.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I don't know what to say really. We got three minutes left till the biggest battle of our professional lives... It all comes down to today. We either heal as a team or we crumble, inch by inch, play by play -- until we're finished. We're in hell right now, gentlemen, believe me. We can sit here and get the shit kicked out of us, or we can fight our way back into the light; we can climb out of this anger and this doubt and this

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: uncertainty -- we can climb out of hell -- one inch at a time, or... (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pause) «+. I wish I could do it for you, but I can't. I'm too old. I look around at your faces and I see young men and I think I made every wrong choice a middle-aged old man can make -- my life is a long list of rookie mistakes. I pissed away all my money, chased off everyone that loved me... lately I can't even stand the face I see in the mirror. This team has never heard their Coach take it to such a personal level.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: «+. As we get older, some things are taken away... well, that's part of life, but you only learn that when you lose something. You find out that life is this game of inches! So's football. Because the margin for error in either game, football or life, is so small... so small, guys. One half-step too late or too early and you don't quite make it. One half-second too slow or too fast and you don't quite catch it ‘cause it's half a fingertip away. The inches we need are everywhere around us, they're in every break of the game, every minute, every second. Mandrake forgot that. He was grabbing for miles when he only needed inches. And on this team there are no shortcuts. There are no more Doctor Mandrakes. On this team we fight for that inch! We tear ourselves and everyone else around us to pieces for that inch! We claw with our fingernails for that inch ‘cause when you add up all those inches, that is what makes the fucking difference between winning and losing -- between living and dying... In any fight I can tell you this, it's the guy who's willing to die who's going to win that inch. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I know if I'm gonna have any kind of life anymore, it's because I'm still willing to fight and die for that inch... (beat) That's what living is. (sweeps the team with a look) The six inches in front of your face. I can't make you do it. You have to look around -- look at the guy next to you -- look into his eyes -- and I think you'll see a guy you know will go that inch with you. You'll see a guy who'll sacrifice himself for this team because when it comes down to it, he knows you would do the same for him! That's a team, gentlemen!... And either we will heal now as a team -- or we will die as individuals...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie listening to these words, with new meaning.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: That's football, guys. (pause) That's all it is. (then) Now what are you going to do? Silence... The team, as if one mind, emits a roar of approval. The players hug and slap each other on the back. It is a joyous moment of sudden unification and affection, a savage release of tension. Julian jumps up onto a table, grabbing their attention.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Listen up, listen up! I got somethin' to say! The team falls quiet again.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Thank you, ‘Coach Stone Age'! (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (laughter) But you're right! Hey, you all know what I've been through. You all know about the money I get. I been hearin' all about people sayin' this and that about me. But lemme tell ya something: I'm sick and tired of it!... I love this game. I want to play this game with you people -- as part of a_team!! (as the team cheers) And I know this sounds corny but I want to thank Willie Beamen, in his own fucked-up way, for makin' me care about this game again. (turns to Willie) Come here, you little bastard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs a smiling Willie into his bear-like hug and swings him around. This is another moment of significance. The team goes wild to see these two finally connecting... And now Monroe feels he must leap on the bench to speak his piece:

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Coach put his heart and soul out for us. Give me that nasty D!

dialogues.speaker: TEAM
dialogues.text: Nasty D!

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: I_want psychodrive -- I want mad dog, drooling, rabid, teeth-bared, balls-out, limb-tearing, face- shredding INTENSITY! What -- do -- we -- live -- for, defense?!

dialogues.speaker: TEAM
dialogues.text: Turn-over! Turn-over! Turn-over!

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: What -- do -- we -- live -- for offense?!

dialogues.speaker: TEAM
dialogues.text: Touch-down! Touch-down! Touch- down !

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Team! What do we live and die for?! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TEAM
dialogues.text: Victory! Victory! Victory! The team runs roaring from the locker room. 199. 218 When most of the team has exited, Monty climbs down from the bench.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: (to Tony) Goddamn! I'm too old for this shit!

dialogues.speaker: MEDIA BOOTH
dialogues.text: Tug Kolowski and Ingo McNaughton are on the a

dialogues.speaker: TUG
dialogues.text: And here we go, ladies and gentlemen, get ready for a classic! Here in Texas, they say God made it so big and flat so everybody could play football!

dialogues.speaker: INGO
dialogues.text: (laughs) «+. That's right, Tug, years ago when Dallas was one and 15, they blamed it on God, said he was on vacation that year...

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: The opening kickoff as McNaughton calls it.

dialogues.speaker: INGO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's a huge boot from Croft... Scanlon takes it in the end zone... He's running it out...

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dangerous move...

dialogues.speaker: INGO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Scanlon skirts a tackle... he's got a block... He's got some running roo

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (laughs) Uh-oh! Watch out...! 219 ir. 220 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: INGO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He's at the thirty... the thirty- five!... He's got some daylight!... He's broken loose! He could go all the way!! The Dallas runner (Scanlon) races through Shark defenders and into the end zone. Dallas fans leap to their feet -- an enormous, pounding celebration, the sound heightened by the ECHOEY nature of the stadium.

dialogues.speaker: LUXURY BOX
dialogues.text: Christina, Ed Phillips, Joe Polito and others watch, their hopes suddenly dashed.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: It's gonna be a long day...

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Coach D'Amato claps his hands and walks down the sideline, talking to his troops, coming to a stop at Cap Rooney -- Willie close by.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Awright, awright, no big deal. We still block and tackle. (to Rooney) Stick with the game plan, Cap. You set on the first series?

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: ... Piece of cake, Coach.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Then bring it home, Rock! Rooney strides onto the field.

dialogues.speaker: STANDS
dialogues.text: The Miami section unleashes a great stomp of recognition and adoration. Huge booing from the Dallas side...

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: The Shark mascot dances. Cap Rooney is back! Two Pantheon Cup rings, anything can happen in the memory. Anything!! Willie applauds as well, looking over to see:  225

dialogues.speaker: STANDS
dialogues.text: His mom -- with an older lady friend and a younger sister at the 50-yard line. She waves to him, in her Sunday best, proud of him.

dialogues.speaker: STANDS
dialogues.text: Cindy Rooney -- with a retinue of loyal wives -- clamor for Cap.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Guys, I missed your ugly mugs.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: Whoa!... Old times, baby! Howszat disc of yours? Still spinning?

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Like Jerry Lee Lewis! Okay, Blue Twins Right Ace 90 Seam. On two. And don't let that corner take away the inside, Sandman. (grins) Trip him, tickle his nuts, I don't give a darn.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: Same old, same old. He is nonexistent!

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: On two. Ready?

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: The ball is snapped... and we go into a SERIES OF CUTS of Cap Rooney's return -- four plays, all quick, on-the- money passes, inside and out, Cap in control, moving the team like a whipmaster.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: On the fourth play, Cap finds the second wide out (Owens) for a TD!

dialogues.speaker: STANDS
dialogues.text: A Dallas fan decks an overenthusiastic Miamian...

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Shark sacks the Dallas QB -- jumpoing up and doing his "sack dance."

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There he goes! Sack number 12 of the year -- a personal high for Luther Lavay.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: But Dallas stays right in the game. A short, broken- field run, 22 yards for a touchdown. (Ingo AD LIBS.) Each man obviously rooting against the other.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Answered by a Miami 32-yard field goal...

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Willie listens and watches closely as D'Amato confers with Rooney, studying Cap's style on the field. He -- not Cherubini -- is calling in the plays, which puts him in the heart of the conflict.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Sharks are poised to score on the Dallas 11... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cap fades back -- a Dallas defender breaks through the line -- Cap scrambles out of the pocket -- no one can get open -- he tucks the ball and decisively charges the goal line. The "old man" will not be denied in a race to the goal line. A Dallas defender zeroes in on him. Rather than slide, Rooney hurls himself into the air, inspired possibly by the younger Willie and collides head-first with a Dallas defender -- a thunderclap of sound. The ball, tight in Rooney's grasp, is planted firmly beyond the goal line -- touchdown!

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: The Sharks taste the old glory!

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Rooney pulls himself slowly to his feet, accepting the congratulations of his teammates, inwardly numb, outwardl ecstatic.

dialogues.speaker: INGO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That is the meaning, in one sentence, of ‘Captain’ Jack Rooney. He will not take 'No' for an answer. I deeply admire a man of that caliber.

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ingo, I never seen you that moved by anything.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: D'Amato watches Rooney intently, sensing the worst, but basking in the glory of it -- the aging charioteer pauses in the end zone, opens his breast to the roar of the crowd. His moment in time.

dialogues.speaker: HUDDLE
dialogues.text: Rooney's significant pain carries over. His teammates keep a respectful silence, but he sweats and breathes with difficulty.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Awright, come on. Second and two, gang. Let's get it. Pro Left Y Switch Zig 90 Fade. On two. Ready? As they break:

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: (urgent, drawing a blank) What's the color?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: The live color? I can't remember the color --

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Red for Chrissake! On two! If you're fucked up, Sandman? Take yourself out, man.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: (panicked) Can't remember the plays!

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Cap fades back, a fake screen to Julian which deceives Dallas, then he flings it far downfield -- headed for Sandman... Rooney thinks it's a lock... But the pass, 45 yards in the air, is overthrown by inches! -- Sanderson, perhaps a half step late on his own, stretches but cannot grasp it -- missing by an inch -- the ball implodes, incomplete, as the Miami fans moan and the Dallas fans roar. As Cap walks to the sideline, crossing his punting unit, an eerie feeling invades a mind already fragile in confidence.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Rooney scans the defense, sees the signs for a full blitz. Under the center, his hands shake.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: (audibles) Set! Black 45... razor, razor... 495 max, 495 max... Hut! Hut! The full blitz at the Miami 35 -- two Dallas speedsters come from either side -- Rooney fakes a handoff to Julian and turns upfield -- but both Dallas defenders slam into him, a devastating double hit -- his body crumples into the grass. The ball sails from his hands -- a Dallas lineman snatching it up on the bounce and sprinting to the Miami 17.

dialogues.speaker: STANDS
dialogues.text: The crowd, which a few short minutes ago loved this man, has turned surly and unsure. Time is swift.

dialogues.speaker: STANDS
dialogues.text: Cindy Rooney knows it's over.

dialogues.speaker: LUXURY BOX
dialogues.text: So does Christina.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (to Phillips and Polito) I'm going down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON TV: The score reads Miami 17, Dallas 21.

dialogues.speaker: STORAGE ROOM
dialogues.text: In a dark and solitary storeroom, Sanderson is shaking and sweating, pathetically pleading to Dr. Powers:

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: Doc, you're my man. I'm just asking you this one time... Look at me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Stop begging, Jimmy. You're making me nervous. You'd make water nervous.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: It's like that, okay? It ain't right, Doc, I never asked you for nothing! M'fucker! Look at me, look at my goddamn hands... (shaking) Man, i live to catch passes, you understand that?! Ritalin, diet shit, anything!

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Jimmy, we been through this. I can't, I won't...

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: You're lettin' me die out there! I can't beat ‘em anymore! Half a step, it's all I'm sayin', half a fuckin' step! I'm 28, man, I'm an old man out there!

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: There is a line, Jimmy. I won't cross it. You don't need it. You can win without it.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: Who you shittin'! It's over... If you could run, catch, feel what I feel, you'd be a whole different person, Doc. You're just trying to hold me down. It's all right, man, I'll make it without you! I'll make it without you, m'fucker...!

dialogues.speaker: TRAINING AREA
dialogues.text: Trainers #1 and #2 work on Cap Rooney, re-taping his bruised ribs and back, as Tony crosses in.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Can you play?

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: .+. Banged up, but I'm okay... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Can you play?

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Yeah... you bet.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Rock -- look at me -- can you play? Rooney looks at him. His face tells the story.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You fought like a son-of-a-bitch out there, Rock... I will never forget this.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: -++- Go do your job, Coach.

dialogues.speaker: LOCKER ROOM
dialogues.text: Tony moves around the locker room, studying his team. He locks eyes with Willie, who comes over. They speak quietly.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: This isn't about you and me anymore. You've got to lead them, Willie. When they look in your eyes, they gotta believe.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I know... Christina -- surprising everyone -- enters the locker room, moving quickly past the players. With Ed Phillips and Joe Polito backing her, she seeks out Tony.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: What do you think you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (seething) You got no business here -- I told you not to come here!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Don't you see what's going on, you... Tony sweeps Christina by the elbow, into the small visiting coach's locker room.  208.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (as intense as he can get) Leave here before I lose my temper, Mrs. Pagniacci, do you hear me?!...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: I_don't care what your problem with him is -- alright!? Cap Rooney is over! You're the only one that's failed to see... Outside, the players listen silently. He throws A pause. Christina

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: NEVER -- NEVER -- talk that way in front of my players! Do you understand!... or I'll spank the living shit out of you, little girl!!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (scared) Don't talk to me like that! It's MY team too! And I don't give a fuck if Willie's changing the plays! You let your ego get in the way of this team, and it is going to cost us the game!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: GET OUT! GET OUT NOW! Before I... a chair. Willie enters tentatively...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Miss Pagniacci...? I'm sorry but... (as Christina waits) «+. Coach D'Amato -- he already told me I'm going in. They all share looks.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (quietly) Jesus Christ, Christy... What the hell happened to you...? exits, her dignity intact. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (nods to Willie) Good...! Prove ‘em wrong, Willie... She crosses to the main locker room, her entourage following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony is talking fast to Willie as they move down the tunnel. The sound of the CROWD GROWING...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: .»-- Take control of the huddle, get ‘em in and out quick. Take advantage of the box while the speaker's hot.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE, (TBD)
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Keep an eye on the front four. Make them work sideline to sideline, they'll slow down, and when you see them, take a knee, lookin' for some air, they're losing it. Then you go right at ‘em. Control the line of scrimmage, and you're gonna control this game.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Stats don't mean shit to me. Get me five yards on first, and they'1l have to worry about stopping both you and Julian. Possession of the ball -- that's all I want. Move those chains.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Read the safety's drop, if he's flat footed or in his backpedal, we go downtown. Keep ‘em honest with your eyes. The longer you look them off, the tougher it is for them to make their break. Surprise 'em, make it sudden, Willie. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What are you, Gary Cooper?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Forget it. Remember, keep them off balance with the hard count. That will slow the pass rush and buy you more time. If you see their arms shaking and their asses up in the air, they're coming... Control the line of scrimmage, you're gonna control this game, Willie

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Coach, you said that already...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: «+. And don't forget to look for the mismatches! (as Willie sighs; he repeats) Look for the mismatches. You'll find one... One more thing! (carefully) Right out of the gate, let it fly. Go 999, and shock the shit out of ‘em. He grins at a surprised Willie. As they now break from the tunnel, the ROAR of the Dallas crowd, and the excitement of the sportscaster's voices overwhelms all.

dialogues.speaker: INGO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well, everyone knows it's ‘crunch time' for Steamin' Beamen. Cagey old veterans have been known to crack under playoff pressure -- so you gotta wonder how this rather volatile kid'll stack up...

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: No, sir! Prisoners will not be taken in this second half! The surviving team goes to Minnesota next week for the Conference Championship.  250 251 252 211.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Willie steps to the side, alone -- and vomits quietly... then he jogs out onto the field for the second half.

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh boy! Dallas is in trouble now ‘Willie's Ritual.' You know, Ingo, in Tampa Bay one time you looked just like that after... Ingo finally laughs.

dialogues.speaker: HUDDLE
dialogues.text: Willie, totally focused, assesses his teammates. He spots Cap Rooney, in uniform, signaling in the play!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Okay, Strong Left Zig 90 Gun, on three, serious -- it's their call. And by the way, guys -- (beat) I apologize for having a big head back there -- but that wasn't me. It was the Devil Red 6-6-6. (as they laugh) Now let's get this bitch before they know what hit ‘em! On three. Ready! They clap and break, believing it. Over Willie:

dialogues.speaker: CAP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (helmet) Watch for the robber on the right... you know it's a beautiful thing to watch you throw, kid!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Good to hear you say that, not-so-old-man.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Set! Black 41, Black 41! Hut! Hut! Hut! Willie steps back, flings it far... 50 aerial yards... Interception!... An upset roar from the Dallas fans.  212.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Willie jogs back, past Tony, loose about it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (into headset) ... hey at least he ran the play I called!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (to Tony) One inch to the left, it would've worked.

dialogues.speaker: LUXURY BOX
dialogues.text: The AFFA Commissioner, with a small entourage, is watching part of the game in Christina's box.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: -.. Let me on the Finance Committee, Phil, and I know I could make a difference with the networks. I know New York, I...

dialogues.speaker: COMMISSIONER
dialogues.text: Your mother looks great, by the way...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Thank you. She's always loved Dallas. Loves Neiman Marcus.

dialogues.speaker: COMMISSIONER
dialogues.text: Great lady. And your golf?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: I'm about an 11 now... from the whites. Think you can take me?

dialogues.speaker: COMMISSIONER
dialogues.text: Whoa! Not bad! I'm afraid I'm not in your class, Christina. (cising to leave) Good game. Good team. (crossing to Margaret with her two pet dogs in hand) Margaret...

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: It's nice to see you, Phil.

dialogues.speaker: COMMISSIONER
dialogues.text: Still miss Art. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I do, too... (displaying her new dog) Have you met Gabrielle?

dialogues.speaker: COMMISSIONER
dialogues.text: (a beat) ++. so I have. He moves, with great dignity, to the door.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (following him, unsatisfied) Phil, I'd really like to... They're out of earshot at the door. The Commissioner, obviously under some pressure of his own, decides to tell her now.

dialogues.speaker: COMMISSIONER
dialogues.text: Christina, the owners would like you to come up to New York for a meeting. Sometime before the first of the year... if possible?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (surprised) Oh? About what, sir?

dialogues.speaker: COMMISSIONER
dialogues.text: Well... there's a concern that's been voiced about some moves that were made... mmm, on your behalf, for another Los Angeles franchise -+. Several of the Association's rules may have been violated on this. We've heard that...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: (stunned) Who! Who said this? Who's been saying this...! She checks herself.

dialogues.speaker: COMMISSIONER
dialogues.text: Is Wednesday this week too soon?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: Not at all. That'll be fine, sir. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: COMMISSIONER
dialogues.text: Good. Then the best of luck to you today... He exits.

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR OUTSIDE BOX A261
dialogues.text: The Commissioner, on the way out, shakes his head, to an associate.

dialogues.speaker: COMMISSIONER
dialogues.text: +. I honestly believe that woman would eat her young.

dialogues.speaker: LUXURY BOX
dialogues.text: Christina, staggered, turns to Ed Phillips and Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA
dialogues.text: What the hell happened!?

dialogues.speaker: ED PHILLIPS
dialogues.text: I don't know, but somebody opened his big mouth. And I'll bet you it was our friend the Mayor!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY POLITO
dialogues.text: You're missing the point, Ed. This guy definitely doesn't want her in L.A. That's the point. Christina is worried.

dialogues.speaker: SCOREBOARD
dialogues.text: Reads: MIAMI 17, DALLAS 28. THIRD QUARTER. 4:27...

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Dallas has added another TD! It looks dicey.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (to Willie) Branco's aching to nail ya. He's playing for the cameras. Go Split Left 90 Hitch, but if you think Branco's gonna bite, audible a fade right to 'Sandman.' (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: You gonna let me check off? Where's the coach I know and love?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: If Branco bites.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: You git it, Coach.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Willie scans the defense. As predicted, the Dallas player (Branco) is tensed for the blitz, his knuckles white to the astroturf.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (audibles) Set! Blue 22... razor, razor... 955, 955... Hut! Branco breaks through! Willie, expecting it, throws a classic screen pass to Julian, who rumbles for 15 plus yards. Branco lies on the field, bleeding. His eyeball lies several feet away. It is shocking, and quickly covered up by the TV cameras.

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Time out. And we'll be right back, folks, after a word...

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: A classic sweep follows, run by Washington, thundering towards Tony on the sideline; he turns the corner with a great block from Madman, and picks up another 20 yards to the Dallas 12-yard line.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Tony, rediscovering the purity of the sweep, smiles to himself. Monroe catches Tony's expression and gives him the "up." (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Willie hands off to Sanderson, who hands it to the second wide receiver, Owens, who runs a reverse 20 yards in for a touchdown!

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: The Dallas QB answers right back. Running in for a TD!

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: It's now Dallas 35, Miami 24 -- 11 points. We PULL DOWN FROM the scoreboard to:

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (re: Dallas QB, to D'Amato) Whatsamatter with this guy? Doesn't he know I'm gonna whip his ass?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Maybe no one's told him yet.

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: (to Willie) You can beat him, Willie. I know his mind... If you hit for another score now, quickly, he'll fold, I know it. Cap's eyes are solid, supportive. Willie believes.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA'S LUXURY BOX
dialogues.text: In a quiet moment, Christina notices most of her associates talk business on cell phones or to each other, only watching the game in quick eyebursts -- she hears a buzzing chorale of "increasing market shares" and “merchandizing revenue streams" and "league relocation protocols..." Margaret sits in a quiet corner with a friend, sipping on a Bloody Mary. She smiles over at her daughter.  262 263

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: The Shark offense is on the Dallas 25, third and seven. Willie is over the ball. His eyes focus... A Dallas safety has his "go to" foot a slight inch ahead of the other. Willie smiles.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (audibling) Set! Zorro, Zorro... Red 66, Red 66... Hut! Willie spins back and hands the ball off to Washington on a counter. Washington shoots through the line with room to run.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Go, baby! Downfield, a Dallas defender tries to force Washington out of bounds, but spinning on a dime, Washington cuts back towards the center of the field -- Dallas defenders tackle him -- one, two, three at a time -- but he drags them for another five yards -- into the end zone. Touchdown!... Willie is the first downfield to jump all over him.

dialogues.speaker: SCOREBOARD
dialogues.text: MIAMI 31, DALLAS 35. FOURTH QUARTER. 02:00... Miami time-outs remaining: 2. A WHISTLE BLOWS. The clock runs.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: The Dallas offense at the Miami 24 -- Third and seven.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Tony talks closely and intently with Willie...

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: The Dallas QB pitches to the flat -- his running back snares the ball and cracks back for a few extra yards -- tired tackling from the exhausted Sharks.  266 267 268 218.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Fourth down and one. Miami 18-yard line. Tony looks... The Dallas field goal unit is not coming out. They're going for it! Tony calls a time-out... Shark runs off the field to sidelines. Tony and Monroe converse with Shark.

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -.. And Dallas is goin' for it! They're takin' as much time as they can in their huddle. The clock is tickin'. One minute fifty. Whew, am I feeling this in the pit of my stomach! Oh, boy!

dialogues.speaker: INGO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Gutsy move on Dallas's part! Fourth and one, they're taking a big chance here. They could take an easy field goal and even if Miami got a touchdown, the game would go into overtime. But ‘Coach U' smells victory now, not a tie, a real gambler...

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .+. Hey, I'd do the same thing, Ingo. That's the kind of play calling I like! It wins ball games !

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Tony and Willie stand close as we hear:

dialogues.speaker: INGO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is the game, Tug! If Miami can hold them here, Willie Beamen will have one last chance.

dialogues.speaker: PRESS BOX
dialogues.text: Jack Rose is outside himself, rooting.

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is it, guys and dolls, this is where the famous rubber meets the famous road!  269 270 271 219.

dialogues.speaker: MIAMI DEFENSIVE HUDDLE
dialogues.text: Shark, bloody and exhausted, yells at his defensive unit:

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: Y'all gonna make this tackle, bitches! Everything we done for is on the line!! This play! Right now! Right here! Forever! Be proud!

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS QB
dialogues.text: Make the first here, take a knee and it's hello Minnesota. On one. Ready?! They clap and move to the ball.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: As the Dallas QB scans the defense, Shark calls for a shift in the Miami defense.

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS QB
dialogues.text: Go! 47 Tiger... Monday, Monday... 48 Bandit, 48 Bandit... Hut!

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: (simultaneous to Dallas QB) Roll-left! Roll-left! Orbit Wheel! Strong right! Edge back! Orbit Left! Omaha Orbit Left! The defensive players scurry to new positions. The Dallas QB shoots back, handing off to the running back. Shark waits, poised to fill the hole. The back powers forward, no running lanes -- he bounces to the outside, sees daylight, speeds for it... Shark runs desperately to the same hole on his bum and swollen knee. The runner is almost to the first down marker -- inches! -- He dives for it! Shark dives at the exact same time -- an all-out lunge of sheer faith to stop the first down -- at any cost! Shark and the runner collide, a loud crash! The runner is stopped! An inch or two short of the first down marker! The Miami 18.  272

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Tony and Monroe go nuts in each other's grasp. Just like the old days!

dialogues.speaker: SCOREBOARD
dialogues.text: Clock stops for the change of possession. 01:34...

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: But Shark lies there like a dead man -- no motion! Dr. Powers and two trainers race onto the field.

dialogues.speaker: STANDS
dialogues.text: Shark's wife and kids look on, terrified.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Tony hurries out, as does Monroe. In b.g., Willie and Cap wait in the grip of fear. The entire team waits. Tony and Monroe now run out.

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Shark Lavay is down and it looks bad, but he definitely squashed Dallas's first down, and it's now Miami's ball. I can't think of a finer way to take a hit like that for your teammates!

dialogues.speaker: INGO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No, sir! What a great tackle! One for the record books!

dialogues.speaker: MEDIA BOX
dialogues.text: ON TV: The tackle replayed... Then the medical cart is shown on the field. Nothing is said. The stadium is hushed.

dialogues.speaker: INGO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well, Miami has one time-out remaining. They're down by 4 with 1:34 left. Nothing less than a touchdown will...  277 278 279 221.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Shark is definitely not moving. The ambulance waits near the goalpost. Tony, Powers, Monroe, and the trainers wait helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Shark, talk to me please! (to others) Jesus Christ, is this the way it starts...? Is he ever gonna...? They ease him onto a stretcher when suddenly Shark's eyes open, falling on Tony with a glazy smile -- and a huge headache!

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: (weakly) «+. I... stop ‘em?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (deeply relieved) Oh, Shark! You stopped ‘em cold, baby! Godammit!

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: You got the bonus, baby! A million bucks!

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: (dreamy ) A million dollars...! (sees Powers) Say, Powers...? Powers AD LIBS.

dialogues.speaker: SHARK
dialogues.text: Are you still white?

dialogues.speaker: STANDS
dialogues.text: Both sets of fans roar their appreciation for his valor, as he tries to acknowledge them with a weak wave of his arm, as they cart him off.

dialogues.speaker: STANDS
dialogues.text: Shark's family, next to Willie's mom, reacts with great relief and joy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He's okay! He's okay! Shark Lavay, one of the greatest the game has ever seen, has probably played his last game, but I can think of no...

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Tony clasps Willie by the shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: He gave you the shot, Willie. Now take it. (as Willie nods) -+. It's your time. Willie runs out, the crowd going nuts!

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: First and ten on the Miami 18. 82 yards to go. 1:34...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: drops back in the shotgun formation -- no pass lanes open, all covered, Willie drops a short screen to Julian, who dazzles on a 16-yarder out of bounds.

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Second and ten. 66 yards to go. 55 seconds. One false step and that's all she wrote, my friends.

dialogues.speaker: INGO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Coach D'Amato is gonna need every blessed one of those seconds.

dialogues.speaker: HUDDLE
dialogues.text: Willie notices Sanderson is rattled, his eyes closed, sweating a storm. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Fourth Quarter. 55 seconds left. It's do or die. Pro Left Red 88 Bronco. On two... You tight, ‘Sandman '? Eye to eye.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: Tighter than pussy on pre-wedding day...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (grins) That's why you're the best! You like pussy as much as I do! Okay then, let's show these big-ass Texas boys what road-kill looks like! Keep it lethal, ‘money. We're through on two.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Willie in shotgun formation -- Three wide outs.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (scans the defense, audibles) Set! Red 44... Razor, Razor... 88 Sally, 88 Sally... Hut! Hut! Willie again sees nothing, the receivers all expertly covered. But then he sees -- a chance -- a desperate chance -- Sanderson is slanting free downfield --

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Tony sees it as well:

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Do it! Do it!

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Willie takes that cubic centimeter of chance; he flings it deep... In breathless suspense, the ball sails. Sanderson, sweating like a pig in his helmet, sees it, adjusts his route mid-stride... It's as if it is his soul flying towards him, which he now catches! And then runs it in another 15 yards into the end zone! A miracle! Jimmy Sanderson feels himself freed of the demons!  287 288 289 290 224.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: A frenzied celebration on the Miami sideline -- in the stands -- they've won! But suddenly... Tony is crestfallen.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: A yellow penalty flag lies on the field... Holding!

dialogues.speaker: REFEREE
dialogues.text: No touchdown. Holding on offense #69. Repeat second down. Ten yards. Madman furiously shoves Referee #3 in argument, and the Referee ejects him from the game (AD LIB).

dialogues.speaker: INGO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh, that might just be the back- breaker right there!

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: That would take the air out of any tire. It's gonna take an enormous amount of will now to...

dialogues.speaker: LUXURY BOX
dialogues.text: Christina and her guests groan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire field stretches before Willie and the offense in the huddle. Never has 76 yards looked so long.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Christina sits down next to her mother; they talk AD LIB -- a new attitude shaping between them.

dialogues.speaker: HUDDLE
dialogues.text: 39 seconds.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Okay, this is the way I like it -- we got 'em just where we want ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: You are such a punk! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Watch your mouth or I'll take it in myself.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I liked you better when you were puking.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Nice and easy, boys. One play at a time. Keep the routes sharp and kiss the sideline like it's the hottest momma you ever seen and we are there! Lemme hear it, brothers! (as the team roars) Lemme hear it again! (louder, even more inspired) Now let's see the swagger, motherfuckers! The team claps, breaks, and starts to the line. The Dallas defense is worn by the swagger and trash-talking coming right at them.

dialogues.speaker: CAP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (helmet) .«.. take another pop at that weakside safety. He's pretending.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: A flurry of plays -- Tony firmly in control -- each play well-called and quickly executed -- relayed from Tony to Crozier, to Cap to Willie. A chain of minds. Every person doing their job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Subjective -- A caught pass -- a runner leaps out of bounds -- a screen pass slanting out of bounds...

dialogues.speaker: COACHES' BOOTH
dialogues.text: Crozier reeling off the plays in conjunction with Tony. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sharks moving downfield like a ravaged but hungry 4th quarter machine. Sanderson is back to his natural glory, playing without the help of substances.

dialogues.speaker: SCOREBOARD
dialogues.text: MIAMI 31, DALLAS 35. 35 yards to go. 13 seconds.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Willie, gazing over the defense at the line, doesn't like what he sees, calls his last "time out."

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That's it! The last one! Something seems to be wrong!

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Willie jogs over to Tony.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: They had it cold.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Smart move. How ya doing?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I'm ready to win.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You know, there's something important I gotta ask you...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: That day you came over to my house, I made dinner for you?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (wary) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Did you not like the jambalaya? Willie looks at him and laughs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Well, frankly, Coach, it sucked -- needed more seasoning... That's why I been throwing up every week.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (smiles) I thought that. Just go out and kick their ass and win the game!

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: Willie scans the end zone -- would love to take a_ shot - but there's nothing -- he throws the ball away, spikes the clock.

dialogues.speaker: SCOREBOARD
dialogues.text: Now reads 35 yards, 9 seconds left...

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Tony stares at the field, at Willie, deep in thought -- it seems the biggest decision of his career is always now

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (to Crozier) Comanche.

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: You're kidding!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Let the kid do his thing!

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Tony, we got nine seconds -- ! You're banking on... Tony casts his eyes skyward at Crozier in the box. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: This is what coaching's all about, Nick. You up to it? Crozier breathes and relays the play to Cap, on to Willie

dialogues.speaker: CROZIER
dialogues.text: Okay you got it. Spread West Hustle 60 Comanche Right. Remind him he's got the option -- rifle or spread formation, check at the line...

dialogues.speaker: HUDDLE
dialogues.text: Willie hears it from Cap and looks over at Tony in amazement. Tony nods... Willie shakes his head. Okay!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (loose) Okay, guys, it can't get more fun than this! I swear to God I didn't call this one. Spread West Hustle 60 Comanche Right, check with me. On one. Ready.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Man has balls of iron.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Tony is the man! We together on this, J-man?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Dynamic duo, brother.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I feel you. Let's see that all- pro strut, baby! Ready? Check with me on one. Ready?

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: They break and line up over the ball. Willie scans’ the defense.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Set, Rifle 22, Rifle 22! Hut! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Willie pump fakes a pass to Sanderson -- the Dallas defenders flinch left to cover him -- Willie immediately takes off right with the ball, skimming the outside of the line -- Madman delivers a devastating block -- Julian runs slightly behind Willie, ready to throw his block -- ... but Willie sees some daylight, and tears down the sideline -- the Dallas safety is racing him -- Just as he zooms in on Willie, he laterals the ball to Julian just behind him... Julian snags the ball -- leaps around the safety, who slams Willie out of bounds -- Julian races against time down the sideline, turning on the afterburners -- the game clock.

dialogues.speaker: SCOREBOARD
dialogues.text: Game clock ticking down... 00:07... 00:06... 00:05...

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Faces: Tony, Cap, Monroe, others...

dialogues.speaker: STANDS
dialogues.text: Faces: Cindy, others...

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: A Dallas corner is moving fast onto Julian -- but Julian, flashing the clock, plays smart -- without selfishness -- no dazzling spin moves -- no evasions -- he dives out of bounds.

dialogues.speaker: SCOREBOARD
dialogues.text: The clock freezes. Three yards to go. No penalty. Four seconds. One play.

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh my God! My heart is up in my mouth right now! Ingo! This is what football's all about... Torture!  299 300 301 302 230.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (to Crozier, re: Willie's running) He's still holding onto that thing like a loaf of bread. Someone's gonna take it from him. (to Cap and QB coach; looking at Willie) ... Is he okay?! (to Julian) Way to run! (to Cap and staff) He did it for once! He thought with his head, not his balls -- unselfish! Great move... let's go... four seconds. One time. I love this game!

dialogues.speaker: PRESS BOX
dialogues.text: Jack Rose is as excited as any ll-year-old kid, praying to more worldly gods.

dialogues.speaker: LUXURY BOX
dialogues.text: Christina and her Mother share the moment of together, rooting for once as a family.

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Willie now huddles with Tony, forehead to forehead, talking low, confidently, as Cap listens.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Take a breath...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Okay... okay...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You set?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Then make ‘em believe, Willie. This time. Now. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAP
dialogues.text: Remember: See it before you do it, kid. Willie nods and runs back onto the field, as there are no time outs left!

dialogues.speaker: STANDS
dialogues.text: The fans are in an uproar, stomping, screaming! A man in a gorilla suit with a placard: "I've gone ape over Willie!" is pushed and mauled by irate Dallas fans. Off flies his ape head!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Well, it's our time in the sun, guys. (looks into each face) One on one, man on man, together! Left Tank Stack 421 Rhino. Lean and mean. On three. Ready! They break and line up over the ball at the four yard line. Willie scans the defensive alignment. The play clock marches...

dialogues.speaker: STANDS
dialogues.text: The breathless crowd...

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: pointing, shifting positions, trying to confuse Willie.

dialogues.speaker: SIDE LINE
dialogues.text: Players kneeling on the sidelines, some praying, barely daring to watch, some chewing nails, others screaming encouragement... Cap Rooney whispers a silent prayer for Willie. Coach D'Amato -- the picture of a man at a zenith in his life...  307

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Set Black 66, Black 66. Hut! Hut! Hut! A sudden torrent of movement -- Miami slams forward -- Dallas slams back -- in SLOW MOTION, Julian reaches for the handoff -- the ball slaps into his stomach -- a convincing fake -- as Willie keeps the ball -- Julian leaps left -- Dallas defenders surge to cover him -- at that moment Willie chooses to go right back over the hole Julian has collapsed. High over the goal line -- he seems to sail through the air for suspended moments -- he is almost there -- almost across the plain of the goal line, almost to glory -- as a wall of Dallas players rise up to meet him like a breaker at sea... Willie crashes into it...

dialogues.speaker: GHOST A307
dialogues.text: whoever he be -- from another time -- diving with him. Willie seems to bauble the football as he disappears into "big Wednesday." All SOUND CEASES. Wind plays off the grass... In the silence of the major pileup, bodies draped and intertwined like smoking car wrecks, referee #2 digs out the players, one by one, looking for the ball «+. the tension rising to extraordinary heights! Where the fuck is it?

dialogues.speaker: SIDELINE
dialogues.text: Tony waits silently...

dialogues.speaker: TUG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I think he lost it, Ingo!

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: A player peels off, revealing Willie smiling, the ball held awkwardly up around his neck, but firmly in his possession... Referee #2's arms now shoot up in SLOW MOTION -- touchdown!
